Entry.2:
1916
There were seven of us M.T. men to be drafted to England on the White Star liner "Medic". A.7. We arrived on the wharf at Port Melbourne at 9am& went on board at 10.30. At 11amafter all the men were aboard the crowds were allowed free access to the wharf, where they kept up a constant stream of last words & good.bye wishes to their friends on board until at the warning for sailing, streamers were thrown from ship to shore, & shore to ship, which with all the different colours criss.crossed in the bright sun, looked very grand as the ship gradually sheered away until all the paper streamers snapped & communication was severed. - The sea was smooth with a slight swell & we felt very good sailors for the time being. Our little party ^of eight had their quarters on a troop deck amidships, a very good possie. we found the food good being served with a.1. butter. Some of us slept on deck.

Dec.17
th
. 1916
A beautiful day. We were in the Australian Bight about noon and though it wasnt rough, the motion caused some of the fellows to feel a bit green & off their tucker, I wasnt too confidant of myself, but was caused no inconvenience. We slept on deck.
Entry.4:
1916
Had a good night on deck. It was chilly enough to appreciate a Balaclava cap, which I had with me. After breakfast we had a parade at 9.15 amand physical jerks followed by a ragtime lecture - three of our party of 
seven
eight were sick,Rog. being constantly bad and unable to eat. A party of fun seekers went round the decks clipping mens hair and it wasn't long before every man had short hair (very short too).
Entry.6:
1916
It is a bit colder to-day, but the sea behaves well, & most of the men are feeling well. Rog. feels better to-day. We wrote some letters as we heard they might be collected by a passing ship (bluff I think). There is slight friction between the N.C.O in charge of our troop deck & the men under him. He is a backsheesh sergeant major whose nick name is "monk".

Dec.20th 1916
A bigger swell today. I assisted Hec. as mess orderly, getting the tucker at meal times, washing up after and generally cleaning up. In the afternoon we were allowed fresh water for washing our clothes, there was also a bathing parade.

Dec.21st 1916
We are said to be in the Indian Ocean now, the sea is very blue and there is a bigger swell, the wind was cold all day. Rog. is bad again and won't come down to meals or take any exercise, we coax him with something to eat on deck.

Dec.22nd 1916
I went down in the engine room with Hec. to have a look round, saw all there was to see, and went down the tunnel to the end of the propellor shafts. "Medic" is twin screw and averages 13 knots per hour, burning about 120 tons of coal per day. We played whist in evening.

Dec.23rd 1916
We had only one parade today and did our washing in the afternoon, there was a big swell on all day - We played whist in the evening - passed a ship during the night, which we saw from our beds on the deck where we always sleep, though we were sent below by a shower of rain at 4 amthis morning.
Entry.7: Lovely day & Sunday, we lay on the boat deck in the sun all the morning reading. We were supposed to be on a deck sweeping fatigue but were dismissed at the last minute.
Entry.8: Oh! what a Christmas, dull cold day. The cooks had been enjoying their xmas, before breakfast which we had an hour late and were lucky to get at all, it consisted of eggs and bacon and the eggs were plum cold. There was not much xmas feeling about and the meals all badly prepared & no comforts issued as we had been led to expect they would be - we played whist in evening.
Entry.10:
1916
Lovely day, we just sat around and listened to the S.M. airing his knowledge of horses to the A.S.C in his charge. We had lifebelt drill in the afternoon. We played cards in the evening. (A.S.C - Divy. sigs& M.T were together).
Entry.12:
1916
This is my third day with avery severe head cold which came on me very suddenly. The boat is rolling more now, they had some engine trouble but have fixed it up & we are again making good time.

Dec.28th 1916
We were chased off the deck at 3 amthis morning by a shower of rain but it cleared up later & was a fairly fine day, my cold eases off towards evening. Read 'The Wilderness' Joseph Hocking - In the evening we played 500.

Dec.29th 1916
It was very showery today, we had physical jerks all the morning. Sports were held in afternoon & evening, the record for skipping was 3380 - We had a front seat for the boxing in the evening.

Dec.30th 1916
A beautiful warm day we were on fatigue preparing for the sports which were held in the afternoon, & we had a front seat again in the evening for the boxing.

Dec.31st 1916
Sunday again & another beautiful day with a shower or two at intervals. We are mostly wearing shorts & singlets & going bare-foot. I spent the day on the deck in the sun reading & sleeping. I read "Happy Valley' B.M. Crocker, very pretty yarn. Saw one of the most beautiful sun-sets I have ever seen & watched it intently for over an hour - & the night was wonderful - so ends the year 1916.

1917
Entry.13:
st
 1917
Another beautiful day, sports were continued, we have only one parade a day on account of the sports. The ships company gave a concert in the evening but I didn't attend it I wrote some letters instead.
Entry.14:
nd
 1917
Rainy & a very lumpy sea. We all stayed below all day with port holes closed. Played 500 in the evening & then had to sleep below.
Entry.15:
rd
 1917
Beautiful day & the sea has gone down a lot. We had a death on board & he was lowered over the side with ceremony at 11 am. We watched the boxing in the evening when Darkie McLeod fought Morris.
Entry.16:
th
1917
Very hot day. I sat in the sun all morning perspiring, then had a shower. In the afternoon I lay in the shade & read "The Quaker Girl". We played 500 in the evening.
Entry.17:
th
 1917
Very hot sun & choppy sea, also strong wind.- on sweeping fatigue in the morning. We sighted land at 6 pm& cruised off Durban all night.
Entry.18:
th
. 1917
We pulled into Durban first thing in the morning & were welcomed by a lady whom we saw signalling to us with flags - We had a route march through Durban in the morning & 
at
 were then given leave from 2 till 10.30 pm. The trams were free to troops & we had a ride round. The day was a little bit showery but the sun was very hot. Had a hot bath & went to the Y.M.C.A. concert in the evening. Like Durban very much. 
Had
 Had a ride in a ricksha.
Entry.19:
th
 1917
Sunday & we had a church parade ashore. It was raining all day, & we were given leave 11.30 amtill 10 pm.
Entry.20:
th
 1917
Went for a five mile route march in the morning. Lovely day - given leave from 2 pmtill 10 pm. Went to museum & art gallery,didn't think much of them - Had a swim at the Marine Parade baths, & had tea on the Parade - Went to Y.M.C.A. concert in the evening.
Entry.21:
th
 1917
We put out into the bay & left Durban at 12.30 mid-day three hours behind the "Berimar",we were in sight of land during the rest of the day - lovely day & smooth sea.
Entry.22:
th
 1917
The rain chased me off the deck at 2 ambut it cleared up at 10 am& the rest of the day was beautiful - we kept in sight of land all day - read all day & played euchre in the evening.
Entry.23:
th
 1917
We were out of sight of land for a few hours, but came in sight again at about 4.30 pm. We played crib in the evening. We slept on deck but it wasn't too good, it was windy & cold.
Entry.24:
th
 1917
We got into Cape Town first thing. All the troops went ashore at 12.30 except a fatigue party (& I made one) who were kept on board to load stores & worked like horses till 7.30 pmwith the promise that we should go ashore the following day - We went ashore after we had finished our work & had a hot bath & a feed & went aboard again at 10.30 pm.We shipped a gun & gun crew -
Entry.25:
th
1917
We pulled out into the bay at 7 am& dropped anchor - we were not allowed ashore as promised, and it was a lovely day wasted.
Entry.26:
th
 1917
Sunday & we spent a lazy day laying about all day - lovely day.
Entry.27:
th
 1917
Still standing out in the bay with five other transports,latest latreen wire is that we will sail to-morrow. We played crib & 500 - I slept below on account of a cold on my chest.
Entry.28:
th
 1917
We weighed anchor at 1.30 pmwith the five other transports,"Berimar" "Orsova" "Kenilworth Castle" "Port Littleton" & one other,escorted by the cruiser "Cornwall" - The sea was smooth as a mill pond, the weather beautiful & we watched the flashing of mirrors from all along the shore they looked like diamonds flashing in the sun, the Cape's farewell to the convoy -
Entry.29:
th
 1917
Sea still smooth & weather lovely, we played cards in the afternoon & evening - The port holes are closed daily at sunset also the dead-lights - I slept on deck under the awning.
Entry.30:
th
 1917
The "Orontes" caught us up to-day & stayed with the convoy - the weather is still fine & the sea smooth - we played, draughts & cards -
Entry.31:
th
 1917
We had another death aboard,a sergeant,the ship slowed up at 11 am& a service held & the body lowered overboard to the accompaniment of the last post on the bugle. Tom honed a razor for me & did it well. We played the old cards again in the evening. I slept on the hatch.
Entry.32:
th
 1917
Our gun was fired a couple of times for practice & we also had a boat alarm practice -
Entry.33:
st
 1917
Sunday - weather warm & fine I take on mess orderly duties for a week with Tom.
Entry.34:
nd
 1917
Weather warm & sea calm - all the clothing that is worn by most of us is a pr of shorts & sometimes a singlet & sometimes not. We put on the gloves on our own deck for a bit of exercise,found it very strenuous.
Entry.35:
rd
 1917
It gets warmer every day now & the sea remains smooth - I went down to the stoke hold & put in three quarters of an hour coal trimming. Had a hot bath & a shower when I came up played cards in the evening.
Entry.36:
th
 1917
Had some more exercise with the gloves with Hec & again went down for an hour, trimming & firing. Had a hot bath when finished, & felt fit. We played cards in the evening -
Entry.37:
th
1917
We had "Neptune" sports in the afternoon as we crossed the line then, the canvas bath was fixed up & filled & several of the officers were caught & took their turn being lathered with flour paste, shaven with a large wooden razor & pushed of backwards into the bath,lance corporal Mason of "Furphy" -(a 
paper
 bulletin published daily & pinned up in a conspicuous place for the perusal & amusement of the troops) - fame also was immersed - I was one of Neptune's police - there was water flying everywhere,& there was plenty of good-natured fun - In the evening a concert was held in honor of Rob
t
 Burns aniversary -
Entry.38:
th
1917
A concert was held in the afternoon - a great naval victory is reported by wireless - Also the "Afric" is reported sunk off Sierra Leone,about 300 miles away from us - I slept below on account of rain -
Entry.39:
th
1917
Raining all the morning,we have our second daily issue of lime juice.
Entry.40:
th
1917
I was chased off deck by the rain at 3 am.Jack & Fred took on mess orderly duties for the week - The sea is like a lake in smoothness -
Entry.41:
th
 1917
We have been travelling at half speed for the past three days on account of submarines. We sighted land first thing^this morning&
got
went into "Freetown" Sierra Leone, which was crowded with all kinds of shipping, including cruisers also a French warship - we bought fruit & cocoanuts from the natives. Bananas 1/- per doz Paw-Paws 3deach Oranges 6dper doz & Cocoanuts 3deach. Nobody was allowed ashore as we had up the yellow flag for quarantine. Very warm day - We collected the fruit by letting down the money in a bucket on a rope & hauling the fruit upfrom the natives in their little canoes alongside. We each had to wait our turnfor the buckets.
Entry.42:
th
 1917
Lovely day again & no word of sailing,no hope of going ashore - we had no parades, spent the time lounging about watching the niggers & eating fruit - some of the boys dived off the deck into the water for a swim but were stopped on account of the number of sharks about -
Entry.43:
st
 1917
We hear that we are to sail on Friday. the weather is beautiful not too hot. & lots of fruit to eat. the paw-paws are beautiful - three sharks were seen cruising close to the boat - a party left the "Berimar" in a life boat & also we sent a party in a boat & they had a race -
Entry.45:
nd
 1917
I was put on main guard in the morning (24 hour guard). We sailed at 2.pm,Cornwall still with us. Whilst on my post at about 2 amI saw Ursa Major (the great bear or dipper),& also the Southern Cross at the same time.
Entry.46:
rd
 1917
The weather is getting cooler every day. My cobbers wouldn't believe that the S. Cross & the dipper could be seen together so I wakened them in the early morning & brought them on deck to convince them.
Entry.47:
th
 1917
Sunday - wind cold & sea choppy. We run at night now without even "port" or "starboard" lights & not even a cigarette is allowed to be smoked on deck after sunset & the submarine guard is always on the alert for periscopes -
Entry.48:
th
 1917
The wind is still blowing from the North & the sea is lumpy. We have to wear our lifebelts all the time on deck. I read "David Harman",it is a great yarn -I still sleep on deck -
Entry.49:
th
 1917
We changed direction North from 31
º
west. Wind still from the North - We had two parades & the boys all got their universal kit bags from the hold.
Entry.51:
1917
It gets a little colder every day most of the fellows are getting into breeches & boots again - we had two full parades - I read "Peg o'myheart" a very pretty tale.

Feb.8
Entry.52:
1917
We had one parade only on account of a mock trial for the "Furphy Times" in which L/c Mason is concerned - It gets dark now before 6.pm.

Feb.9
th
 1917
We had one parade only on account of a concert in the aftenoon. Sea smooth with a big swell - I have started sleeping below now for the rest of the trip as it is getting too cold on deck.I still have a cold shower every morning
Entry.53:
th
 1917
Tom & I start mess orderly duties together again for the last week on board. I read "The way of an Eagle" by Ethel Dell - for the second time
Entry.54:
th
 1917
Quite uncomfortably cold now. We played "House" (the onlypermitted gambling game in the British Army) in the evening at 3dper card, I lost 1/9 Crown & Anchor boards have been in evidence but always took a trip overboard when spotted by an officer& the owners & players crimed
Entry.55:
th
 1917
Cold wind all day & a shower of light rain. I read "The four feathers" A.E.W. Mason - find it long winded -
Entry.56:
th
 1917
Dull cold day with a little light rain. We are getting near to our destination,where the sun seldom shines. Reading, writing & playing cards all day -
Entry.57:
th
1917
All the ships took a zig-zag course during the day on account of submarines.The weather is dull & cold --we are supposed to be skirting the Bay of Biscay
Entry.58:
th
1917
The Cornwall signalls that if the destroyers are not at the rendez-vous the transports are to run independantly at full speed for Devonport -
Entry.59:
th
1917
We have parted company with all but the "Berimar" even Cornwall has left us. We picked up Destroyer No. 58 at noon & followed it. We saw four destroyers manovering & scouting, they are extremely fast. We had our first "iron rations" issued (Bully beef & biscuits - We are making fifteen knots & it is a fine day for a change - We passed wreckage & oil on the water, said to be the last signs of a submarine.
Entry.60:
th
1917
We ran into a heavy mist a little

off Devonport & cruised about slowly till orders came to pull in - We handed in our hammocks & blankets as we were expected to disembark but we had them re-issued & stayed the night on board -
Entry.61:
th
1917
We disembarked & took train to Tidworth Salisbury plains, (the very name put the wind up us) were served with a cup of tea & a bun, with best wishes from the Lady Mayoress of Exeter,at that station, & after about seven hours travelling arrived at Tidworth.We marched to No 4 Camp Parkhouse. about 3 miles with packs up, in the rain & mind,it was heavy going in our soft condition. We arrived there at 10 pmsaturated with perspiration, & were issued with five so-called blankets each. (& damp at that) & a cup of hot soup. We were then allotted to a big drafty hut, with a small heating stove in the centre, as an ornament (it was little use for anything else). We made our beds at about 12.30 & got into them & dozed & shivered till 7.30.am.
Entry.62:
th
1917
We got up at 7.30 am& had breakfast, well cooked but not too liberal. Attended first parade at 9.am& stood around all day being inoculated, issued with black boots, waterproof cape & wool gloves, very cold work.
Entry.63:
th
1917
Went on parade 9.30 am& were dismissed, put in the day writing letters home telling of my safe arrival & first impressions of Blighty (impressions not too rosy) it was not so cold; At the sound of an aeroplane overhead, we all made a rush for the door of the hut & looked up in wonder, it being the first time that most of us had seen a plane.
Entry.64:
st
1917
I was put on fatigue,cutting chaff as I didn't attend 9.30 amparade. In the evening, two cobbers & I walked over to Cholderton, a small village a couple of miles from camp,had a cup of tea & bread & cheese at the Crown inn & walked home again.
Entry.65:
nd
1917
After 9.30 parade we waited outside the pay office for pay,but were not paid till 4.30 pm. I was down at the stables again in the afternoon cutting chaff,left there in time for pay - In the evening my two cobbers & I went to the Garrison theatre at Tidworth & saw "Lucky Durham,it wasn't bad -
Entry.66:
rd
1917
We were all put on guards & fatigues.I was put on coal humping - It rained in the afternoon so, our job being done. we sat in the hut round the fire to warm

a part of our bodies, whilst the other parts were cold. I collected thirteen letters from the post office. Twelve of us were put on Shipton piquet & marched to Shipton (about a mile) in the evening & sat in the Y.M.C.A. writing letters.
Entry.67:
th
 1917
We saw the sun for the first time since we got near England - In the afternoon a couple of us walked to Tidworth but there was nothing to see -my birthday by the way -
Entry.68:
th
1917
Sunday. I wrote letters all day.
Entry.69:
th
1917
There was a frost last night, but it was sunny during this morning - We were enoculated again & had a medical examination,four of us walked over to Cholderton in the evening
Entry.71:
1917
We did nothing all day on account of being enoculated yesterday. I did a bit of washing, & wrote some letters,received a cable from Mother with birthday wishes - also a letter.
Entry.73:
1917
Went for short marches - nothing else doing. Some of the boys were warned for quarter guard to-night. I wrote several letters also received one - Rog obtained special leave for 3 days -
Entry.74:
st
 1917
After first parade we had nothing to do all day. I received three letters & wrote a couple - it rained all night -
Entry.75:
nd
1917
Nothing to do again to-day.I received two letters. I was on the Shipton piquet in the evening - it was very misty all day -
Entry.76:
rd
1917
We went on a route march in the morning all round Tidworth in charge of Monk - he was making things a bit hot & crimed Hec for falling out. I went on quarter guard at 5.pm. The Auxillary M.T. Unit arrived in camp at 11.pm,they went to No. 3 camp.
Entry.77:
th
1917
Came off guard at 5.pm. I went over & saw some of the fellows I knew in the unit just arrived - It snowed at night.
Entry.78:
th
1917
We had another route march in the morning - In the afternoon we had a short lecture on reviving a drowned man & also½ hour of drill under Monk. I had a hot bath after, & wrote letters.
Entry.79:
th
1917
Fine day with a high Easterly wind. Drilling all the morning under Monk. In the afternoon we watched a game of football (aust. rules).I was

put on isolation guard at 5.pm. It snowed during the night.
Entry.80:
th
1917
It froze after the snow & a stiff cold wind blew all day. I came off isolation guard at 5.pm& in the evening sat round the stove & talked.
Entry.82:
1917
A fine day but very cold. I was on fatigue in the morning & paidin the afternoon - a lance corp. & Rog & I went into Tidworth to fetch two prisoners back. We had tea in Tidworth & escorted said prisoners - Tom was pretty bad at night & I was up late looking after him. It snowed again at night.
Entry.84:
1917
Tom was a little better to-day,his temp. was 102º last night. We were all out toboganing in the afternoon on the hills round the camp, using corrugated iron panels for tobogans.I wrote letters in the evening -
Entry.85:
th
 1917
I caught a very severe cold.I was coughing a lot during the night. I was on all parades,we went for a walk out of sight of the camp & sat down
Entry.86:
th
1917
I went on sick parade & saw the doctor about my cold, as it had the wind up me,however he didn't do me much good. I went to bed at 6.30 pm.
Entry.87:
th
1917
I went sick again but the Quack doesn't seem to know too much. Monk took us out for a route march & gave us a bit of drill in the afternoon.I wrote a couple of letters & retired. 8.pm.
Entry.88:
th
1917
I was on all parades to-day, my cold being slightly better,they called for an escort of a corporal & three men, to take three men to Devises gaol, I was picked for one.
Entry.89:
th
1917
We left camp 11.15 amwith the three prisoners & had a good trip arriving Devises 3.30 pm,delivered the prisoners & hired a room for the night instead of returning straight to camp - the town was all in darkness at night. We spent the evening in a tavern -
Entry.90:
th
 1917
A beautiful spring day. We got back to camp at noon. In the afternoon Crow & I walked to "Greatley" about six miles away & had tea in a cottage there & returned home in the evening -
Entry.91:
th
1917
Another lovely day - I went on quarter guard at 5.pm.
Entry.92:
th
1917
Drizzling rain most ot the day just enough to make it miserable. We had a good guard. Hec was mess orderly.I wrote a few letters in the guard room came off guard at 5.pm.
Entry.93:
th
1917
Heavy snow storm & wind it cleared up at noon & Monk took us out in the afternoon for a route march round Tidworth. We counted him out & came home in our own time. Coming home we came across an aeroplane which had alighted. We tooka good look at it
Entry.94:
st
1917
I paraded to the adjutant & put in a general complaint against Monk. He said that he would look into the matter. We were drilling in the afternoon under Monk with an officer supervising (since the complaint). I had a wire from my sister who had arrived in London on special leave from her unit in Salonika, & put

in for disembarkation leave.
Entry.95:
nd
 1917
I was on cookhouse fatigue in the morning & we were paid in afternoon.Our leave is granted from next Monday. It snowed on & off all day - I went on quarter guard at 5.pm.
Entry.96:
rd
1917
We are put on draft again & all leave is cancelled. We expect to leave here tomorrow so I have written my sister to meet me at place of embarkation.Jack & I went to Pictures at Shipton in evening
Entry.98:
1917
Draft not to go till Tuesday next. Mar. 27
th
- had a reply from M- & wired back to ask if she would come to Tidworth to see me as I could'nt possibly get leave. I walked to Tidworth to find out about trains & a room.

Mar 25
th
1917
I met Marion & stayed all day with her. I was able to hire a room for her in Tidworth.
Entry.99:
th
 1917
I tried to get twenty four hours leave, but couldn't get it - M. came out to the camp & had dinner at Shipton & came again to camp in afternoon. I got permission to be off parade &

we went to Tidworth, had tea & stayed till 9.45 pm& I walked back to camp. it freezes hard every night now
Entry.100:
th
 1917
I had to be on both parades to-day & M- came out at 4.pmto meet me. We went to Tidworth to tea & I stayed the evening - said good-bye to her as she will leave for London again in the morning
Entry.101:
th
1917
Warned for France to-night,on parades all day & left camp 5.15 pm,left Tidworth 7.30 pm& went straight to Shornecliffe - We were issued with sheepskin coats our cloth ones being taken away from us.
Entry.102:
th
1917
Arrived Shornecliffe 3.30 am& marched to billets,some large empty houses on the sea front enclosed with fences & guarded. We lay down on the floor & slept till 7 am. I phoned to a friend in Canadian headq
trs
here & he came round & saw me. We were given leave from 2.30 pmtill 9.pm& walked all over the town,had a good tea & went to a picture show.
Entry.103:
th
1917
Got up 7.am,fell in 1.pm& marched to the Quai,got aboard channel

steamer & sailed at 3.pm,arrived at Boulogne after a spell of Mal-de-mer 5.pm& marched to rest camp on "one blanket hill" drew two blankets each & allottednine men to a bell tent,we were waiting about all evening to get our rations -
Entry.104:
st
 1917
Reveille 5.amtime one hour ahead of English time. We heard nothing of shifting till ten minutes before we were to move away - We marched to station & entrained for Rouen. left 7.15 pm.
Entry.105:
st
1917
Very slow train,had bully beef & biscuits to eat going down,had a drink of tea at Etaples,arrived Rouen 5.pm& marched to No.1 Base M.T. Depot,a Tommy M.T. base - we were allotted tents
in
at a camp in an orchard about 1 mile from the main camp.
Entry.106:
nd
1917
Reveille 5.am,first parade 6.50 ambreakfast 8 am. We had a steam bath in the morning & enjoyed it very much,dinner 12.30 till 1.45. We were on fatigue breaking up parts etc. supposed to be no good,but a lot of really good stuff was broken up, & there are even those who say positively that the officer in charge of the base (a Jew, by the way)

has some complete cars burried in a certain piece of ground, cached till after the war. I am sure that 1
st
M.T. base is responsible for a good share of the £8.000000per day of the war expenses. Tea 5:30 pmlate roll call 9.pmthen march back to our camp at the orchard
Entry.107:
rd
 1917
We were waiting for a medical inspection all the morning &then did'nt get it - we were put into isolation, (still in the orchard). We went into the square to drill all afternoon - we kicked up a schindy in the evening about the 9 pmroll call,
we had
havingto wait around so long when we wished to be in bed.
Entry.108:
th
1917
We worked up at the spare parts shop all day, doing nothing much - we went down to the orderlyroom for our pay I drew 20 francs - my first pay in France. In the evening I had a shave&hair cut (I don't appreciate the Froggie barbers) &a feed of eggs &chips with a bottle of beer at Gaby's joint with Jack.

April.5
Entry.109:
1917
We were at repair shop all day. I arranged to be paraded to the C.O. to-morrow about the 9.pmparade - We have had a whole day without rain. Jack was picked for piquet
Entry.110:
th
 1917
Worked in the morning at the repair shop again -Sergt. M. promised to see what he could do about the 9.p.m. parade, so we carried on as usual. In the afternoon I went on a lorry to town - it rained all the afternon and evening. Jack and I went into Gaby's for our eggs and chips and hotred wine with sugar (Vin rouge chaud)
Entry.111:
th
1917
Worked on unserviceable stores all day - Jack and I got leave from 5.30p.m till 9.15pm and went into Rouen and had a look around, had a good feed and wine.
Entry.112:
th
1917
Worked onuns-stores all morning. We were called out on draft for up the line but it was cancelled again - being Sunday, it was a half holiday so we dodged the M.P.'s & went into Rouen - fine day.
Entry.113:
th
1917
We worked down at the tyre stores all day on the wharf. We took a spell once in a while & went over to a cafe across the road - it snowed & rained all day on & off - we arrived back at the base at 4.30p.m.& they tried to drill us till 5.30 but we weren't having any. There was no 9.p.m. parade on account of a concert being held.
Entry.114:
th
 1917
We were down at the tyre stores hopping over to the café between^whilesfor hot wine, a very good drink in the cold weather - In the evening we cleaned up a bit & went into our café to see Gaby & drink hot wine till 9 pm.
Entry.115:
th
1917
I was warned for quarter guard & we went into the square to drill at 3.30 pmto pack kit for departure the following morning - We went to our café in the evening & said good-bye to Gaby -
Entry.116:
th
1917
Rose at 5 am,fine morning - we were sent up the line with a convoy of Albion lorries - convoy started at 7.am. We stopped for 1¼ hours at Neuchâtel at 10.15 amreached Amiens 4 pm,went straight through arrived at Albert 6.30 pmhad tea & looked round - saw the Cathedral tower with the leaning statue on top. We slept in the lorry we came up in,four of us & the two Tommy drivers. It rained and snowed at intervals through the day.
Entry.117:
th
1917
Reveille 6 am. We waited around all day in hopes of being sent for. We dubbined our boots & leggings & washed our feet. We

took a walk round the town which was very much battered & shell shocked one or two civies
were
had come back, it kept fine all day, we slept in lorry again
Entry.118:
th
 1917
We were sent to K supply column in charge of Colonel Moon. We were put through a test driving a lorry (Peerless) & 8 of us put in a bell tent, it was a lovely day -
Entry.119:
th
1917
Jack & I went to Bapaume in a lorry (as loaders) to get some stores from the railhead (it is just four weeks since Bapaume was captured by us) Fritz put eight 5.9 shells over to the railhead whilst we were there,my first time under fire. There was a load of tyres to go back to the park & three "clyno" motor bike's with sidecars,so Jack &I each rode a bike back to Albert. The roads were'nt too good & it was raining all day -
Entry.120:
th
1917
I & another man were tested on a Daimler staff car,a light car job going - he did best so he got the job. I had never driven a Daimler & he had,they are funny to drive if one does'nt know them,the engines are so quiet & deceptive.
Entry.121:
th
 1917
Esq
Ted& I were put on cookhouse fatigue in the morning - went to Bapaume at noon & got back at 4 pm& had tea together. The morning was fine but it rained the rest of the day.

April.18
Entry.122:
1917
Esq
Ted& I were on cooks fatigue again in the morning, after dinner we got a stove & put it in the tent, heated up some water & had a bath in a petrol tin - In the evening they sent four of our eight over to 1
st
Anzac Corps troops.
Entry.123:
th
1917
Raw
Alf& I were on cooks fatigue in the morning. We shifted the cook house on account of a fire they had there - We were sent over to 1
st
Anzac C.T. supply column in the afternoon it was raining most of theday but cleared up in the evening -
Entry.124:
th
1917
I went down to Railhead on a lorry in themorning & in the afternoon was put on an old "Dennis" 30 cwt lorry with
Raw
Alf& sent down to K column workshop to work on it. I was paid 40 francs. I did a bit of washing in afternoon,it kept fine all day -
Entry.125:
st
1917
We didn't do too much work,

on the lorry, just kept out of sight - we sleep & eat on the lorry. We went to a little stream they have the audacity to call the river Ancre & had a bathe,it was a fine warm day -
Entry.126:
nd
1917
We worked all the morning cleaning the lorry & had the aftenoon off (Sunday). We went souvenir hunting.

April.23
rd
1917
We worked on the lorry all day cleaning etc - it was a beautiful warm day with clear blue sky - a Fritz Aeroplane came over at high altitude & we watched them shooting at it,being the first one I had seen - In the evening we walked to Aveluy & saw the battered state of the church -
Entry.127:
th
1917
We put in the time around the lorry. We have done all the work there is to do & just waiting for a part^intake manifold- In the evening we walked to Pozieres (battle field of
Entry.128: it was a wonderful sight for the uninitiated,all the trench works, & on Fritze's line the deep dug-outs - in many places the dead were not thoroughly buried & a limb would stick out - we saw the huge mine craters at La Boiselle.
Entry.129:
th
 1917
Anzac day. We put in the day in the lorry, I received a bunch of letters in the evening, the first since arrival in France. We were put on guard in the evening - the weather was dull but no rain.
Entry.130:
th
1917
We had practically no sleep last night - we worked at K. col. work shop all day & in the evening went to the Church room in Albert & wrote letters, the morning was dull but the sun shon in the afternoon.
Entry.131:
th
1917
We heard a big bombardement in the early morning,it sounded terrific as it was the first I had heard - it was in front of Bullicourt. In the evening - after working all day in the shops - we went again to Pozieres riding in a lorry both ways - the day was cloudy but no rain.
Entry.132:
th
1917
Still waiting for lorry part - I had some letters also wrote some. It was a lovely day -
Entry.133:
th
1917
At the workshop in the morning it being Sunday we had the afternoon free - we had a bath & went for a walk.
Entry.135:
1917
Stayed with the lorry all day had a bit of a sleep in the afternoon

received more letters & wrote some, beautiful warm day -
Entry.136:
st
 1917
Stayed at the lorry all day,received some more letters - a Fritz aeroplane came over & was duly shelled by our Anti-Aircraft guns,some of the shrapnel dropping at our feet - beautiful day
Entry.137:
nd
1917
Stayed around all day. taking little walks in different directions souvenir hunting - received more letters.
Entry.138:
rd
1917
We got up at 5.30 am& wentfor a walk before breakfast - the part arrived for the lorry & we put it on - we made some nettle tea in the evening & drank same it is supposed to be good for the blood - beautiful day -
Entry.139:
th
1917
Reveille 5.30 am. We drove the lorry out of the workshop at noon & took it back to the column. In the afternoon we made a couple of trips for rations. We were paid in the evening - I drew 40 francs & two green envelopes -
Entry.140:
th
1917
We were taken off the "Dennis" lorry & put on a three ton Daimler No 2-2.I was driving all the afternoon & evening getting back to the column at 9 pm.
Entry.141:
th
 1917
Went to Bapaume with the lorry,were out all day returning to park at 7.30 pmto find that I was on guard - lovely day -
Entry.142:
th
1917
Coal stunt on to-day, we hauled coal from railhead at Albert to the gas works & also to Belview - infantry men out on a spell shovelled the coal - When we got back to the park we cleaned out the lorry to make it fit to sleep in,we sleep on the floor, having a rack for our blankets etc in the day time & lockers etc to carry tucker & utensils - lovely warm day—
Entry.143:
th
1917
I went to railhead in the morning for a load of hay & took it to the dump - It rained all last night & all the morning,clearing up in the afternoon - We all went to the pictures at Albert in the evening -
Entry.144:
th
1917
I went to railhead in the morning for a load of petrol for the column - I was supposed to go to Bapaume in the afternoon with canteen supplies. but the battalion representatives failed to turn up at the wholesale canteen - Jack & Blue - came to join this column - lovely day—
Entry.145:
th
1917
In the morning I went for a load of hay at the railhead, & to Avuloy railhead

for a load of chloride of lime - In the afternoon we went to Pozieres stonedump & hauled road metal for the Bapaume Road at Le Sars - I picked up an old french Cavalry sword & kept it for a souvenir,it was a beautiful piece of steel - lovely day -
Entry.146:
th
 1917
We went to the Pozieres stone dump & hauled stone all day for the Bapaume R
d
made some tea (on the primus, which we carry) & heated up a tin of
Machon
Maconochies. We got back to Park at 4.30 pm& had a bathe in the Ancre before tea - it dose'nt get dark now till 9.15 pm& we rise at 5.30 am.

May 12
th
1917
We took a load of hay to 6
th
Brigade Artillery at Fréchencourt in the morning & went to Becourt in the afternoon,received some letters & a parcel from home. On May 5
th
five lorries were transferred with their drivers to 6
th
Bgd.. Artillery which was taken out of 2
nd
division & made mobile. Also five lorries with their drivers were transferred to 12
th
Bgd. which was taken out of the 4
th
divy. We were still kept with the column but subject to move with our respective brigades
the Brigade was called
the lorries were attached to the6
Entry.147: A.F.A. B.A.C. (Australian.Field.Artillery. Brigade.ammunition.column) & we were called the Afabacs from then on.
Entry.148:
th
Sunday 1817
We went to the railhead to clear some coal -which necessitated cleaning the lorry out when we got home. I wrote some letters in the evening - lovely day -
Entry.149:
th
1917
Went to railhead in the morning for a load of supplies for the dump at Belview.In the afternoon we went to Vaulx with a load of canteen supplies - Vaulx is 3 miles N.E. of Bapaume & about 3 miles from front line, the weather was fair but cool.
Entry.150:
th
1917
Went to Fréchencourt in the morning with load of hay came back through Heilly. In the afternoon we went to Bapaume starting from Albert at 4.30 pm. We returned to Park at 8 pm- lovely day with one or two showers -
Entry.151:
th
1917
Went to Fréchencourt in the morning withhay - In the afternoon we cleaned our lorries for an inspection - received some letters . - General rain set in late in the afternoon -
Entry.152:
th
1917
Went to Fréchencourt in the morning with hay & had three short trips in the afternoon - I wrote some letters in the evening & sent a piece of hand painted silk work away - Raining all day—
Entry.153:
th
 1917
ne trip from railhead to the dump, the rest of the day we spent cleaning the lorry - We were paid - I drew 40 francs & two green envelopes - fine day -
Entry.154:
th
1917
Railhead to dump in the morning & went to Bapaume in the afternoon. I was on guard from 11 pmtill 2.20 am. We are going north on Monday - fine day -
Entry.155:
th
1917
Sunday.Coal stunt again. I had a touch of influenza -
Entry.156:
st
1917
We loaded up with hay at the railhead & returned to Park - We joined twelve lorries of our brigade (6
th
B
gd
Amunition Section) & started North at Noon in charge of an officer & S.M. We travelled at a good pace. My engine heated badly & I advanced the ignition, which necessitated taking off the magneto as it was fixed ignition & after that she ran well & did'nt heat- Hec. came on with me as second driver. We went through S
t
Pol & Lillers,parking about 11 pmjust outside
Haze
Hazebrouck on the Pavé about 15 kilometres from our destination - I still feel sick & sore -
Entry.157:
nd
1917
Got up 6 am& started up 6.30 am. We had slept on our load of hay & cooked

our breakfast there also - We got to Bailleul & after waiting in the small square (Place Plichon) for some time. Went along the rue de Moulins to the 2
nd
Anzac Corps troops Supply column, where we were to be attached,it was a Tommy outfit with workshop & when we lit a primus to cook our dinner on the load of hay the O.C. happened along & he did go off a packet - We dumped our hay - We went down town & had eggs & chips for tea also some wine at an estaminet - Am still stiff & have headache - The amunition section went on their own -
Entry.158:
rd
1917
Reveille 4 ambreakfast 4.30 on the road at 5 am. Went to Steenwerck railhead for a load of hay for the dump - when we got back we cleaned the lorry & had it inspected. Feeling very dicky all day like when I had Dengue fever in Rockhampton - I had a warm bath up town in the evening .in Madame's bedroom in a half barrel for 1 franc.
Entry.159:
th
1917
Reveille 4 am.We went to Steenwerck railhead at 5 am& took a load to the dump got back to park & greased & cleaned the lorry Hec. was'nt well so he slept till noon, I felt much better in the morning but was very bad again at night.
Entry.160:
th
1917
Reveille 4 am.Went to Steenwerck railhead & dump - returned to park & slept till noon - lovely day - I felt pretty bad in the morning,much better in the evening but very tired & I stayed in & went to bed early - The guns are just starting a bombardment.
Entry.161:
th
1917
Steenwerck railhead again as usual when we returned to Park we were sent out on a coal stunt , we had to load & unload our own lorry - lovely day - I have felt good all day -
Entry.162:
th
1917
Reveille 4 amas usual - we went to Romarin gravel pit,right by a Tommy battery of 60 pounder guns & close to an 11 inch howitzer on rails all of which were in action firing from time to time - We hauled gravel to Hyde Park corner.We had to wear our tin lids as shrapnel was coming over very close to us. We watched a Fritz aeroplane come over us & set fire to an observation baloon very near us & come back, he appeared to be rather interested in us (he was very low) so we got under the lorry till he
was
hadpassed over (We were waiting to unload at the time by some old field gun pits)
Entry.163:
th
 1917
We had to take a rear wheel of to get it retyred, the others went out to Romarin again. When they returned they said Fritz had been shelling heavily - I worked on the lorry all day greasing etc
Entry.164:
th
1917
During last night shells were falling on the outskirts of Bailleul not vey far from the work shops - we listened to them whistling & exploding,in the morning our guns started a heavy bombardment.We are still held up for a wheel - dull day -
Entry.165:
th
1917
We fixed a foot brake that had been dragging & we got the wheel back & put it on - We were sent into the workshop for an engine overhaul
Entry.166:
st
1917
Fritz was shelling the Bailleul
statton
station during the night & also searching in our direction & fairly close to us, they came over our heads. Many of the Tommies hopped out of their lorries to find better shelter than a tarpaulin.We are getting quite used to shell fire.We dismantled the engine by ourselves & took the engine out. In the evening we watched a Fritz aeroplane come over & set fire to two baloons just at dusk & go away with our machines firing at him & chasing -
Entry.167:
st
 1917
Fritz sent over a couple of duds in the morning, one landed just outside the workshop, about ten yards from us.It put the wind up the mechanic who was working on our crankshaft, so that he could hardly do any work all day & every shell that came over he would run out to see where it lobbed.I wrote letters in the evening - lovely day -(
Entry.168:
nd
1917
We worked on the lorry all day.I went up town after tea & got a book from the church library -
Entry.169:
rd
1917
I did'nt feel too good all day being Sunday, it is half holiday so I lay down in the afternoon & rested.
Entry.170:
th
1917
Hec paraded sick in the morning - I felt very bad all day, bad head, sick stomach & general debility - so we did very little work - we saw a lot of our own tri-planes manouvering all day. Fritz was shelling round us again to-day
Entry.171:
th
1917
A Fritz plane dropped a bomb on the Connaught dump (on the Ravelsburg road) about 
a
1mile from us & it was exploding all day long - I felt much

better to-day but weak - Fritz lobbed a few shells fairly close to us in afternoon & our guns opened up & gave what for all night -
Entry.172:
th
1917
Our guns are giving Fritz Hell to-day, he lobbed three shells near the park in the afternoon but did no damage though there were some horses very near Jack & I went up town after tea & got some books from the library - lovely day but thunder in the air -
Entry.173:
th
1917
We were wakened up at 3.10 amby a tremendous explosion (two huge mines at Messines Ridge were fired) & our guns started a heavy barrage - The troops hopped over & took
from 3 Kil
six kilometres & a lot of prisoners - The New Zealanders hopped over first followed by Australian & Irish troops - I went down to the Casualty clearing station in the evening & helped carry the wounded in. They were coming in very fast,being attended to & put back in the Ambulances & taken to other hospitals. There was a very heavy rain storm & I was soaked to the skin -
Entry.174:
th
1917
I felt very sick again to-day

I ca'nt throw off this fever, I did'nt get up in the morning, but I got up & worked in the afternoon,our guns are still bombarding intermittently but Fritz is still drobbing shells all round us doing a bit of damage to houses etc. He got a house in Rue de Moulin just down from us,one woman was wounded -
Entry.175:
th
1917
I felt better to-day - I saw an account in the paper of last Thursday's work at Messines - I wrote some letters - Our guns are going strong -
Entry.176:
th
1917
Sunday.We walked to Steenwerck to the 3
rd
A.D.S.C to see if any of our mail was being sent there as we had left Australia as reinforcements for that unit, however there was none & we returned to park.
Entry.177:
th
1917
We put the engine back into the frame & will soon be outon the road again (our other lorries are now parked down in Place Plichon) No Fritz planes come over our way now, we are keeping him amused in other directions,& he is too busy to worry us -
Entry.178:
th
 1917
We couldn't turn the crankshaft so we had to take off the base & loosen the main bearings a little,we had trouble all day - The mechanic is good but ca'nt concentrate on his work if Fritz does any shelling - There was a heavy rain storm in the afternoon - We had a feed of onions & French bread & butter for tea it was very acceptable. Letters from home
Entry.179:
th
1917
We got the engine nearly assembled after a good days work,the Daimler engine takes much more overhaulling than a poppet valve engine I am feeling good now -
Entry.180:
th
1917
We got the engine fully assembled & are waiting for a clutch part - we went down town after tea & had a look at all the captured german guns & trench mortars in the square - nearly all of them were captured by the N-Zealanders & Australians -
Entry.181:
th
1917
The lorry was towed to start the engine,there was a knock from oil pump shaft so we took off the crank case base & fixed it. We took lorry out in the afternoon for a test run,we went to Caestre & back, she was O.K.

but not as much power as when she went in. Dickie turned up from 3
rd
O.S C transferred to 12 Affas - Jack's lorry was evacuated & he has a Thornicroft in its place. I took our lorry down to Place Plichon with our other lorries,ready for duty,& glad of it -
Entry.182:
th
1917
Did a bit of camouflaging (rubbed the body of lorry down with oil) otherwise had nothing to do all day - We went to a lecture in the evening -
Entry.183:
th
1917
Sunday.We went to the railhead in the morning for supplies - In the afternoon I gave a bit of a tea party,invited six of the other boys into the lorry & we had eggs & french bread (new) & butter (they are not supposed to sell bread to the troops, but I can sometimes get it) & we had a good time, it cost me 8 francs
Entry.184:
th
1917
We went to Bailleul railhead & De Brocken road dump in the morning & Coal stunt in the afternoon. Fritz started shelling Steenwerck - It rained quite a bit in the afternoon but the weather is very warm. I started wearing shorts—
Entry.185:
th
 1917
Went to Bailleul railhead & De Brockendump - there were heavy showers at intervals through the day - The Brigade are drawing their supplies at De Brocken dump.Fritz planes are coming over regularly again now - We were on a coal stunt in the afternoon - In the evening I saw a quadraplane manouvering over the R.N.A.S. Aerodrome - I never saw another but heard that they hav been tested & found wanting.
Entry.186:
th
1917
We did'nt go out at all to-day - We handed in our paybooks & we draw pay to-morrow - Fritz lobbed two shells over here first thing this morning. they landed just down the road behind the 4thdivy ordnance lorries. no damage done. We had showers at intervals -
Entry.187:
st
1917
We were called out at midnight last night to shift camp & equipment of 42
nd
(Q'land) Battallion from behind Steenwerck (Between Steenwerck & Bailleul) to Neuve Eglise - We took three seperate big loads & had breakfast with the Bat. We got back to the park at noon to-day. I drew 50 francs.We slept all the afternoon - I was supposed to be on guard last night but I missed on account of going out.It rained a little in the afternoon.
Entry.188:
nd
 1917
Have done nothing at all to-day.It has been raining nearly all day - we had tea in café (Maria Louise's joint) I bought a set of Hugo's french lessons 3 francs 25 centimes - I received a letter from M-and answered it
Entry.189:
rd
1917
Brought E.F.C stores from Bailleul railhead to the canteen,we got a few back sheesh articles out of it & they gave us a good dinner.
Entry.190:
th
1917
Sunday.We left park at 7.15 am& went to Hyde Park corner & picked up anti aircraft (13 pounders)salvage amunition & took it to a dump near Pont de Nieppe,Fritz skittled another baloon - fine day -
Entry.191:
th
1917
Fritz dropped bombs in Bailleul & also sent over a few shells last night - We went to Ravelsburg in the morning & took a load to Croix du Bac - got back to park for dinner - We cleaned up the lorry a bit in the afternoon. In the evening I wrote letters.
Entry.192:
th
1917
We went to Romarin stone dump & hauled road metal to Ravelsburg, Hec was driving & went in the ditch it was unavoidable, however we soon

got out of it with the aid of another lorry - There was nothing exciting up at Romarin to-day - I wrote letters in the evening -
Entry.193:
th
1917
We went to Hyde Park corner gravel pit & took three loads of gravel to Ravelsburg,got home at 4 pm. It was fine all day but rained a little in the evening - Hay is on the ground now & the Barley is almost ready to cut.
Entry.194:
th
1917
Fritz came over & dropped three bombs early this morning, which I think did no harm
but he lobbed a shell right into the & knocked it rotten
We went to Romarin & drew three loads of stone to Ravelsburg,it
wo
rained in the morning & again in the evening but wase fine during the afternoon.
Entry.195:
th
1917
We went to Romarin & drew three loads of stone to Ravelsburg. I received some letters forwarded from the base.I wrote letters in the evening
Entry.197:
1917
We took a load of Tommy engineers to a flying school ten miles out,we saw the rotary engines at close quarters - The engineers went to ashphalt a road

in front of the flying grounds to prevent dust,but it was raining all day so they could'nt do much,we returned with them & then had to go for a load of stone
Entry.198:
st
1917
We went to Romarin & took two loads of stone to Clapham road. Pay day. I drew 50 francs. - Sunday -
Entry.199:
nd
1917
Went to Romarin & drew four loads of stone to Neuve Eglise - Fritz planes came over in force after our baloons, but were chased of by our machines - - To-day is the first really fine day we have had for a week - I wrote letters in the evening -
Entry.200:
rd
1917
Fritz came over twice during the night & dropped 4 bombs each time knocked an estaminet near us rotten & killed a few civies, the shrapnel from our antis was falling all about us. We went to Romarin & drew three loads of stone to Ravelsburg - had a bath when we got home - beautiful day - We saw a Fritzplane brought down in an air fight,he landed right by the R.F.C. aerodrome.
Entry.201:
th
 1917
Went to Romarin & hauled four loads of stone to a mile & a half the other side of Neuve Eglise (Orchard road)

King George passed through Neuve Eglise at noon - This is one of the times he is said to have visited the front & is referred to in the papers as a tribute to his courage -
Entry.202:
th
1917
We hauled three loads of stone from Romarin to Orchard road, shrapnel was bursting over us in the morning.Dull & cold all day but no rain -
Entry.203:
th
1917
We carried a fatigue party to Hell-fire-corner & returned to Petit Pont & fetched a load of gravel to Hell-Fire-Corner. Fritz was shelling some heavy batteries on our left with some heavy stuff & a big piece of H.E lobbed at our feet it just missed the sergt in charge of the fatigue party & he would'nt stay any longer we had to pick up the party & go back home - he had the wind up properly. During the noon hour Hec & I took a walk up towards Messines ridge & watched Fritz shelling batteries in the valley on right of Messines - it was when we got back to the lorry that he turned his attention to the battery close to us.
Entry.204:
th
 1917
Last night Fritz came over with forteen planes & dropped eighty bombs,causing 170 casualties in Bailleul. He got one casualty clearing station,killing two or three nurses,I am not sure which. I was on guard from 2.20 amtill 5.30 amduring which time he was over, the civies all came running down to a big cellar under one of the main buildings in the Place Plichon also a lot of Tommies & some of ours ran for cover under an archway into the courtyard, where the empty petrol tins were stacked, some person pushed the stack over & did'nt the crowd scatter they thought it was a bomb, also some one threw a rock (a piece of pavé) into a lorry where there was a driver sleeping (or trying to) & nearly scared him to death - There was one machine gun firing at the planes from the top of the building in which was Margurite's ( the girl with the beautiful hair) estaminet - We went up to Romarin for stone again in the morning -
Entry.205:
th
1917
We went out to Armentieres with a French civy working party - During the day orders came through that all Military vehicles - lorries. ambulances etc were to go out of Bailleul at night time

& also the civies were warned to get out - That night there was a general exodus the civies took their most valuable portable possessions with them & marched out at about 8 pm. We had to go out to Atterstene about five kilometres along the road toward Strazeele & we picked up a load of women & children & took them to their destinations - Fritz did'nt bother Bailleul much that night. -
Entry.206:
th
1917
We hit the road at 7 amfor Bailleul picking up a load of civies on the way - We went to Bailleul railhead at 10.30 am& returned finished at 1.30 pm,greased the buss & filled the gear box with oil,& at night again went out to Atterstene to park for the night -
Entry.207:
th
1917
Our five lorries (6
th
Bg
d
) went to Steenwerck railhead & loaded up two with hay two with oats & one with rations & reported to the B.A.C waggon lines in the afternoon near De Brocken road & were sent on to a prearranged spot at Hazebrouck & were followed by the Brigade. We discharged our loads at the new waggon lines, had our suppers & went to bed
Entry.208:
th
 1917
Went back to Steenwerck railhead for the Brigade daily supplies & back through Haazebrouck to five miles past Cassel
follow
(where the Brigade had stopped for the night) where we arrived at 1 am& unloaded. We got stuck on a railroad crossing on the way, but got out without much trouble - lovely day -
Entry.209:
th
1917
We lay-in, in the morning & at noon went back to Caestre for supplies & got back to the waggon lines at 6 pm. We started again at 9.30 pmfor a new camp went through Wormhoudt & Hondschoot to Ghyvelde where parked & waited for the Brigade as we did'nt know just where they would camp. They arrived about 6.30 am& made their waggon lines
on a
in the paddocks by a road leading out of ghyvelde & we dumped the supplies for them -
Entry.210:
th
1917
We went back to Arneke railhead for supplies. I took a wrong road & whilst backing to turn round I backed a little too far & the road gave way & I went into the ditch - we had to unload the lorry & we got a passing Thornicroft to pull us out & we loaded up again

& got back to the waggon lines at 7.30 pm,had tea & unloaded - lovely day -
Entry.211:
th
1917
We went into Dunkerque railhead for supplies but there were none there for us so we had to go to an emergency dump on the wharves - We had a good look at the town whilst we were there - the kasino was almost demolished by one 12 inch shell when it was being used as a hospital. The Kasino is at Maloles Bains, a suburb of Dunkerque,we also had a look down the Rue de la Marine, Dank. Rainy day -
Entry.212:
th
1917
Into Dunkerque again for supplies.I stayed with the lorry whilst Hec went exploring the town some more - we got home 7 pm.
Entry.213:
th
1917
Dunkerque again (we rather like the townit is a pretty big place & a seaport) Hec stayed with the lorry whilst I went into the town. I visited the coiffeur & had a hair cut - Early this morning three Fritz planes came over Dunkerque & dropped bombs - two of the planes were brought down - Fritz has a long range gun at Dixmude with which he shells Dunkerque sometimes so in the town they have a listening post scientificly worked &

they hear the gun fired in time to warn the population of the shells approach & also into what quarter of the town it will lob, by clanging a bell in that quarter. (this is'nt a yarn) - We got back home at 7.30 pm. I wrote letters in the evening - fine day -
Entry.214:
th
1917
We went to S
t
Idasbald railhead at 2.30 pmbut couldnt get any fodder, so had to go back to Dunkerque emergency dump - it was a very dark night & I had no headlights & it was raining all night but the road was good. I arrived at home at 1 am.
Entry.215:
th
1917
We slept till 10 am& went up to S
t
Idasbald again at 2.30 pm. We drew our supplies & got home at 8.30 pm,it rained lightly all day—
Entry.216:
th
1917
We went to S
t
Idasbald railhead to draw & waited all the afternoon & finally had to go back to Dunkerque. We got back home at midnight. - Weather fair.
Entry.217:
th
1917
We went to S
t
Idasbald & drew our supplies we saw a R.N.A.S. plane
cum
come a gutzer & get stuck in the canal,we watched them get it out again.

We got back home at 7.30 pm. I received some letters -
Entry.218:
st
1917
We drew at S
t
Idasbald & got home at 4.30 pm. We were paid. Hec went into Dunkerque & stayed the night
Entry.219:
nd
1917
We drew at S
t
Idasbald & got home at 3.30 pm. Fritz blew up a dump of 30,000 gals of petrol & we could see it burning - Hec. did'nt get back from Dun. We parked in an orchard & picked the green apples & stewed them, they were no good raw, but very good stewed -
Entry.220:
rd
1917
A lovely day after the morning mists cleared - Hec still away & I carry on by myself - Went to S
t
Idasbald to draw supplies & got through at 4 pm& altered the jets of my carburetter (solex) I went into tea with Roy & Dickie in their lorry - the mosquitos were very bad all night -
Entry.221:
th
1917
Hec came back at 8.30 amin time to come to S
t
Idasbald. Fritz dropped a lot of bombs in the early morning but none near us - We drew supplies & got through at 5 pm,had a lovely tea including Saratoga chips & stewed apples

& custard (we prepared all our own meals on a primus). We moved to 66
th
Division M.T. column (the old clickerty click) a Tommy division we had to park with themour five lorries & 12
th
Brigade five lorries & 3
rd
Brigade five lorries - we parked to-gether -
Entry.222:
th
 1917
We went to S
t
Idasbald railhead for Brigade supplies as usual, Syd's & Burney's lorries were kept in for inspection & Tommy lorries sent in their place,we got back to park at 7.30 pm.
Entry.223:
th
1917
My lorry was kept in for inspection.I slept in till 10.30 am.We had a good dinner. Hec & I went along the canal & had a good wash after which we got into a patch of peas & picked enough to make a big feed,we went back to the lorry cooked the peas & fried some chips & had a great tea. I wrote a french letter for one of the boys to Marcelle,his girl in Dunkerque.
Entry.224:
th
1917
We went to the railhead for supplies, put in our time waiting at the railhead in a little estaminet - I bought a bottle of beautiful Malaga for 5 francs & took home with me - lovely weather -
Entry.225:
th
 1917
Went to S
t
Idasbald railhead as usual for supplies,on the way back towards La Panne I picked up three Canadian sisters from No. 1. C.C.C.S. & gave them a lift.One of them happened to know my sister, & asked me to come along & see her some time.
Entry.226:
th
1917
I called at the C.C.S as we passed on the way to railhead & saw the before mentioned sister,she happened to be on duty at the time so I did'nt keep her,she asked me to come along to tea sometime. It was raining all day. When we passed Bray Doons on the way home - Hec. hopped off & made for Dunkerque for the night -
Entry.227:
th
1917
I carried on singlehanded as Hec did'nt get back yet - I received some letters & wrote some. I washed my tunic in Petrol & made a good job of it,also sewed color patches on - fine day -
Entry.228:
st
1917
Went to Railhead, whilst we were there Fritz put over a few gas shells into Furnes - We got back to park at 6 pm. We dont have to go on any parades & we dont allow them to interfere with us much,so the 66
th
div. column will do us - The three Brigades of Artillery with their

transport columns & the Tunnelers were the only Australian troops up this way they are expecting a big stunt up here to be worked in conjunction with a stunt at Ypres,in which the fleet also would take part with their long range guns,the idea being to cut off the piece of country from Ypres to Ostend & command the higher country for next winter -
Entry.229:
st
1917
Went to railhead as usual. When I got home I met Hec,just back from Dunkerque where he had been for three days,he was on his way back on Monday night & was nabbed by the military police & jugged,the brigade sent in two men leading a spare horse to escort him home - Raining all day -
Entry.230:
nd
1917
Went to railhead & drew fodder delivered it & went home. And were sent back to the railhead on a coal stunt, but managed to get there just as it was finished & made the best of our way home. We overtaken by night & it had been raining all day so we parked for the night about three miles from home to prevent going over, what was next to an impassable road in daylight, at night lorries were bogged all along it -

This bad road was three parts of a square {
all
^two out of threeterribly bad) which we were forced to go round instead of travelling direct to our destination by the fourth side which was a main road & in splendid condition it was specified as a one way road against us & the reason was that there was a lorry park along it (but there was heaps of room for trafic) "C'est la militaire" there was also a lorry park on the bad road which made it much worse.
Entry.231:
rd
1917
When the other lorries came along we joined them & went along to railhead,now we have to draw full loads of fodder & take it to a dump at Coxyde,we then draw our issue & deliver to the Brigade waggon lines - It rained all day again. -

Aug.4
Entry.232:
1917
We drew at the railhead & came home via Coxyde dump (via Coxyde les bains) Hec went into Dunkerque again for the night - Our lorries parked in the road from the brigade to the 66
th
column - on our own - the five lorries from each of the three brigades were together (the amunition sections were parked at Lamours)

Aug.5
th
 1917
Entry.233: Railhead & Coxyde dump as usual - fine day for a change.
Entry.234:
th
1917
Misty all day but no rain. We went to railhead & Coxyde dump for supplies as usual - We are having very good tucker,cooking it all ourselves, it is greatly helped out with the stewed apples & custard which we have daily for our main meal which is tea when we are done work for the day - I eat these days whilst Hec is away with Jack & sometimes with Dickie. I dont like cooking & eating by myself.
Entry.235:
th
1917
Railhead & dump as usual,we had a bit of a shindy with the supply officer at S
t
Idasbald (Gertie we call him) because he spoke to us as he speaks to his own men as though they were dogs. I did a bit of washing when we got home. Hec has arrived home from Dunkerque. I roused on him for being away so long.
Entry.236:
th
1917
General assizes - Hec brought seven days pay for being nabbed in Dunkerque.Our case in which Fipwas principle party was remanded for a day - We greased up generally - We played halfpenny nap in the evening at which I lost four francs.
Entry.237:
th
Kept in again for orderly room, case again put off. The O.C knows that the

trouble was caused by his own officer so he can't with justice punish us & as in the Tommy Army an officer is never in the wrong he was undecided between justice & military methods - Three Fritz planes came over in the morning observing - It rained in the afternoon
Entry.238:
th
1917
Still kept in because of this case which is put off indefinitely (until called for) we cleaned the buss up thoroughly,underneath and all. It was showery all day - played½dnap in the evening & won 15 francs -
Entry.239:
th
1917
We got up early as we thought that we were to go to railhead, but we did'nt go out, we took it easy all day - Hec made a suet pudding for tea & it was très bonne
Entry.240:
th
1917
We lay a'bed till noon & read. In the afternoon we walked along to see the 49
th
division sports the other side of La Mour Hec went into Dunkerque in the afternoon.
Entry.241:
th
1917
We had a quiet day,nothing to do. The weather continues showery - Hec came back from Dunkerque this morning
Entry.242:
th
1917
Hec went out in the morning with the 30 cwt lorry but got back at 1 pm&

he, Burney & I got passes for Malo les Bains & went into Dunkerque in the tram (Malo is open to troops but Dunkeerque is
closed
out of bounds) I bought a vest pocket Kodakfor 55 francs - We had our photos taken. Hec & I together on postcards - we went along to see Hec's girl Marcelle & her cobbers - we got back as far as Bray Doons in a RNA.S. lorry & walked the rest. home -
Entry.243:
th
1917
We got up at 6.15 am& went to Railhead ViaCoxyde & back to dump Via Coxyde les bains, where the tunnelers were camped, there are several big guns parked on the la Panne Coxyde road - we got home at 6 pm.Weather was showery - we went to bed at 9.30 pmafter a snack

We were told that our case had been dropped
Entry.244:
th
1917
We did our usual run for suppliesgot finished at 3 pm& front tyres crook. We got up a scratch team amongst us & played the 66 DSC Rugby & got beaten badly. Frank was our best player.
Entry.245:
th
 1917
We stayed in to get our front wheels retyred. We did'nt get up till 9.30 am& had a very easy day. Fritz is shelling the railhead pretty frequently now. I have'nt yet been there during
the
a strafe.
Entry.246:
th
 1917
We cleaned the buss in the morning & read & played cards in the afternoon - In the evening we went up & watched a socker match between the Belgian flying corps & the 66 D.S.C. at the Aerodrome about two milesaway - there were international professional players on both sides & it was very pretty to watch the Tommies won the game, but I reckon the Belgians played the best game - at night the sky was gloriously lit up with search-lights (our own & Fritzes) from all round us, there was one searchlight base with two lights each served by a Tillling Stevens lorry about one mile from us.
Entry.247:
th
1917
We had nothing at all to do to-day,it was a beautiful day (Sunday) Hec went into Dunkerque for the night -
Entry.248:
th
1917
Beautiful day. I went into Dunkerque to the tyre press & took Paddy with me to give me a hand,the tyres did'nt take long & we spent the rest of the day in town - I had a haircut. We met Hec. & he came back with us at 8 pm.
Entry.249:
st
1917
The top of my
raid
radiator was cracked & leaked badly so I got a new top & put it on without going into workshop much against the workshop oficer's wishes

as he wanted to get me me into the workshop for an overhaul & I did'nt want one - we had a good practice game of Rugger seven per side in the evening - lovely day -
Entry.250:
nd
1917
We went on the road to-day,started out at 5.30 amfor S
t
Idasbald drew supplies & got finished by 11 am. We walked to the Canal for a swim in the afternoon, but it was stirred up too much so we had a good wash in a small canal on our way back. Our 47
th
Battery Rugby team played the 66
th
D.S.C in the evening & beat them easily after a very good game. Frank played for 66
th
- beautiful day - Fritz came over at 10 pm& dropped his tailboard near here, all the searchlights and antis were in action. During the raid Hec & I donned tin lids & walked about½ a mile down the road where we had grave suspicions of spies at work in an apparently deserted house & we thought this a good time to watch (We were after the leave & money attached to catching a spy) but we lay in the ditch at the side of the road watching but saw nothing, but I have always had doubts about that house.
Entry.251:
rd
1917
We left Park at 5.30 amfor railhead did our job & got home at 11 am.
Entry.252:
th
 1917
Windy & showery all day -

We left Park for the railhead at 5.30 amfinishing at 11 am.We had a sleep in the afternoon & I wrote letters in evening
Entry.253:
th
1917
We left Park for railhead at 5.30 amfinishing at 11 am. We got passes for Malo les Bains & went into Dunkerque,got the photos we had taken last time we were in & other things we wanted -

it was very windy all day—
Entry.254:
th
1917
Sunday.Left Park for railhead at 5.30 amfinishing at 11.20 amweather showery. The 6
th
Brigade played 66 D.S.C. Rugger in the evening & beat them 10 to 5 points after a very good game. Frank again played with 66
th
D.S.C.
Entry.255:
th
1917
It rained nearly all night & showery all day - We left park for Railhead at 5.30 amfinishing at 11 am. We rested in the afternoon & in the evening I read.- In the morning coming back to park I passed the sentry at the cross roads with his consent (I thought that the road had been opened) & got along about half a mile & was stopped by the adjutant of the column who
gener
park their lorries there & had to go back to the corner with the officer where he took my

name & particulars & had to go back by the bad road after all (the sentry told him that he had tried to stop me but I wouldnt take any notice - a lie of course -)
Entry.256:
th
1917
Left park at 5.30 amfor Railhead arriving back at 11 am,we found that we had to go back for a second load as the brigade was drawing double issue on account of moving in a couple of days. The day was extremely windy with a few showers.
Entry.257:
th
1917
I was kept in & had to attend Orderly room at 9 amaccused of forcing a guard & going down a one way road Contrary to traffic regulations & the O.C. read out a crime as long as your arm with evidence which would hang a man. I replied to the charge that I must have misunderstood the sentry & denied his charge that the sentry had tried to stop me,the case was remanded for further evidence -
Entry.258:
th
1917
The 66
th
D.S.C moved to Malo & we went with them - We left Malo again at 4.30 pm(our five lorries) & went to Coxyde dump for a load & we travelled all night.Stopped at Arneke & dumped the supplies,the Brigade had followed us & camped

at Arneke - I went to the O.C of 66
th
DSC before we left Malo & he told me that as we were separating from them my case would be dropped - I was just as well pleased
Entry.259:
st
1917
We drew at Arneke & hauled to near Ecke - Esq had magneto trouble but with a good lot of towing we managed to keep him with us - the weather was very windy & showery -
Entry.260:
st
1917
We drew at Caestre & dumped supplies at waggon lines,but had to pick them up again as orders suddenly came through to move to Ecke which we did -
Entry.261:
nd
1917
We drew at Caestre & delivered direct to batteries which were scattered.Fritz came over & dropped bombs last night but they were not too near us. We were parked in the square at Ecke with ourtailboards against the church yard, the amunition section was there too, but we did'nt have much to do with them,we did'nt even know the men—
Entry.262:
rd
1917
We drew at Caestre & issued to Batteries - We drew pay at ourrespective Bats. I drew 40 francs. We had to go back to Caestre for Petrol & coal - we stayed

there for a feed of eggs & chips & went back at 8.15 pm.Canadians are arriving here for the stunt which is shortly coming off—
Entry.263:
th
1917
Esq went back to 1
st
Anzac. Workshop for repairs. We had to draw twice at Caestre to-day - Fritz came over again last night but did'nt drop anything near us. Beautiful day,one of the best I have seen since we left Sierra Leone
Entry.264:
th
1917
Fritz came over last night & dropped bombs around us,two of them fell in the back yards of the houses opposite us - We drew as usual at Caestre & in the evening we were ordered to park down at the B.A.C. waggon lines on account of Fritz.
Entry.265:
th
1917
We drew at Caestre in the morning.In the afternoon we went to the 1
st
Anzac Ordnance at Poperinghe for clothing for 17
th
battery,they had'nt what we wantedso we came home empty - There has been a big bombardment going on in Ypres sector lately - the weather is rainy -
Entry.266:
th
 1917
Drew at Caestre as usual in the morning. We are moving to-morrow to near Ypres - I hit myself with the starting handle on the right breast & seem to have hurt myself internally,there is no outside sign—
Entry.267:
th
1917
We drew at Caestre & travelled through Bailleul which we had'nt seen for two months. Fritz has damaged it some with shell fire but not as much as we had heard. We stopped for dinner at Marie Louise's joint & went on through Locre past Canada corner to Dickebusch where the Brigade had their new waggon lines - we parked there for the night - (Dickebusch is 6 Kilos from Ypres)
Entry.268:
th
1917
I took^theColonel & several of his officers up to Ypres in the morning & waited there till they were ready to come back in the afternoon, it was our first trip to Ypres & we took a good look round,saw Cloth Hall etc - We watched a twelve inch Naval gun in action about 100 yds from where we were parked just across from the station,there were several Fritz planes over observing, I saw some of the boys I knew of the 5
th
A.S.P lovely day—
Entry.269:
th
 1917
We drew with 1
st
Anzac C.J.S.C. at Whipenhoek siding & delivered to Brigade. Whilst we were there (Dickebrusch) Fritz came over & dropped several bombs, killing three men of the brigade & also a lot of Tommies just across the road from us & about 30 of their mules. We figured that the bombs were poisoned by the way they affected some of the men, I dont know if theywere. We had to go back to Poperinghe to park with 1
st
Anzac C.T.S.C. -
Entry.270:
th
1917
We drew at
Reninghelst railhead
Whipenhoek sidingat 6.30 am& delivered to the brigade,they moved off the main Ypres road up between Ooderdom & Vlamantynghe on account of Fritzes Planes - We watched a Fritz plane caught by a searchlight, last night, it was a fine sight & the first I had seen so far - My breast was very sore where I hit it with the starting handle, so sore that I could'nt drive. I think a rib is fractured or cracked—
Entry.271:
th
1917
We drew at
Reninghelst railhead
^Whipenhoek Sidingat 6.30 am& delivered to Brigade & returned to park in the afternoon. Most of the Australian troops are up here now for this big stunt supposed to be coming off next Sunday - I hope the weather holds -
Entry.272:
th
 1917
We got to railhead at 6.30 ambut did'nt get our load till noon as the train was delayed - I read the official history of the 1
st
Canadian Division & saw the graves of some of the officers mentioned L
t
Col. Boyle & Major Hart McHarg etc. in the Poperinghe old cemetary,also saw the cemetary near Oouderdom of a lot of the P.P.C.L.I. (Princess Pats) killed early in 1915. We delivered our supplies & returned to Park. - fine day—
Entry.273:
th
1917
The sentry called us at 5.30 ambut we did'nt leave Park till 10 amthen we went to Reninghelst railhead to draw We drew supplies & delivered to Brigade & returned to Park - Two of our drivers Paddy & Alf were transferred to 4
th
D.S.C. Hec met an old cobber of his in 21
st
Battl.^campednear Oouderdom - lovely day -
Entry.274:
th
1917
We Went to Reninghelst rlhd - at 10.30 am& drew the supplies & delivered them returning to park at 7 pm.
Entry.275:
th
1917
Sunday.We drew at Reninghelstas usual & dumped our load. at
B.A.C
the respective batteries & parked in the paddock next to the B.A.C to rest instead of going back right away to Park & getting

on a coal stunt or some other job, it was just about noon & our lorries were parked close to-gether,mine nearest to B.A.C. Fritz came over with three big bombing planes & fourteen smaller machines. I was out on my tailboard firing at the leading plane with my rifle on the chance of hitting something - & he lowered his tailboard I saw two bombs coming down close together & watched them turning over & over I got in the lorry & knealton the floor resting on my rifle. Charlie was with me in the lorry, I heard (& felt) one explosion & waited several seconds for the other one, but it did'nt come, so I got up very much marvelling that I was still whole & went outside to see where they lobbed & the extent of the damage done (meantime there were one or two bombs exploding in some of the battery lines) the small^holewhich the one which exploded made was only five yards from my lorry the other one with a broken tail about a yard further away & yet a third about ten yards further still away also with a broken tail & within one hundred yards square there were three other duds - the one that exploded wounded a man over

Sept 16
th
1917(continued)
in the B.A.C lines who had taken cover under a
g
G.S. Waggon (he was taken to hospital) - the tarpaulin cover on my lorry
was
had a number of holes in it where pieces had gone through just above where my head had been & one piece just grazed my knee (I had shorts on) later on a Tommy R.E. Officer & W.O. came down & destroyed the duds with gun cotton - I consider that I had a very narrow escape,had the bomb fallen facing the other way I should have got the full force of it— lovely day -
Entry.276:
th
1917
We drew at Reninghelst at 10.30 amdelivered supplies & returned to Park at 5.30 pm. We went up to Y.M.C.A. at Whipenhoek in the evening (opposite casualty clearing stations) across the fields about¾ of a mile. There was'nt much doing & when we got back Jack, Dick & Blue were Hookey mut as Kipling says (it was Bluey's birthday) they were all more or less helpless & I worked hard putting
them
Blue over the tailboard into his lorry -
Entry.277:
th
1917
We drew at Reninghelst as usual & delivered the goods returning at 5 pm. We had a gas mask inspection at 7 pm.Weather still beautiful.
Entry.278:
th
1917
The weather still holds good though it has been threatening - We hear that the stunt is coming off to-night at 9 pm. - Received letters from Aussie.
Entry.279:
th
1917
Preliminary stunt came off
fr
early this morning - 1
st
& second Aust Divies hopped over with Jocks& Tommies & took all objectives in six hours instead of 24. Great excitement reigned at the C.C.S in the evening, we went over there & talked with the wounded men, watching them coming in all the time, plenty of wounded Fritzes also. We watched one or two operations at the 2
nd
Canadian. C.C.S. amputations etc it is a sad sight - Eleven planes came over during last night with bombs but none fell very near us - It rained just before the stunt but cleared up again - The last two mornings we have got up at 4.30 amleaving the park for Reninghelst railhead at 5.30 am.
Entry.280:
st
1917
Got
Left park at 5.30. for Reninghelst got our loads & had to take them to a dump where we drew our Brigade supplies by batteries. I serve the 17
th
battery.
Entry.281:
nd
1917
Reninghelst & dump at same time.We are still advancing - fine day -
Entry.282:
rd
 1917
