Fritz came over several times last night & dropped bombs, catching three Tommy lorries up on the Whipenhoek road,they caught fire & were destroyed. We made our usual trip to Reninghelst & dump to Brigade. We went into Poperinghe in the evening & I bought a small set of chessmen & board to play Hec. as he could never get a game.
Entry.283:
th
1917
Reveille 4 am,left Park at 5 am&had to make two trips with supplies - In the afternoon Rex took us to ordnance to get clothing etc for the battery.We got back to Park at 7 pm. I had a game of chess with Hec.
Entry.284:
th
1917
Reveille 4 amleft Park 5 amto Reninghelst dump & brigade - Nothing special to-day - I lay out in the sun for an hour or so - Charlie & I went into Poperinghe in the evening - lovely day -
Entry.285:
th
1917
The 4
th
& 5
th
Divies hopped over at 6 amthis morning & were successful & found it easy - We went along in the evening to the 2
nd
Canadian C.C.S. & talked to the wounded. Fritz often counter-attacks but without much success
Entry.286:
th
1917
It rained a little during the night but cleared up at about 10 am. We were up at

4 amas usual & did our job. Fritz has'nt been over for several days now.
Entry.287:
th
1917
Left park as usual at 5 am& took our supplies from Reninghelst to the Brigade. The weather keeps beautiful cold nights & warm days - on account of the cold early mornings I left off my shorts & got back into breeches.
Entry.288:
th
1917
Left park as usual at 5 am& broke a front spring so came back early from the brigade to put on a new one. Hec. met his cobber out of the 21
st
batl. & he came in the lorry & had tea with us & Hec went into Poperinghe with him after tea. Fritz came over at 7.30 pmdropping bombs in Poperinghe & he was over all the time in relays till 2.30 amdropping bombs all round us,the Anti's did some beautiful shooting, especially the battery across the road from us,they brought down two Fritzes that night,it was very spectacular from beginning to end and very awe inspiring. I think all of us felt a bit windy though none showed it. Acouple of the fellows took their blankets & went out into the paddock & burried themselves in an old haystack - Hec. did'nt come home from Pop -
Entry.290:
1917
I reported Hec. missing & told them he had gone to Poperinghe. I went to Railhead as usual & did my job. We learned that there were 1500 casualties in the Poperinghe district last night, nearly all soldiers too. I went up to the casualtyclearing station in the evening to enquire for Hec. but could'nt learn any news of him, I wrote to his cobber in 21
st
Battl incase he had got through.

October.1
st
 1917
Fritz bombed again last night but casualties in this district were only two hundred. The battery across the road from us brought down another plane in flames. I went to the railhead etc in the morning -

Oct.2
nd
1917
Last night Fritz left our district alone but bombed about three miles away round Steenvoorde - went out on supply run as usual. In the
evening
afternoonI went into Poperinghe & saw the Town Major but could get no track of Hec. amongst the killed so hope for the best. I was on guard in the evening first shift 7 pmtill 10.20.
Entry.291:
rd
1917
Fritz did'nt bomb within three miles of us last night but was over us a couple of times & the Antis had a go at him - he put some Shrapnell over into Poperinghe early this morning - I did my trip as usual -



Oct.4
Entry.292:
1917
Hop over this morning & all objectives were taken quickly. We drew at Reninghelst & delivered at Ouderzeele where the Brigade moved to - we went back to Pop - (1
st
A.C.T.S.C) to park for the night - wet drizzly day—

Oct.5
Entry.293:
1917
We drew at Reninghelst again & took the supplies to a place near Merville between Foret de Nieppe, & Merville - We parked with the brigade - The day broke fine but turned cold & rained a bit -

Oct.6
Entry.294:
1917
We drew at Caestre (so also did the 3
rd
& 12
Entry.295: brigades) & delivered to the brigade & made our park in a farm yard,we hear that we are out for a three week spell. I made application for transfer to the Aust. Flying corps - Wet cold day
Entry.296:
th
 1917
We drew at Caestre going via Vieux Berquin & delivered to Brigade - wet cold day -
Entry.297:
th
1917
We drew at Caestre - very cold night last night & this morning broke fine but it rained a little in the afternoon - no news of Hec. I have asked for them to try & get some news - I had a game of chess with Frank - When we left 1
st
A.C.T.S.C. they sent five loaders with us.one of them

lives on my lorry with me (one on each lorry) Joe -(his name).
Entry.298:
th
 1917
Last night was warm. We got up at 6 am& moved off at 6.45 for Caestre.Train was late & we got back at 11 am. We went & got comforts in the afternoon & distributed them amongst the batteries - Frank came in for supper & I made some trifle with cake(comforts) custard made with eggs & milk (from Farm house) & rum (issue) instead of brandy & it was good
Entry.299:
th
1917
Got our supplies from Caestre arriving back 11 am. In the afternoon Joe & I walked into Merville. I had a haircut. It was cold & rainy in the morning but fine in the afternoon
Entry.301:
1917
We went to Caestre as usual - In the afternoon Charlie, Joe & I walked to La Motte(7 kilometres) & had a hot bath at a civies house,three tubs together in the same room,it was very comfortable & we enjoyed it - by the time we walked home again we were tired out - we had some hot milk & rum & went to bed -

Oct.12
Entry.302:
1917
We did two trips to Caestre to-day as Fip's
tyre
wheel had to be re-tyred,we lost no time on the road and finished at 1 pm. Raining all day—

Oct.13
th
 1917
Esq made two trips to-day as Fip's lorry is still out of action - Raining all day on & off - we had some lovely beer in Vieux Berquin & Madamoiselle there told me that the Australians would be away from that district in another week & that
English
English troops would come in - The civies always knew our movements before we did -
Entry.303:
th
1917
Fip was on the road again & we made our usual trip to Caestre,fine day for a change - I dreamed last night that I was wounded -
Entry.304:
th
1917
We were in Caestre by 8 ambut the train did'nt get in till 1.30 pmso we waited down at the railhead - a lot of Canadians are up this way for the next stunt. The Canadian light Horse are near Abeele. fine day -
Entry.305:
th
1917
We did our usual trip to Caestre & when we got back had to return again for a load of coal. We pinched some gum thigh boots from a railway shed they will be very useful. P.P.C.L.I. are up here - Burnie, Budge, & three others went on leave to-day to Blighty - fine day -

Oct.17
th
 1917
We went to Caestre for supplies & again with unserviceable stores from the battery as they are moving to-morrow. We had a feed of beautiful apples out of the orchard that the 17
Entry.307:
th
1917
We drew at Caestre & proceeded through Bailleul & Westoutre to La Clyte. The Brigade did'nt arrive till 7 pm. We waited for them & delivered the supplies - The driver in Burnie's place set his lorry afire but it was quickly put out with Pyrines & no damage done - We went back to Meteren to park with 49
th
D.S.C a Tommy column (our three brigades were there) it was a very dark night & the roads strange. Went through Locre & Bailleul arrived there at midnight -
Entry.308:
th
1917
We drew at Caestre & proceeded through Bailleul to La Clytte & delivered
sip
supplies to brigade, got back to Meteren at 7 pm& had supper - fair day but showery -
Entry.309:
th
1917
I had to go to the tyre press in Caestre & get a rear wheel re-tyred the other lorries split my load up between them & delivered it for me. I got back to park at 9 pm fine day—
Entry.310:
st
1917
We drew at Brulooge railhead just under Kemmel hill. & delivered to brigade at La Clytte.
Entry.311:
nd
1917
We drew at Brulooge railhead, it rained all last night & through the day. We got back to Meteren at 6 pm. AStaff Sergeantcame to take charge of our five lorries which we resented,as we had been all the summer with only a lance corporal in charge - one of ourselves,& we needed no looking after -
Entry.312:
rd
1917
It rained hard during the night & everywhere to-day isdeep mud. We left the park at 9 am& had to wait at railhead, as the train was late we stayed the night with the brigade
Entry.313:
th
1917
We left at 9 am& took officers & gunners from our respective batteries up to Zillibecke to look at their alloted gun positions & as advance party. The roads were very bad in places & we had an interesting time Fritz was shelling a bit - We got back & drew the supplies & delivered them & returned to Meteren at 5.30 pm.
Entry.314:
th
1917
We left Park at 6.30 amfor Brulooge railhead but did'nt draw fodder till 10 am& rations till 2 pmtook it up into Dickebusch where the Brigade had moved to. 17
th
battery was camped at Dickebusch church (what remained of it) The main Ypres road through Dickebusch was closed to traffic & I had to go round a very bad road to get to the church. I got stuck once but got a pull out,got back to Meteren at 5.30 pm.
Entry.315:
th
1917
We made another advance this morning with success - we drew at Brulooge railhead in bulk & split it up at La Clyte church & delivered to our respective batteries. I was able by telling a tale to the sentry at the cross roads, to travel the main road to Dickebusch - It has rained hard all day & the roads are getting very bad - we got back to Meteren at 5 pm.
Entry.316:
th
1917
We drew in bulk at Brulooge rhd - & split up loads at La Clyte. & delivered to batteries at Dickebusch. Fine day but cold - we got back to Meteren at 7 pm.
Entry.317:
th
1917
Fine day & cold but very wet under foot - We drew as usual at Brulooge & delivered to batteries got back to park 6 pm.
Entry.318:
th
1917
Went out at 8 amto 1
st
Anzac ordnance at Poperinghe, then on to Brulooge railhead for supplies which we delivered - we parked up in Bailleul on the way home long enough to have a hot bath, it was'nt bad 1.50 francs. Got back to Meteren 7.30 pm. Fritz is over here now dropping bombs about two miles away -
Entry.319:
th
1917
We left park at 9 amfor Brulooge railhead delivered our load & returned to Park,cold wind & rainy all day - Fritz was shelling Bailleul all day & got a direct hit on the E.F.C killing five men. Heard officially that Hec died of wounds received on night of Sept 29
th
in Poperinghe at 2
nd
Canadian.C.C.S, on Sept 30
th
I was at that C.C.S on that date & could learn nothing of him. Budge came back from Blighty leave.
Entry.320:
st
1917
Lovely day to-day.We drew at Brulooge as usual, returning to park 5.30 pm.We went to a Corporals mess in Meteren in the evening & had a bit of a sing-song -

Oct
Entry.322:
brigade waggon lines were bombed last night with a few casualties.We heard Fritz over but he did'nt lay any eggs near Meteren. fairly fine day—

Nov.2
nd
1917
We drew at Brulooge as usual & delivered to the brigade - on the way back we saw some of the Canadian light horse escorting Fritz prisoners back from the line.
Entry.323:
rd
1917
The roads are very slippery & heavy, we had to make a detour for Dickebusch with our supplies. Yank came on with me as second driver.

Nov.4
Entry.324:
1917
We made our usual trip to Brulooge railhead La Clytte & Dickebusch & return to Meteren - Weather fairly warm but rainy.

Nov.5
Entry.325:
1917
In passing through Locre on our way back from Brulooge,Yank called into the Convent & asked to see the grave of Major W.K. Redmond who was burried in the grounds,there was also a Canadian burried there - roads very bad.Weather warm.

Nov.6
Entry.326:
1917
Usual trip to Brulooge & Dickebusch.Miserable weather in the morning but it cleared up in the afternoon. We often see our planes practicing with machine guns over the Dickebusch lake at a ground target - Austroops have made another advance - Fritz shelled Bailleul all day long -
Entry.327:
th
1917
I was kept in for the day to work on the lorry. Joe & Yank were set to work cleaning, instead of which they went away & got boozed & when the officer came to inspect the work a few pleasantries were exchanged but nothing happened. Joe got blind. speechless, paraletic in the evening. Yank got quarrelsome.
Entry.329:
1917
We went out again this morning to Brulooge railhead & the brigade - a machine came down in the Dickebusch lake
& the
whilst practicing & the pilot was drowned.There was much internal trouble on the lorry yesterday but to-day things are near normal - Joe had a very big head - we got John Bull to see what he had to see about the war.

Nov.9
th
1917
The weather is still wet & miserably cold - We made our usual trip to Brulooge & Dickebusch,the battery is having a lot of casualties, mostly gas & are short of gunners.Charlie left the lorries & went back to the 106
th
How. battery -
Entry.331:
1917
ToBrulooge for supplies as usual The roads are very sloppy but generally hard underneath - a big bombardment started this morning.

Nov.11
th
1917
Bombardment still on,instead of returning to Meteren after our work was done we went to Park with 39
th
DSC (Tommies) between Locre & Bailleul.
Entry.332:
th
1917
The first fine day we have had for a long while. There was¼ inch of ice on exposed water this morning. We made our usual trip for supplies -
Another
Entry.333:
th
1917
Another bigbombardment started last night - made our usual trip for supplies & returned to X corps in Boesheepe to Park.
Entry.334:
th
1917
Left park at 7.30 amfor Brulooge & delivered supplies to Brigade, the
Brigade is
waggon lines aremoving to-morrow to Kemmel Hill the guns being in action now further to the right, in front of Kemmel.
When
We returned to Boesheepe & had supper after which I walked to C.L.H. Headquarters on the Abeele Watts road & saw an old friend, spent the evening with him in his favourite estaminet & he walked almost home with me. I got back to the lorry at midnight to find my leave warrant for Blighty waiting for me. Yank also had one.

Nov.15
Entry.335:
1917
Jim (from Amunitions section) was sent

to take over my lorry & Yank & I left Boesheepe at 9 am& caught the 11 amtrain from Abeele to Boulogne arriving there at 4.30 pm. We jumped out of the train when she slowed up this side of the bridge climbed down the embankment & went to a café & had tea,instead of marching up one blanket hill to the so called rest campafter tea we got a room, made enquiries about about channel boat & went to bed at 8 pm.
Entry.336:
th
1917
We got up & had breakfast & caught the first boat at 9 am. We waited for the convoy which consisted of three leave boats & two Hospital boats & we were escorted by three destroyers,the sea was calm & we had a good trip across,entrained at Folkestone & arrived at Victoria 2.30 pm. We took a taxi to A.I.F headquarters, Horseferry R
d
& got our passes stamped etc & went & had a feed.I then left Yank & proceeded to Kingston where I had an Aunt & I was duly welcomed -
Entry.337:
th
1917
I went up to town to Commonwealth Bank - had dinner at Eagle Hut. American Y.M.C.A. - & returned to Kingston - I took my cousin to the theatre in the evening & saw "To-night's the night
Entry.338:
th
 1917
Sunday -I stayed at home all day & had a good rest - Went to Church in the evening with my Aunt.
Entry.339:
th
1917
I went up to town in the morning & saw The Tower, & S
t
Pauls Cathedral,went up into the whispering gallery & heard the history of same whispered on one side of the dome to be heard distinctly on the other side. I Bought a book I had heard a lot about - "Raymond" by Sir Oliver Lodge,& returned to Kingston - The weather miserably dull but fine.
Entry.340:
th
1917
I took my cousin to M
me
Taussauds in Baker Street in the morning,we had dinner at Slaters restaurant in the Strand & afterwards met M
r
M. to go to Bairnsfathers "Better ole" but we couldnt get seats, so we Went to the Palladium & saw Geo Robey - We got back home 6.30 pm.
Entry.341:
st
1917
I went to Euston to enquire about Glasgow trains etc. I had dinner at Victoria S
t
Y.M.C.A. & wrote some letters. Went to the Bank & back home. Left Kingston at 9.30 pm& caught 11.30 pmtrain to Glasgow to see a friend.
Entry.342:
nd
1917
Arrived Glasgow 10 amafter a

comfortable journey, had a wash & brush up & some breakfast on the station, with a man whose aquaintance I made on the journey up & we went to the Cathedral & looked round with a guide. Then I went out to Clyde Bank to see my friends arriving 1 pm, had dinner & went for a walk. We went to the pictures in the evening & slept at a Hotel.
Entry.343:
rd
1917
I went round to my friends place in the morning & we went by tram to Glasgow as I wished to go back to Leamington.We had lunch & I caught 1 pmtrain to Rugby arriving there about midnight & finding no connections for Leamington till 8.10 am, I had to find somewhere to sleep which I eventually did, after some trouble - I was made very comfortable in a
private
select boarding house -
Entry.344:
th
1917
I caught the 8 amtrain to Leamington & went straight to my brother-in-law's people whom I was going to visit. My beau-frère had not turned up though hewas expecting to be home about this time on leave - We went to the Pierots in the evening & had a pleasant time. I was to stay with my friends for a few days & found them very nice people -
Entry.345:
th
1917
We went to Church in the morning & for a walk in the afternoon,it was a fine day - & some friends came in in the evening & we had some music.
Entry.346:
th
1917
I had made an appointment with the dentist for 9.15 amwhich I kept. He did all the work necessary in 1¾ hours (filled seven teeth) & made a very fine job of them for£2.12.6. M
r
& M
rs
S & I went to the theatre in the evening & saw "To-night's the night" (the second time I have seen it.
Entry.347:
th
1917
I slept in this morning got up in time to have a good hot bath before lunch (which we had early) & I caught 12.46 train to Paddington - Left my haversack at Waterloo & went to tea in Oxford Street with & friend & went back to Kingston at 8.30 pm.
Entry.348:
th
1917
I went to Victoria & booked a bed for to-night as I am going back to France to-morrow morning a day early as I wish to visit my Sister at her Unit. No 1. Canadian Gen. Hospital. Etaples - I took my Aunt to the Pictures in the afternoon& the theatre in the evening & saw "Search me" it was very good - I got back to my bed in Victoria at 12.30 -
Entry.349:
th
1917
I caught 6.30 amtrain to Folkestone arriving there 8.45 am& transferred onto a boat leaving at 10 amarrived at Boulogne 12 noon - sea was very choppy & though I was'nt sick I wasn't too far from it & I was very pleased to be once more on terra firma.I was put in the procession for one blanket hill but I hopped into a side street at first opportunity,evading the Red Caps (F.M.P). I made my way towards Etaples hopped a lorry & arrived at the hospital at 5 am. I met my sister & we were served tea together in the Matrons private sitting room where we spent the evening together (I had'nt seen her since she came from Salonika to see me at Parkhouse camp in March). A Sergeant fixed me up with a bed for the night -
Entry.351:
1917
I had breakfast in the Sergts mess & met my sister at 8.30 am. We walked to "Paris Plage" & met a friend of Marions (my Sister) & we went to dinner to-gether finishing up on a bottle of fiz(40 francs) I caught the 2.10 pmtrain from Etaples to Boulogne & hopped into bed for a while & caught a train at midnight for Bailleul (a troop train,comprenez? & as

it was full up I had to get into the little brake box on top & in this cold cramped possie I spent the time from midnight till I arrived at Bailleul at 8 am.)
Entry.352:
st
1917
Yes Bailleul at last - I went into an egg & chip joint to get warm & have breakfast & then went to Marie Louise's joint as I expected she would know the whereabouts of the section. I met some of the boys at her place on the way to Brulooge Railhead for supplies, so I stayed in the warm till they got back again at 3 pmmy buss with a broken spring - Our park is just outside Bailleul on the Hazebrouck road parked with 5
th
D.S.C. I feel very sorry to be back again -
Entry.353:
nd
1917
Took the broken spring off & left it in the blacksmith shop to be repaired & being Sunday we had a half day off. Weather very cold & windy -
Entry.354:
rd
1917
Weather still very cold & windy. We put the spring on & found it a very cold job - the lorry had'nt been looked after during my absence & I found plenty to keep me busy all day - Jim stayed on with me as second driver - In the evening we went to a Sketch in Bailleul "The Spy from

the sky" it was played especially for the soldiers as a warning to keep their own council as it was so hard to tell who is a spy these days, & dinkum it is hard to know who to trust - the play was very good & I think that it went home -
Entry.355:
th
1917
I went to Brulooge railhead & we delivered to the Brigade just this side of Kemmel hill. The weather was fairly cold, but no wind, it tried to snow but the sun prevailed. Fritz came over last night & the night before & dropped a few bombs on Hazebrouck - I did some letter writing in the evening - Jim came home well boozed -
Entry.356:
th
1917
Last night was very cold. Hard frost - to-day is cold but sunny & no wind.We did our trip for supplies, Budge & I walked to the top of Kemmel hill, from which advantageous position we were able to see Lille on the right & Ypreson the left & the intervening country - the old cage on the top where a lion used to be kept was rather knocked about but still standing - I wrote letters in the evening, we were given an issue of rum, which we duly appreciated as a night cap to make us sleep well & warm—
Entry.357:
th
1917
Still very cold, but bright & no wind,frozen under foot all day - we made our trip for supplies as usual - I wrote several letters in the evening. The Primus was'nt going too well, I had no prickers -
Entry.358:
th
1917
Weather quite mild today,we got home from supplies at 2.30 pmas usual & worked on the lorry till 4pm- Fred (came over with me on the "Medic") from 5
th
D.S.C. came in & spent the evening with me & we partook of some delicasies that I had received that day in a parcel from my Aunt in Kingston -
Entry.359:
th
1917
Very warm to-day & a little wet & muddy underfoot. Yank got back from leave (8 days late) & was put on 38316 lorry - We made our trip for supplies as usual.
Entry.360:
th
1917
Sunday -It rained all last night & all day to-day - We did our usual trip for supplies.
Entry.361:
th
1917
The weather cleared & remained fair but it was very raw cold - Joe & Jim came home together well inked & I had to put them both to bed & give themsomething to eat - Usual trip on supplies.
Entry.362:
th
1917
We made our trip on supplies & returned at 2.15 pmto Park & cleaned the lorry up a bit. Weather fine & not too cold - We saw Fritz come over & get two baloons, forcing the observers to descend by Parachute shooting at them the while with the machine gun however they all landed alright - The boys voted on the conscription issue - mostly against it - Fred & I went to see "the Barn Owls" in Bailleul in the evening they were very good - I had to put Joe to bed again when he came home.
Entry.363:
th
1917
I stayed in to-day & cleaned the buss - fine day & not too cold - we went up town in the afternoon, I bought some silk & lace table centres to send away.Fritz came over in strength in full daylight & dropped bombs along the Bailleul-Armentières road,he got seven men of the 5 A.S.P. & put the wind up a good many more.
Entry.364:
th
1917
I went out on Supplies this morning, got back 3 pm. I sent parcel away - also received a parcel from Glasgow friendwhich included shortbread etc. Fred came in & spent the evening with me,he is going on a trip to-morrow to Boulogne.Poor old Tom & Jackie were killed to-day

monkeying with a dud bomb that fell yesterday - Tom picked it up & accidently dropped it & it was'nt a dud when it fell right, it killed Jackie instantly & blew Toms legs off & he remained consious for a minute or so & died -
Entry.365:
th
1917
Very warm to-day,but a fine misty rain was falling all day - went on supplies as usual. I swopped batteries with one of the other lorries, I now serve 18
th
batt. instead of 17
th
batt. Fred left for Boulogne with his lorry. Fritz shelled Hazebrouck heavily -
Entry.366:
th
1917
Beautiful day,but still wet underfoot - We did our supply trip - Jim had a liberal lot of rum up at the battery & kept it up in the evening - The 5
A.S.P.
D.S.C.have had several lorries catch fire during this month,some of them burnt pretty badly -
Entry.367:
th
1917
Cold & windy. I had trouble starting my engine & had to get a tow to start, the magneto is crook (Dixie).I carried on with the supplies the rest of the 5
th
D.S.C moved off to Boulogne to-day -
Entry.368:
th
1917
The weather was wild & snowing in the morning - I had to get a tow to start my engine again, but carried on with the Supplies - Fritz is bombing near here very heavily - our guns are bombarding continuously -
Entry.369:
th
1917
Fine day but a bit of wind made it very cold - I got a tow to start my engine again, after the engine is warm, I can start it by hand. Our guns are still hard at it - To-morrow we draw at Steenwerck railhead as the Brigade is moving towards De Suel - The 1
st
D.S.C. took the place of the 5
th
D.S.C. & we remained attached to them.
Entry.370:
th
1917
Beautiful day but cold, freezing all day - We drew to-day at Steenwerck,the brigade moved to-day - 106
th
& B.A.C. up at Neuve Eglise & 16
th
17
th
& 18
th
Batteries at De Seul & on Bailleul.Armentières road near La Crèche - We did'nt get back to park till 5 pm. The 12
th
Brigade moved into the waggon lines which the 6
th
vacated -
Entry.371:
th
1917
Very cold, ice bearing everywhere there was a thick rhyme on the trees all day. I went up to K column

workshop to get my magneto fixed,the electrician had a go at it & gave it back as fixed,I was out at noon & went to draw for the brigade - I wrote letters in the evening -
Entry.372:
st
1917
Very cold but fine - Had to be towed again to start the engine, I drew the supplies & went up to the workshop when I had finished & stayed the night. Roy & Dick were also in the workshop & they spent the evening with me -
Entry.373:
nd
1917
Not so cold to-day - I left the engine for the Staff Sergt to try & start, but he could'nt get her going,took carburettor off & worked on it & eventually got her started - I did'nt go on supplies to-day as I could'nt get out in time - When I got out I went back to the Park - had a hot bath in Bailleul -
Entry.374:
rd
1917
Very cold again - Had to be towed again to start the engine - drew supplies for Brigade & got back to Park at 2.30 pm.
Entry.375:
th
1917
Fine day, quite soft with an attempt at rain. I was able to start the engine to-day as it was warmer. I drew supplies & returned to park 3 pm. Joe was warned for guard for

to-night but he came home too boozed to know anything so Jim who was'nt bad said he would do it & he went to look for the guard room, he opened the door of the Q.M. store (which was next to the guard room) thinking that it was the guard room, he asked the Q.M. Sergt a question & getting anything but a civil reply he stonkered the Q.M. with the result that he was put in the guard room as prisoner & I did Joe's guard after all & Jim lay down in the guard room dead to the world & did'nt even know I was there.
Entry.376:
th
1917
Jim was let out of the guard room as it is Xmas day,the Q.M. has marks of anything but an Xmas spirit on his face - we drew & delivered fodder as usual but G.S. Waggons - Snow squalls at intervals all day - 18
th
bat. had their Xmas dinner at 12.30 (to which we were invited) but we did'nt get finished work till it was over so we went along to the 16
th
Bat. mess at 3 pm& had a good feed,there was more than everyone could eat of Turkey & ham with beaucoup vegetables & pudding to follow. with as much bottled beer as required - I went with the lorry round to the several

batteries & collected the other personnel of our little unit & went back to Park about 11 pm. We enjoyed the day though it was anything but a homey Xmas,it was way ahead of last Xmas spent on the old Medic.
Entry.377:
th
1917
We went out on supplies as usual the snow from last night stayed on the ground & it was squally again to-day, with sunshine in between whiles. Jim stayed the night with his brother in the amunition section at La Crèche.
Entry.378:
th
1917
I picked Jim up on the way to Steenwerck for supplies - We went back for coal for the brigade & delivered same.We had some whisky at the 18
th
canteen & went back to Park feeling very pleased with ourselves & looking
thro
at the world through rose-coloured glasses - We stayed in the lorry all the evening & with the primus kept good & warm. We have an issue of rum every night which we use as a night cap—
Entry.379:
th
1917
We went to the Caestre tyre-press & had a
new
rear wheel re-tyred & came back Via Hazebrouck & La Mott, Foret de Nieppe & Vieux Berquin. certainly a long way round but we wished to see

what damage Fritz had done to Hazebrouck with all his shelling & bombing,it was pretty knocked about especially near the railway & station - I went to Pictures in the evening with Burnie & Scotty & afterwards for a feed of eggs & chips,it snowed all evening—
Entry.380:
th
1917
We went to Steenwerck as usual for supplies - When we got back to Park we had to paint out our shamrock sign (

signifying supplies) & paint shells on instead in red & blue as we are forming the amunition section, much to my satisfaction - fine day but pretty cold. Frank & Beachy had an argument which ended in blows & then not till Beachy threw in the sponge (which I should say he was in need of at that stage in the region of his face) the weather got warmer in the evening.
Entry.381:
th
1917
We have finished drawing supplies for the Brigade now, their G.S. Waggons will do it from now on - We moved our five lorries to Steenwerck & parked with 3
rd
D.S.C. in the square - The 12
th
bgd lorries took our place with the 1
st
D.S.C. & the 12
th
Bgd lorries & also 3
rd
bgd finished drawing supplies for their respective brigades—
Entry.382:
st
1917
Jim stayed in bed till noon, Joe & I walked down to the barber at the station & had a hair cut & left our razors to be honed. We walked into Bailleul & had tea at Marie Louise's Joint & Frank & I went to the Dons at the concert hall,they were very good - we met Joe & Phil again at 8.15 pm& walked home to Park about 7 Kilo's. had a snack & waited up to see if
we
our guns were going to wish Fritz a happy new year,as we heard they would butnothing happened & we went to-bed & there ends the year 1917 - During which time I came to France & got quite a bit of experience, & have been from Rouen by lorry up through Amiens & Albert Doullens,S
t
Poll. Bailleul. Dunkerque & back to Poperinghe & Ypres etc finishing up the year round Bailleul again,we have been parked during that time with eleven different M.T. Columns, attached for rations & dicipline -

The winter so far has been very mild, with practically no snow & January coming in like a lamb, will it as they say go out like a lion?

1918
Entry.383:
st
 1918
We are now part of an amunition
colu
section,though we are not yet parked with the rest of the section. We are termed 6
th
A.B.A.F.A.P.S - (6
th
Army Brigade. Aust. Field. Artillery. Park section) - & our colour patches consist of a red shell withS/6in blue We started up & went up to Neuve Eglise for amunition, but there was nothing doing when we got there so we went back to park. We went for a five kilometre walk before we went to bed.
Entry.384:
nd
1918
We were all put on fatigue work taking down a Y.M.C.A. Hut which the 3
rd
D.S.C. intended taking with them when they moved, which they are anticipating - Weather very soft & a little rain fell.
Entry.385:
rd
1918
3
rd
D.S.C. moved to Bailleul Armentières road next to 1
st
A.S.P. & we moved with them,in the afternoon we did a bit of cleaning on the lorry. Weather mild & bright & sunny. Fritz put over a bit of shrapnel trying for the baloon over K column workshop.
Entry.386:
th
1918
We were busy all the morning cleaning underneath the lorry thoroughly as our new officer (Joe Grim, as he was known to the section) went crook at us for the filthy state of the lorry (as he expressed it)

In the afternoon we had a tin of metho burning (methylated Spirits issued for putting in radiators to minimise chances of freezing but we used our own discreation as to how we used it & we found that we derived more comfort from it by burning it in an open vessel inside the lorry) & sat round it. I stayed in & read all the evening -
Entry.387:
th
1918
We had to set out our tools & personal kits for inspection by Joe Grim,after that ordeal was over, Joe & I walked into Bailleul & had tea then we went to see the Dons at the concert hall & walked home after—

Memo - The weather has been very soft all this week thoring consistently - Coal & bread are almost unprocurable by the civil population here.
Entry.388:
th
1918
We went to Steenwerck railhead & hauled a load of oats to 10
th
Brigade dump. Jim drove 21136 -
Entry.389:
th
1918
We did'nt go out to-day. I painted the new lockers which Ibuilt in the lorry & it is very cosy. I went to Bailleul & had a hot bath,also went to ordnance & changed a p
r
of breeches.
Entry.390:
th
1918
A wild morning. snowing hard and cold. I had to go out on a job. so also did Bud -

We went up to Steenwerck R.E. Dump & loaded up with R.E. stores. Bud had a cracked cylinder & I had to tow his lorry with my load on & his also. I towed him to our destination OX Kent amunition dump & then towed him back to Park. I went into Bailleul & spent the evening with Jack & Dick. 12
th
Bgd. in their lorries -
Entry.391:
th
1918
Fine but cold in the morning & snowing all afternoon - in the evening it got much warmer - we did'nt go out to-day - I had letters from home
Entry.392:
th
1918
It started to thaw very much to-day, no lorries out on account of the thaw. it is quite cold on hands & feet - we can get no "metho" now, but manage to keep the lorry fairly warm with the primus -
Entry.393:
th
1918
Weather still soft - nothing to do - I read "the Harvester" J.S. Porter. I had a bit of an argument with Joe,which he took to heart he went into Bailleul in the evening & he came home boozed at night—
Entry.394:
th
1918
Still thawing,very wet underfoot & there is practically no ice or snow left. I wroteaway for Pelman course of memory training - Received a parcel from Marion as she is on leave in Blighty -
Entry.395:
th
1918
We cleaned up the buss in the morning & I read "McClusky the reformer" A.G. Hales in the afternoon - Harold just back from Paris leave spent the afternoon in the lorry with us, talking needless to say mostly about the gay city.
Entry.396:
th
1918
We had another fall of snow last night.Nothing to do to-day - I read all the morning & made an ascetylene gas lamp in the afternoon & wrote letters in the evening - We are getting our rum issue every night again -
Entry.397:
th
1918
We stayed in all day with the back down ascetylene lamp burning (works très bonne) & read in comfort - we also pinched a five gallon drum of "metho". it rained nearly all day & was a bit windy -
Entry.398:
th
1918
Very stormy night lots of rain & a high wind. ditches & holes were full this of water this morning,but it is'nt cold. I stayed in all day & read "Quinneys" by Vachell - Had letters also a book by Post. Joe goes into Bailleul every evening -
Entry.399:
th
1918
It was snowing & raining more or less all day & we spent a real lazy day, we lay down all afternoon & slept - Joe stayed in & read in the evening for a change.
Entry.400:
th
1918
Fine day & warm, I brightened up the buss a bit in the morning - which consisted of wiping it over with a mixture of petrol & oil to make it look as if it had just been painted, so that Fritz could see them well with the sun shining on them - I read all the afternoon - I received an Xmas billy from Queensland which I thankfully acknowledged in the evening—
Entry.401:
th
1918
Fine & Warm - nothing to do all day.My Paris leave came through & I leave to-morrow morning - Frank & I went to Bailleul & had a hot bath - went back to Park & straightened up my kit -
Entry.402:
th
1918
I walked into Bailleul & caught 8 amtrain to Calais had lunch at a restaurant just outside the station & caught Paris express at 12.10 - I handed a note to an M.P. on the station at Etaples as we passed for my sister in which I said that I would hop off & see her on my way back from Paris - arrived in Paris 8.30 pm, met at station by charabanc & we were taken round to Pepinière barracks had our passes fixed up, had a good meal at Canadian Y.M.C.A & were taken by charabanc to an hotel recommended by Y.M.C.A. Hotel Prince Albert
Entry.403:
st
1918
I did'nt like too well the place I was staying & I met a couple of fellows out of 31
st
Canadian Battalion in the same way so I went with them to Hotel D'Egypte, they took a double room between them & I took a single room. They were nice rooms & nicely furnished in the most central position two hundred yards from the opera. We went & saw the Eifle Tower & went up in the great wheel in the afternoon & went to the Olimpic theatre in the evening.
Entry.404:
nd
1918
We got up at 9 am& had breakfast at our hotel. We went & saw Napoleons tomb & Hotel d'Invalides in the morning & in the afternoon to "Musée Gravin" which consists of waxwork tableaux of historical interest,cabinette fantastique,conjouring etc & Palace des Mirages - We had tea at the Soldiers & Sailors club & stayed to the concert in the evening,it was splendid & consisted of 1
st
class talent only -
Entry.405:
rd
1918
We went on Y.M.C.A excursion to Versailles at 10 am,went by train as all lorry seats were booked up,had a very good guide to take us. Thetrip cost 10 francs only which included a very good meal at a hotel in Versailles.After dinner we were taken all over the Grand Palace &

grounds, told the history of everything. We got back at 4 pm& we went to tea at a nice little restaurant where they catered only for a few regular customers, they were very nice to us however & the meals were well served by a little demoiselle named Cécille - We went to the "Nouveau cirque" Rue
Rivo
S
t
Honoré in the evening, it is a permanent circus in a big building,it was pretty good—
Entry.406:
th
1918
We got up late in the morning & had breakfast at the hotel - we had dinner atCécille's joint & in the afternoon went to Jardins des plantes. Gardens & zoo in one then to the Bastille & went through Cathedral de Notre Dame & saw Palace de Justice - We had tea at the leave club & in the evening walked around the city—
Entry.407:
th
1918
We went along to the Louvre in the morning, but the Musée did'nt open till 1 pmso we went back & had dinner atCécille's,we marked time in the afternoon & in the evening went to Casino de Paris & saw Gaby Desly & Harry Pilcer, in Suzette amongst other things,it was beautiful,stage effects were beautifully managed

& the costumes gorgeus not in colour but effect -
Entry.408:
th
1918
We stayed in bed late & went without breakfast. We went through the Louvre art Galleries (Musée) in the afternoon & in the evening we saw "Faust" at the Opera.We had the worst seat in the house I believe right behind a big pillar,but as we went there more
for
to see the building & effect than to follow the opera which we could'nt understand, we had an enjoyable evening.
Entry.409:
th
1918
Sunday -But the best times must come to an end & I woke up in the morning to find this my last day in Paris - we got up late & went without breakfast - we went to Bois de Boulogne in the afternoon the place of sunday crowds & came back down the Avenue de champs Elyssée & had supper atCécilles. We finished up on champagne & I told them that I would be down in Paris again as soon as possible & I would sure come & see them - I caught 11.40 pmtrain from Gare du Nord after a splendid holiday which I was very sorry had finished so quickly, the Canadians who were on 14 days leave saw me off & they remained as they had three more days still to go.
Entry.410:
th
1918
Arrived at Etaples 9 amwhere I got out had a wash & brush up & breakfast & walked up & saw Marion at the Hospital & as she was on duty she asked me to come back at 2 pm- I went to Paris Plage & met the sister of one of the boys of the section, as he asked me to look her up if I would be near where she was. I took her to dinner at Paris Plage & was sorry I have to say good bye so soon, but she had to get back to her place of duty & I had to go back to my sister. I met her & a friend of hers & the three of us went for a walk to a small village about five kilo's away & we had tea at a farm house (the village was Stella Plage) then we walked back to Paris Plage to the restaurant
wh
we had visited the last time I had seen my sister & we had a good supper & walked home with them & back to Etaples. By that time I was dog tired, having had no sleep much in the train & walking all day, & I tried to find a hotel or room to sleep but could'nt get in any place,at lastin desperation I went to the Y.M.C.A officers rest & got a bed for the night which I was very pleased to get into -
Entry.411:
th
1918
I got up & had breakfast & caught 8.30 amtrain to Calais, where I had dinner & caught 1.20 pmto Bailleul - (on the Paris trip a man travells in comfort on a French civilian train paying his own fare, which is quarter rate to Soldiers) had supper at Marie Louise's Joint & walked out to the park where I arrived 8 pmwhere I told of the good time I had spent in Paris & I swore that I would never go to Blighty again on leave, Paris will always do me
Entry.412:
th
1918
Talking shop again now - The lorry had'nt been out since I left, Jim went to Blighty on leave on 21
st
last night was cold but to-day is warm & the sun bright, I spent the day reading in the lorry - a 15 minute barage at night.— otherwise all quiet—
Entry.413:
st
1918
Quite a bit colder to-day. I stayed in the lorry all day & studdied French which I wanted to learn for my next leave in Paris. I wrote several letters in the evening -
Entry.414:
st
1918
Nothing doing to-day - cold misty day, had the back down all day & studdied french by artificial light & read all day—

Feb.2
nd
1918
We went out on a coal stunt at 1 pmfor 1
st
Anzac C.T.S.C. & did one load. When we returned we parked up with the amunition section in a very deep muddy position & are now attached to 1
st
A.S.P. - We have to be on parade at 7.30 am.

Memo
The weather has been colder since I returned from Paris,but not too bad & we still have quite a bit of sun. There is a bit of strafing going on at intervals again.—
Entry.415:
rd
1918
Fritz was over here three times last night & dropped some bombs, but none within two miles of us - To-day has been fine & moderately warm - I worked on the lorry in the morning. In the afternoon I went along to 5
Entry.416: A.S.P. & saw some of the fellows I know.
Entry.417:
th
1918
We went out at 10 amto draw for 1
st
Anzac C.T.S.C. I had to have a tow to start my engine - It was a beautiful day just like spring. Joe was told to be ready for his Blighty leave
Entry.419:
1918
I fixed my magneto & generally cleaned up a bit, we were warned to be ready to move out at a moments notice,in the

words to stand to till midnight for any emergency work - beautiful day - I stayed in all the evening & read -

Feb.6
Entry.420:
1918
Frank & I went up to Suzanne's in the morning to learn a little bit of French. here was a family of three Mother & two daughters aged twelve & fifteen respectively 
Suzanne &
Lucienne & Suzanne, they used to keep open house to the soldiers & sell coffee at 1dper time. They always had a warm fire & a smile for the boys & we appreciate a place to spend a few dull minutes round the home fire - Joe went to Blighty on leave. I went to Meteren in the afternoon to see Jack as it is his birthday - Coming home at night I caught up the fellows on their way home all boozed & walked with them - they had been stopped by the Military police in Bailleul but had given a good account of themselves & got away -

Feb.7
th
1918
The bunch are feeling a bit dopey after last night's jolification - Bud went to Blighty on special leave to be married - Frank came on with me as second driver as Jim is in hospital in Blighty & expects not to be back again, thinks he can work it for Aussie.
Entry.421:
th
 1918
Last night, was very warmto-day

also with a shower at intervals - Wespent most of the morning with Suzanne - In the afternoon we had a bonzer hot bath in the lorry - Lucienne went to stay for two or three days with an aunt in Neuve Eglise,she went two days ago -
Entry.423:
1918
We spent a good part of the morning & afternoon with Suzanne.Lucienne came home from Neuve Eglise in the afternoon. Fritz has been shelling Neuve Eglise a bit lately, he chased a company of R. engineers
of
out of their camp there & also put a few into the 106
th
lines - I received my first lessons in the Pelman Course & we spent the evening comfortably reading & discussing the merrits of it.

Memo
The weather for the past week has kept warm with wind from NW - W & SW winds & showers at intervals, atmosphere dull & damp - roads mostly drying - trees in good bud - crops coming up—

Feb.10
th
1918
We spent an hour up at Suzannes in the morning (Sunday).In the afternoon we went for a walk & applied the first lesson of Pelmans. In the evening we studdied French & Pelmans -
Entry.424:
th
1918
In the morning we cleaned up the buss for another inspection. In the afternoon we walked up to Neuve Eglise & back -
Entry.425:
th
1918
Joe Grim is due back from Blighty leave today - We went up to Suzanne's for our usual coffee in the morning & afternoon.Frank was on guard in the evening so I went along to 5
th
A.S.P & spent the evening with Len -
Entry.426:
th
1918
We went out to-day for 1
st
Anzac C.T.S.C. & did a lot of running about. Raining mostly all day - I was on guard in the evening, they do a dinkum guard here & sleep in the guard room. I had reliefs 5.30 pmtill 7.30 & 11.30 pmtill 1.30 am.
Entry.427:
th
1918
Weather still dull but no rain to-day. We walked to Nieppe in the afternoon (next village to Armentiéres) & had a look round the church, which was much battered,our troops occupied any shelter in the way of houses that remained fit for shelter. I wrote to Jimin Hospital in Blighty -
Entry.429:
1918
The sun came out to-day for a change. Frank & I went up to Steenwerck Station & had a hair cut,took some photos of Suzanne's family -

Feb.16
th
1918
Last night was very cold,it froze for the first time since a long time - to-day was a lovely day - a Fritz Aeroplane was
brought
forceddown between Bailleul & Meteren without a shot being fired,by one of the new Dolphin machines. The Fritz tried later to make his escape but was caught before he got to the line - We walked into Bailleul for some photographique material in the afternoon

Feb.17
th
 1918
Entry.430: -We developed the photos of Suzanne's outfit last night in the lorry & printed them to-day - they were'nt too bad. It was cold last night but a lovely day to-day - We went up to Suzanne's in the afternoon for a coffee & to show them the photos.
Entry.432:
1918
Fritz was over here last night dropping bombs, but did'nt drop any near here - We were called at 5 am& left the park at 6.15 am& carried the Chinese labour corps from their camp at Mont Noir to their work at La Flettre & back in the afternoon,they pinched our soap,we got homeat 5.30 pm, lovely day,.We had a look over the Bailleul Aerodrome during the day as we came back to Bailleul & parked there whilst the Chinese worked -

Feb.19
Entry.433:
1918
Fritz was over again last night dropping bombs. We went out on the Chinese stunt again. We stayed in Fletre for the day & took them home again in the evening,lovely day - we went up to Suzannes in the evening -
Entry.435:
1918
We stayed in to-day - Misty all day with showers. We went up to Suzannes for a while in the afternoon.

Feb.21
st
1918
On the Chino stunt again to-day - took them along the Hazebrouck road & we went to Meteren & parked with 3
rd
A.S.P. whilst waiting for them. (12
Entry.436:
brigade lorries are attached to 3
rd
A.S.P.) In the afternoon we took the chows home & returned to Park,in the evening we went up to Suzanne's - lovely night -

Feb.23
rd
1918
We took the chows to Meteren. Whilst waiting for them we celebrated the fact of Bud's marriage & return to France with champagne & wine - We went to the pictures in the evening (at our park)

Memo
The weather keeps warm, but is mostly dull with occasional showers.
Entry.438:
1918
Sunday (& incidently my birthday). We did'nt go out with the lorry to-day - Frank & I went for a walk in the morning & again in the afternoon,lovely day— We had a big argument on Patriotism in the evening.

Feb.25
th
1918
We did'nt go out with the lorry to-day the 3
rd
brigade lorries took the Chows & the drivers caused a bit of a bother with them. Frank & I were on guard at night - it was a perfect night, only one or two Fritzes were over -
Entry.439:
th
1918
We went out on the Chow job. One of our boys caused a riot withthem at dinner time & had to run for his life, they were making themselves too familiar & would'nt keep away from the lorry, so his nibs threatened them with a revolver & that was enough they got hold of anything they could lay their hands on & his nibs sought safety in flight (& the surest way with those fanatics).I was'nt there most of us went along & parked in the Place Plichon (Bailleul) & waited. I bought some new parts for my primus burner 8.francs 25c. We took the chows home early on account of the riot - we got home 2.30 pm.
Entry.441:
1918
We went for the Chows as usual & brought them within half a mile of our Park to work on a light railway which was being run into the O.X.F. Trent. Ammo dump outside Bailleul - Johnno accidently ran over a chow & killed him& they tried for his blood,he drove up to the park & got well hidden as quickly as possible & the chows followed him up, we all turned out with rifles loaded & bayonets fixed & were told to by the officer in command of the Chows if anything started we were to kill the whole lot if necessary & that the lesson would do them good. For our part we were sick of the cows & we were wishing for an openly hostile act as an excuse to get into them but they quietened down after a while &
some other
wetook them home again - they are a stupid lot of beggars—
Entry.443:
1918
We went up for the Chows, fully armed & prepared, but they were quite docile to-day - Whilst we were waiting for them we took a party of Tommies to the gas school in Caestre - got some booksfrom Pelman
Entry.444:
st
1918
We fetched the Chows & took them to Caestre & waited there for them, we got a Y.M.C.A. form & sawed it up & made some bonzer beds - We went up to

Suzannes in the evening - Sunny day with Snow squalls.
Entry.445:
nd
1918
I went out at 8 am& took a fatigue party of 45
th
Battalion up to Vierstradt. It was very cold & windy & snowed a bit in the afternoon - We slept well on our new beds last night, the night was cold.

Memo
Weather mostly cold & windy,with spells of bright sun, this week - Fritz raided our lines on Friday night whilst our 13
th
battalion was changing over but he came a thud.
Entry.446:
rd
1918
Still cold but the wind dropped towards afternoon - We cleaned the lorry in the morning & did nothing in the afternoon. In the evening we went up to Suzanne's for a while then came home & did some Pelman
Entry.447:
th
1918
We did'nt go out to day. We are said to have finished with the chows now. We went up to Suzanne's in the afternoon & took their photos to them,fairly cold all day but no wind, it rained in the evening. It looks like Japan coming into the war -
Entry.448:
th
1918
We did'nt go out again to-day, we went up to Suzanne's in the afternoon & I got Suzanne to sew some colour patches on a tunic for Joe - Frank & I went to Bailleul in the evening & saw the Sentimental Blokes at the concert hall - To-day has been fine but a bit cold.
Entry.449:
th
1918
We did'nt go out again to-day, some of the lorries went out - Frank & I got passes & went into Bailleul for a hot bath,had tea at Marie Louise's 4½ francs each & got home again 7.30 pm,lovely day. Warm
Entry.450:
th
1918
Fine day but misty. We left Park at 6.30 am& took a labour party to Neuve Eglise. Frank & I went for a walk over Messines ridge way forward of the18 pounders, it was misty & we went further than we had intended, we ran into the 18 pounder anti tank gun out on its own,on our way back. We got home at 4 pm. Jim got back from Blighty. He had been boarded for Aussie & passed & was waiting going home, he went out & got boozed & hit upa bit rough & they gavehim his khaki& sent him back to France. We went up to Suzanne's in the evening—
Entry.451:
th
1918
Fritz was over here with bombers early this morning - We took the labour corps party to work in the morning but did'nt have to wait for them. We went back to Park & cleaned the lorry - Frank & Bud walked up to the B.A.C. at Neuve Eglise for the mail in the afternoon.
Entry.452:
th
1918
We did'nt go out to-day - Last night one of the 12
th
brigade lorries had an accident at the bottom of the Bailleul hill by the Hazebrouck road. The drivers (Poor old Blue was one of them) were both killed & also the dispatch rider, whom they were trying to avoid when they ran into a tree & went over into the ditch. In the evening Frank & I went to Bailleul & saw the Smart Set at the concert hall.
Entry.453:
th
 1918
Sunday -We went to take the labour coyto work, but they did'nt want us,they dont work on Sundays - We got back & greased the lorry. Fritz put two shells into Steenwerck railhead to-day killing two diggers - our time advanced 1 hour last night -
Entry.454:
th
1918
Beautiful day. Budge came back from Paris leave last night so I spent the morning hearing his experiences - we did'nt go out to-day - I went to Steenwerck in the afternoon & bought writing pad etc.
Entry.455:
th
1918
We did'nt go out again to-day - lovely day - Joe & I walked up to 18
th
battery in the afternoon & we went to the pictures at the park in the evening - Joe got some tucker from 1
st
A.C.T.S.C.
Entry.456:
th
1918
We took an engineers party up to Wychatte (on left of Messines) & waited all day for them, we took a walk all over the joint,looked at the mine craters etc. Fritz came over & left a curious trail of smoke in his wake which stayed in the sky & did'nt lose its shape for one hour.

Mar 14
th
1918
We went to Strazeele on "roads" came back & hauled stone from Bailleul railhead to outside points. It rained all last night & this morning but cleared up in the afternoon, heavy bombardments on both sides at intervals

Mar 15
th
1918
Did'nt go out to-day. We cleaned the lorry in the morning - fine day

but windy & cold - The 1
st
A.S.P. moved out yesterday & 2
nd
D.S.C moved in. The 2
nd
D.S.C. & 4
th
A.S.P. amalgamated & we are attached to them for the present. Fritz started shelling Bailleul again.
Mar

Mar 16
th
1918
Fritz shelled Bailleul again last night - lovely day to-day - We shifted our lorries up the road a little - We are Standing to again till midnight. Joe & I went up to Suzannes for a while in the evening. I got the 5
th
lesson from Pelmans—

Memo. The M.T. Columns are amalgamated

1
st
A.S.P. with 5
th
D.S.C. to form No 1. Company

4
th
A.S.P. " 2
nd
D.S.C. to " No 2. M.T. Coy.

3
rd
A.S.P. " 3
rd
D.S.C. " " No 3. M.T. Coy

2
nd
A.S.P " 4
Entry.459:
A.S.P. " 1
st
D.S.C " " No 5. M.T. Coy

Corps troops to form No 6. M.T. Coy.
Entry.460:
th
1918
Lovely day - We did'nt go out to-day but shifted the lorries into 2
nd
D.S.C Park off the road on some runways in rows. Joe Grim came round in the afternoon & set us to work cleaning the lorries up.
Entry.461:
th
 1918
Last night was'nt so cold as usual anotherbeautiful day to-day - I cleaned the lorry up thoroughly in the morning.

Esq & Ban were examined for the Flying corps (preliminary medical exam only).
Entry.462:
th
1918
We went out on roads working from Bailleul. We parked in Place Plicton for dinner from 11 amtill 1.30 pm. Fritz was shelling just down the hill from us from 11.30 till 1.30 pm but did little damage. Raining all day.
Entry.463:
th
1918
Still raining & foggy all morning but it cleared up in the afternoon. We didn't go out to-day. I went up to Suzannes on my pat. in the afternoon to wile away an hour. We expect to hand in our Daimler lorries & have peerless lorries instead.
Entry.464:
st
1918
We had to take all our kits out of the lorries & take the lorries up to 1st A.C.P.-S.C & hand them over, fortunately the weather was fine for the job. We slept in an old hut for the night.Fritz is still shelling Bailleul. Wherever we are we can hear the report of the gun. Then for a few seconds silence then almost over head a crack or report which sounds the same as one of our guns not far away, then the shell travelling makes a frightful noise all the way to Bailleul. We then hear the explosion we have had arguments about the queer way the shells go but we can't get any light

on the matter. anyway it is a very big shell.
Entry.465:
nd
1918
The first drivers all went to Caestre where we took over Peerless lorries from 49
th
Tommy Division - we picked numbers out of a hat to see which lorry each man would have - I picked 8133 not a bad lorry but in bad condition & out of adjustment.We drove them back to our own Park & fixed up the lockers & beds etc like in the old lorries & made it comfortable. Lovely day - The 3
rd
& 12
Entry.466: brigades also changed their lorries for Peerless at the same time.
Entry.467:
rd
1918
We did'nt go out to-day - we fixed up the lorry & made several adjustments to engine etc. Joe is not sleeping on the lorry now, it is a great relief - two men are plenty on a lorry. Some of the lorries were in Bailleul to-dayFip - shifted the French post office & nearly all Civilians have left- Fritz has done a lot of damage this week with his big gun & to-day, he got the clock tower of the Maire. The gun is supposed to be a 14.2 inch - We hear rumours that Fritz is making an advance on the Somme & wiping us up -

DIARY OF THE WAR.

Great battle in France continued. Enemy attacks during the night on Noyon-Chaulnes front and endeavour to break through at junction of French and British Armies. During the day violent attacks on whole front, south of Somme ; Noyon and Roye evacuated and British forced back on both banks of river near Bray.

Turkish force, 22 miles north-west of Hit, broken up and retreat cut off by cavalry ; 5,000 prisoners with guns, etc., captured.
Entry.468:
27.—Enemy attacks in mass delivered from south of Rosières to Ablainzeville (about 30 miles). Albert taken by enemy and determined attacks made north and south of the town, and in the Ancre-Somme angle. West of Roye the French were forced back beyond Montdidier after fighting of " unheard-of-desperation."

British destroyer mined and lost with 41 lives.

Advance of British forces east of Jordan, con-verging on Amman.
Entry.469:
28.—During night severe fighting astride the Somme and in Ancre valley north of Albert, and during day on whole British line from Rosières to north-east of Arras (55 miles). Enemy attack on Arras and Vimy repulsed. Bitter fighting south of Somme. French counter-attacks east and west of Lassigny ; enemy driven northwards on 7-mile front.

Turkish forces on Euphrates pursued beyond Ana, 83 miles above Hit.

British armed steamer
Tithonous
sunk by torpedo ; 4 lives lost.
Entry.470:
29.—Heavy enemy attacks south of Somme ; British forced back to west of Hamel - Marcelave - Demuin - Mézieres. Fu-tile attempt to break through by enemy on French front from Moreuil to Lassigny (25 miles).

Paris shelled by long-range gun ; church struck during Tenebrae service. and 75 killed and 90 injured.

Colonial mounted troops at Hedjaz railway about Amman ; several miles of track, etc., destroyed.
Entry.471: 30.—Unsuccessful attacks by enemy in Somme-Ancre angle. South of Somme down to the Avre attacks and counter-attacks ; Moreuil and Demuin lost and re-taken. Attack on French from Moreuil to beyond Lassigny (about 37 miles) pressed with great weight despite slaughter exceeding anything previously known ; several villages gained by enemy west of the Avre and about Montdidier.
Entry.472:
31.—South of Somme enemy attempts to advance along the Avre and Luce valleys unsuccessful.

Recapture by French of some villages lost on
Entry.473:
Footing gained by enemy in Hangard-en-Santerre.

During 11 days of fighting, attacks by R.F.C. with bombs and machine guns on enemy troops, transport, etc. ; in air fighting during the great battle, 350 enemy machines destroyed and 189 brought down ; 137 machines lost by British.
Entry.474: 1.—Comparative quiet on battle front. Enemy casualties estimated at 300,000 ; gain of devastated territory about 1,100 square miles, some 250 square miles of it west of the line of 1914-16 ; 75,000 prisoners, 1,100 guns, 100 tanks, etc., also claimed by enemy.
Entry.475:
2.—Local fighting on West front.

General Sir Henry Rawlinson commands Fifth British Army in succession to General Gough, recalled.
Entry.476:
3.—Local encounters in France ; Ayette retaken by British.

Rheims municipality to remove to Paris.
Entry.477:
4.—Battle on West front renewed by heavy attacks on Franco-British lines between Somme and Avre Rivers ; British pressed back about Hamel and the French in the Luce-Avre angle.

British destroyer sunk by collision ; all hands lost.
Entry.478:
5.—Enemy attacks continued about Moreuil throughout the night ; ground gained at Castel. At dawn heavy attacks on British front from Bucquoy to the Somme (about 20 miles).

General Van Deventer's dispatch on East African operations to
Entry.479:
issued.

April 6.—Local encounters on British front. On French front sharp fighting in Lassigny and Noyon region.

April 7.—Local fights on West front. With-drawal by French in angle west of Chauny, south of the Oise, to straighten line. Rheims violently bombarded during night.

April 8.—Violent bombardment of French and British fronts and gas shells poured into British lines from La Bassée Canal to Armentières.

April 9.—Enemy attack on British and Portu-guese on 11-mile front from La Bassée Canal to Armentières ; Portuguese in centre forced back about 3 miles to River Lawe ; the British conforming on north flank along the Lys River, held crossings from Estaires

Bac St. Maur ; on south flank Givenchy lost but retaken with 750 German prisoners. Neuve Chapelle, Richebourg-St. Vaast, and Laventie taken by enemy, who claimed 6,000 prisoners, 100 guns, etc.

Further advance in Palestine west of the Tul Keram-Ramleh railway.

April 10.—Extension of battle of Armentières north of the town to Hollebeke (25 miles) involving Messines battleground. After crossing the Lawe at Lestrem, enemy thrown back again. Armentières evacuated and British pressed back on line of Messines Ridge and Ploegsteert. Fierce local actions on French sectors below Somme. In air fighting 35 German machines brought down and 4 British lost.

April 11.—Fierce battle round Armentières. Enemy assaults in Lawe River region repulsed. North of Estaires and at Ploeg-steert British forced back towards Bailleul. Enemy attack on Messines Ridge repulsed.

Ostend bombarded from the sea.

Turkish attacks on Palestine positions repulsed.

American ship 
Lake Moor
 torpedoed and sunk by submarine.

April 12.—Enemy attacks round Armentières pressed during night and Merville captured. During day British pressed back on Bailleul. Sixty-two German machines and 3 balloons brought down by R.A.F. and 12 British machines lost. Fifty-six tons of bombs dropped on enemy formations, etc.

Attack on England by 4 Zeppelins, one over Midlands, one near North-West Coast, and two near East Coast ; 6 killed, 15 injured.

Paris bombed by Gothas ; 26 killed, 72 injured.

Report of Justice Younger's Committee on German cruelties to prisoners published.

April 13.—Enemy who had penetrated Neuve Eglise in night ejected by counter-attack. Enemy attacks north of La Bassée Canal, round Merville and Bailleul, repulsed. Attack west of Wulverghem beaten off, and in evening fourth attack on Neuve Eglise and one on Festubert repulsed.

April 14.—Failure of four enemy assaults on Neuve Eglise in night, but during day British troops compelled to withdraw. Further attacks on Bailleul repulsed. Seven attacks round Merville and line which had bent restored.

General Foch, Commander-in-Chief of Allied armies in France.

April 15.—Enemy attack south-east of Bailleul and adjacent hills carried, British falling back to new positions north of Bailleul and Wulverghem ; occupation of the towns by the enemy.

Ten German trawlers sunk by British in 



April 16.—Capture by ene 

schaete, Spanbrockmol 

Messines Ridge. In eveni 

Wytschaete retaken by c 

British forward positions on 
 

Ridge east of Ypres withdrawn to 

in consequence of enemy progres 

Messines region.

April 17.—Intense enemy bombardment of whole Lys battle front and infantry attacks from Mieppe Wood to Wytschaete ; Meteren and Wytschaete again in enemy hands.

April 18.—Heavy bombardment of Lys battle front from Givenchy to St. Venant. Assaults on Givenchy positions and south of Kemmel repulsed. Advance by French astride the Avre on 4-mile front for about a mile, taking 650 prisoners.

April 19.—Local encounters on Lys front after severe defeat of enemy at Givenchy and ten days of continuous fighting.

April 20.—Minor enterprises on British front. American units in action in attack east of St. Mihiel.

April 21.—Local fighting about Robecq.

Shelling of Paris by long-range gun con-tinued ; total number of victims to date 118 killed and 236 injured.

Rittmeister Freiherr von Richthofen, famous German airman, killed.

April 22.—Raiding and reconnaissance encoun-ters on West front.

Guatemala at war with Central Powers.

April 22-23.—Naval raid by British on Ostend and Zeebrugge ; two obsolete British cruisers sunk at entrance of Ostend harbour, and more at entrance of Bruges Canal. 
 
to Zeebrugge mole blown up by old submarine ; storming and demolition parties landed and enemy destroyer and submarine depots and large seaplane base damaged.

April 23.—British positions improved by local operations, and some 200 German prisoners taken in Flanders.

Heavy bombardment on Somme and fronts.

April 24.—Attack in weight and aided by tanks renewed by enemy on British front south of the Somme and adjoining sectors of French front, and capture by him of village of Villers-Bretonneaux, east of Amiens;repulse elsewhere with loss.

Mar 24
th
1918
Three of our lorries went out to Neuve Eglise to be attached to 184 Tunneling Coy a tommy company with Australian tunnelers attached - Bud is in charge of us & we are expected to be away seven days. We went to Voormezeele in the afternoon. We parked at Neuve Eglise & drew our rations dry.

Mar 25
th
1918
We went to Voormezeele & S
t 
Eloy in the morning & in the afternoon we went & Strazeele railhead (Via Vieux Berquin) for a load of corrugated iron etc. We passed through Bailleul & were surprised at the damage Fritz had wrought. We got back to Park (Neuve Eglise) & unloaded before we had our tea, it rained nearly all day —

Mar 26
th
1918
Fine day but a cold wind blowing - We take it in turn to go to Kemmel for rations^ & fuel. to-day we went & in the evening took rations up to the party at Wychathe 3000 yards from Fritzes line, we were not supposed to go up till dusk, but we got there just before dusk. Fritzes observation baloons were still up, we delivered the rations at "Dud Corner".

Mar.27
th
1918
We only did one trip to-day to

Vermozeele, it was a wretched cold, bleak grey day. We heard bad news from the Somme. I had a parcel from Mary.

Mar 28
th
1918
We only did one trip again to-day to Vermozeele with R.E. stores. Cold bleak day, it rained in the evening. I wrote in the evening.

Mar 29
th
1918
Another wet day, we took R.E. stores to Vermozeele in the morning & took the relief party up in the afternoon. Our despatch rides came up with our mail & instructions in the afternoon.

Mar 30
th
1918
The morning was fine but it turned wet in the afternoon. We took a load of R.E. stores to Vermozeele in the morning, tunneling timbers etc. I made some adjustments to the lorry in the afternoon.

Memo
Very startling news from the Somme this week of a great German advance. We don't know just what to think of it from what we hear, it is said that we are drawing Fritz into a trap & will then cut him off.

Mar 31
st
 1918
Sunday.Fine day except for a few showers. We took a heavy load of R.E. Stores to spoil bank in the morning. Fritz was shelling with shrapnell & H.E. Frank & I were sick (also Budge & Tuck) from the effects of some gas we got into at Vermozeele yesterday. We had no trip on in the afternoon so worked on the lorry.

April 1
st
 1918
We took R.E. stores to spoil bank in the morning & in the afternoon took a load of troops to Poperinghe - fine day. I went to the Cemetery (new military cemetery) on the whipenhoek road & found Hec's grave. I saw the attendant & gave him 30 francs to put up a decent wooden cross, painted & inscribed, he showed me a sample one & it was very good. Went back to our park at Neuve Eglise.

April 2
nd
 1918
We went to spoil Bank with R.E. material in the morning & in the afternoon there being no run I adjusted the selector-rods. I am getting the lorry into better condition gradually. We took a walk into Neuve Eglise in the evening (we were parted about 3/4 of a mile down the Kemmel road) & watched the Aust. heavy guns being placed in position.

by the catterpillers 8" & 9.2" Howitzers.

April 3
rd
1918
We did'nt go out in the morning but went to Vermozeele at 1 pm& brought out all the Australian tunnellers attached to the company (1
st
 Division) Our troops are all on their way to the Somme & the 
men
fifth army is coming up here. They are arriving every day -In the evening Tiny came up with two lorries & relieved our three lorries &we went back to the park which is now at Meteren.

April 4
th
1918
We had to drain the gear box & thoroughly clean it, 
for
^and oninspection found two bolts of the star pinions sheared so had to take the differential out. Rainy day again.

April 5
th
1918
Joe Grim came home boozed at 1 amthis morning & had us all out to drain our radiators which we had all (but two) omitted to do. There was no danger of frost but orders were to drain and we had'nt done it - we worked on the gear box all day - rainy day - The 1st M.T. Coy are going down to the Somme to-morrow.

Joe Grimcame along in the evening

and found the sentry off his beat (he was in my lorry yarning) & put him under open arrest.

April 6
th
1918
I had to act as escort for Sid on his charge, he asked for a court martial & was remanded (asking for a court martial was only bluff & remanding was also bluff).Frank went out on Bud's lorry - we got the gear box finished & are mobile if wanted,it was fine in the morning but rained all the evening -

Memo
With the arrival of our 4
th
 Division on the Somme the Germans seem to have brought to a haltat Albert, it seems that we & the French will make a combined counter offensive all along the line -
Entry.480:
th
 1918
We 
drew
went out on supplies for the brigade as they are moving down South. We drew at Steenwerck & hauled to Strazeele & delivered to the individual batteriies - We parked in Strazeele for the night - fine day -
Entry.481:
th
1918
We started up at 10.30 am& drew at Steenwerck We made two trips as the brigade are entraining to-night.



When we had delivered the supplies we returned to our column for the night. Raining a bit all day -
Entry.482:
th
1918
Big bombardment at La Bassé in the early morning. There was a heavy mist - We started at 9 amon the road for the Somme, we went like the hammers of Hell all day & reached our destination "Allonville" (a town about seven kilo's from Amiens) at 10.15 pm we passed through the outskirts of Amiens (we got split up at Poullainville in the dark & some of us went through Amiens & the rest by a bye road - the 4
th
 M.T. Coy were parked at Poullaineville) we made a feed & went to bed, the place we parked was very muddy & it was raining when we pulled in, on the whole we made a quick & successful trip. All the lorries arrived safely.
Entry.483:
th
1918
We had to go to Longpré Sur Somme for supplies. Bob came in charge of the five lorries. We went through Amiens to Longpré les Amiens by mistake, found the mistake & went on to Longpré S. Somme Via Picquigny. When we got there we found no supplies for us We went back to Allonville Park through

Amiens arriving home 11 pmwe heard during the day that Fritz had broken through at La Bassé yesterday morning & came right through all along the line up north.
Entry.484:
th
1918
We went at noon to Amiens (S
t
 Roche) railhead for supplies & found the 1
st
 Div. on their way back up north having been down here about three days - We loaded up & hauled to Frankvillersto the brigade & got back to Park at 11.15 pm,fine day but it rained in the evening.
Entry.486:
1918
We went out at 7.15 amto Varennes stone dump (Via Querrieu) & took back a load of stone to Allonville - Had trouble with the engine & went to Park at 5 pm,fixed the engine trouble & had tea & left Park again with two other lorries at 6 pm,Eddie in charge. We were given Berteaucourt as our destination to shift a trench mortar headquarters, we were given no map reference but were shown the place on the map,just in front of Domart - We went past our guns of all sizes, & way past the French 75
s
 & right into Domart & were stopped by French infantry who were crawling about, & told to go back as we were under direct observation from the hills ahead which were in Fritze's hands,it was just

before sunset,we turned round, & went back as quick as we could, the road was under fire, & it was difficult to dodge the dead horses etc 
on
 & shell holes on the road - We went to Boves, where we were halted by the sentry as the town was being shelled. Eddie phoned up S.M.T.O. & found out that we had been given the wrong Berteaucourt. We were then directed to go to Berteaucourt les dames which was also by a Vilage of Domart, but near Vignacourt. We arrived there (after travelling all night) at 4 am.

April13
th
 1918
Had breakfast & a sleep & at 6.30 we loaded up with headquarters stuff & took it to S
t
 Roche (Amiens) Station the 1
st
 Div still entraining - We got back to Park at 12 noon had dinner & went to bed till 7.30 pm,had tea & wrote letters - We had an interesting time on the French front & were lucky to get out as we did -

Memo
The weather has been generally rainy this week with a little sun -
Entry.487:
th
1918
We left Park at 8.30 amfor Varennes stone dump & fetched a load of stone back to the Allonville 
les Alencons
 Petit Camon road where they were making an amunition dump -
Entry.488:
th
1918
We left park at 7.30 am& loaded ammo at Poulainville & took it to corps reserve dump on the 
allon
 Amiens Contay road near S
t
 Gratien. got back to park at 4.30 pm& received some letters from home & a parcel. Cold day but no rain —
Entry.489:
th
1918
We went to Flesselles amunition dump at 8.15 am& hauled to Corps reserve dump,heavy mist & cold wind all day. We heard that the Germans have captured Bailleul, & Meteren is 
the front
 no mans land.
Entry.490:
th
1918
We stayed in to-day to work on the lorry - it was a dull rainy day - I lost 15 francs at a two up school in the evening there was a very big school & up for hundreds of francs.

April18
Entry.491:
1918
Five of the lorries are out on supplies every day for the Brigade & when they have finished they return to Amiens & load up with furniture etc & haul for the civies - We got ready for the road. Cold bleak day & some rain.
Entry.492:
th
1918
Last night was very cold (a frost).Fritz came over & bombed near us,he was very low. We went out to-day on

supplies to Ailly-Sur-Somme railhead & took them to Frankvillers got home at 4 pm.
Entry.493:
th
1918
We had a hurry call at noon for three lorries & we went up to S
t
Omer - We arrived there at 7.30 pm& were parking for the night when Frank whowas at the wheel, hit the lorry in front, & broke the top of the radiator. We parked up, & Frank & I went to find the casualty park which we knew was in the town. I interviewed the Colonel in Charge, & he gave me a chit for a top off one of the radiators in the pack of disabled lorries, we went round & borrowed tools & set to work & dismantled one. I worked on the radiator, whilst Frank went round the other cars taking anything that was useful e.g. sparkplugs etc which we found hard to obtain honestly - we secured the top & carried it to our lorry -
Entry.494:
st
1918
We got up early & fixed the radiator & were finished in time to load up (Armouries workshop equipment) & we did'nt lose a minute. We had dinner in S
t
Omer & left for Vignacourt at 1 pm.On the way Sid's lorry caught fire owing to a leaky connection. I was not far behind & arrived with my

pyrine in time to help put it out, which we managed to do after a strenuous five minutes. We then had to rewire the engine & were fortunate enough to get some high tension cable from the loads we were carryinng - meantime Eddie's lorry was way ahead & we crawled in at 9 pmtowing Sid's lorry as he had not been able to start up - We threw off our loadshad supper & went to bed -

Memo 
The weather has been cold bleak & windy, regular March weather - The war prospects dont seem to improve.Fritz has got Meteren & Neuve Eglise.
Entry.495:
nd
1918
We had a good nights sleep & got up at 10 am. I rewired the engine as I had obtained some cable from the Corps Armouries work shops which we brought down from St Omer. We got back to Park at 4.30 pm,to-day has been fine, but it clouded up again in the evening -
Entry.496:
rd
1918
Went out at 5 amto Ailly - S. Somme on Supplies, 
took
made two trips to FrankVillers with oats & returned to S
t
 Roche railhead with a load of wool from Pont Noyelles. Fritz is

shelling Amiens heavily all the time now, he lobbed three all round the railhead whilst we were unloading the pieces of H.E. coming down all about us, we did'nt lose any time,we got home at 9 pm.

April24
Entry.497:
1918
Out again at 5.30 amto Ailly-S.S for Supplies for the brigade at FrankVillers - There was a big bombardement early this morning.We took another load of wool, but had to take it to Ailly.S.S. railhead as Fritz was shelling S
t
 Roche too much - We can see fresh damage done every time we pass through Amiens. Got home 8.15 pm.
Entry.498:
th
 1918
Anzac day. We stayed in to repack cylinder head water joints the 5
th
 Divy have captured a lot of prisoners etc to-day,fine warm day - it rained in the evening -
Entry.499:
th
1918
I was on picquet from 2.30 amtill 6 am. We left the park at 9.30 amfor Flesselles railhead &had to wait all day as the train was late, we got our load at 9.30 pm& took it to Corps reserve dump - got home

at 12.30 am. We spent the day playing two up & a Tommy A.S.Cman hopped in to the school & 
took
broke the school,the weather was fair -

(We are attached to the 3
rd
 M.T. Coy but although they have been amalgamated in name, they have been running seperately for work etc - we have been drawing tucker from the ammo. column - to-day the cook houses have amalgamated & there is a great improvement in the tucker)
Entry.500:
th
