1918
Fine day,we got up at 9 am,left park at 11.30 am& took small arms ammunition from Corps reserve dump to Amiens (for machine guns as anti aircraft arms) on Boulevard Alsace
 
Loraine. We got home at 4.15 pm,it rained a bit in the evening.

Blossom is coming on the fruit trees. Fritz is shelling Amiens all the time and knocking the centre of the town about badly—
Entry.501:
28
th
1918
We left park at 6.30 am& took supplies from Ailly
 
- S. Somme to Fréchencourt where the brigade have moved to - The Fritzes have taken Kemmel Hill -
Entry.502:
th
1918
We left Park 6.30 amon Supplies

Weather wet & miserable - When we got back to Park we had to move the park to Molliens-au-bois & parked down a muddy lane where as there was no place to turn & come out we had to back down, we brought our échelon of amunition from Allonville & unloaded it at the bottom of the hill -
Entry.504:
1918
We went out on supplies again at 6.30 am.Raining all day & very miserable. We call in at Madame Bully Beef's every morning & have rum & milk (hot).We got home at 4 pm.I received some letters.

May.1
st
1918
We went out on Supplies at 6.30 amto Ailly & Fréchencourt,weather still dull & cold but no rain to day - They are stopping lorry traffic on a lot of roads & making other roads for one way traffic & they made us come back home through Amiens^& Rainneville& we travelled thirty kilometres when we usually get home in six kilos. They say they are short of Petrol. It is foolish to think that the drivers will economise when they have to do foolish things like this, but it is the Army
Entry.505:
nd
1918
We stayed in all day & worked on the lorry in the morning - fine warm day - We went down to a shooting range & watched the French Chasseurs shooting. They use carbines - they told us they had just come homefrom Italy -
Entry.506:
rd
1918
We greased & cleaned up a bit, Frank & I went down on the range with our own rifles & had a shooting competition with some amunition we pinched from the échelon. We left Park at 3 pm(three lorries) for a Tommy field artillery waggon lines near Glisy. We were detailed to help them move to
Ravelcourt
Ravelincourtthey did'nt want us in the
morning
evening so we walked across to the right of Villars Brettenoux^near Cachywhere the French Colonial troops were. We watched their 75 mm. guns in action & then walked further to the support trenches & had a yarn with the Algerians. They got us down into the trench as we were too visible to Fritz on top. They made us welcome & exchanged cigarettes being very proud of their native cigarettes which we did'nt care for - We watched the shells of their 75
s
bursting in Fritzes lines
Entry.507:
th
1918
Fritz came over bombing during the night - We got up at 6.30 am& loaded up with Fodder rations & cooks furniture etc & took it to
Ravelcourt
Ravelincourt. The Q.M.S came on my lorry & brought to light some champagne & 1908 Sheblis which we all enjoyed, as was evident by the way the telephone poles went by - we got home at 6 pm.
Entry.508:
th
1918
We left the park at 5 amfor Querrieu where we picked up men of a labour battalion & took them to Bertangles - It rained most of the day - When we got back to the park we had to shift our amunition échelon back to Allonville & Park with the 3
rd
M.T. Coy. again x see
memo
.
Entry.509:
th
1918
We left the park at 9 am& went to Ferreres & picked up a load of ammo & took it to Querrieu - lovely day -
Entry.510:
th
1918
We left park at 6 amto work for 1
st
Aust. corps troops (old Anzac.C.T.S.C.) took two loads from Vignacourt railhead one to Poulainville & another to Rain^neville & got back to park at 6 pm.
Entry.511:
th
1918
Left Park at 5.30 amfor Ailly-S. Somme on supplies to the brigade at Freshencourt.Lord Strathcona's Horse, Royal Canadian Dragoons & Fort Garry Horse (Canadian Cavalry Brigade) were standing to all day expecting action, but there was nothing doing, they are camped at Fréchencourt. When we got back to Park we had to change a wheel as our tyre was done.
Entry.512:
th
1918
We left the park at 6 amfor Flesselles railhead & took Amunition to a dump at "Daours" on the Corbie road - We saw one of our planes bring a Fritz machine down over Amiens - the road was very rough.
Entry.513:
th
1918
We left Park at 8 amfor Flesselles & took a load of Amunition to Daours dump - We watched some French naval guns in Action just outside Daours.The weather is much better now but not too warm - We got back to Park at 5.30 pm.
Entry.514:
th
1918
We left park at 6 amfor Ailly-S.S. on Supplies to Fréchencourt - We brought a load of wool back to Ailly.S.S. in the afternoon - got home at 5 pm.

Memo
Fritz came over at 3 amlast Sunday5
th
with several machines & dropped bombs very close to us. We got the debris which they raised - The weather has been mostly wet this week.
Entry.515:
th
1918
Fritz came over in the early morning with several planes dropping bombs in Amiens. We went out at 6 amto Ailly-S.S. for supplies to Fréchencourt, brought back a load of wool from "Pont Noyelles to Ailly-S.S,in the afternoon returned to Amiens & took a load of wine to Belloy.Sur.Somme for a Froggy for a consideration - wet day -
Entry.516:
th
1918
Fritz came over again early this morning, there are three machine guns mounted round the park & worked by some infantry billeted here (we are parked in Hennesy's Farm yard - (of Hennesy's
Brandy
)
three star cogniac) We went out on Supplies at 6 amAilly-S.S. to Fréchencourt got home at 3.30 pm.
Entry.517:
th
1918
We left park at 5 am& picked up a load of dry goods from a store in Amiens & took it to Ailly-S.S. for the Froggies - got to the railhead a bit

late, but got round the corporal in charge with some champagne we had - We took our load out to Fréchencourt & then went for a load of firewood to Daours & came back toFréchencourt through Corbie^otherwise I had to go back through Amiens(the road direct fromFréchencourt to Daourswas a one way & held by a sentry),I souvenired a beautiful specimen of a stuffed hawk with outspread wings (just alighting) at a taxidermists^at
Fulloy
Fouilloy- We had to put on our gas respirators to go through Corbie a Fritz was sending over gas shells,a sentry there wanted to send us back through Amiens but we put up a tale & got through - delivered our load of wood & returned to Park -
Entry.518:
th
1918
We left the park at 4.15 amto shift a load for some Froggies in Amiens, on our way to Ailly-Sur-Somme on Supplies.Fritz was bombing Amiens as we went in & he had been shelling also & he got the house adjoining the place we had to go to & the people were'nt there, but we
emptied
helped ourselves to condensed milk, tinned vegetables etc. from the window of the shop also some wine from an estaminet that had been knocked, & we went to Ailly-S.S. & took our load of fodder toFréchencourt

& returning to the Froggies place in the afternoon took a load to Molliens Vidame.
Entry.519:
th
1918
We went to Ailly-Sur-Somme for supplies, but had to go on to Vignacourt for oats, we got to the brigade at 1 pm& rested there till 5 pm& returned to Park.
Entry.520:
th
1918
We left park at 5 am& took supplies from Ailly.S.Somme toFréchencourt returned to Amiens & took a load of gluecose to Saleux for a froggie, got back to Park at 7 pm. Fritz comes over every night with bombs
Entry.521:
th
1918
We left park at 7 amfor Flesselles railhead on amunition & took one load to Corps reserve dump - got back to park at 6 pm& moved the park to Belloy-Sur-Somme three kilos past Picquigny,arriving 10 pm,we unloaded our échelon of amunition & parked down the road behind the Church.
Entry.522:
th
1918
We went out on Supplies to Ailly-S.S. railhead &Fréchencourt. but they had no hay at Ailly-S.S - so we had to go to La Folie past Flex-icourt, we went toFréchencourt Via Condé la Folie, I met Eric atFréchencourt

he was with 10
th
battery - We got back to park at 7.30 pm.
Entry.523:
th
1918
We went to Ailly-S.S. for petrol & oil for the park, Doc. came with us to get it & comingback we had a few drinks of point blank. Doc & Frank had a drop too much with the result that I took the load off whilst Frank propounded to Doc on the subject of a corporal lending a hand when there was no need. We went down & had a swim in the Somme at noon, the water was cold & the stream swift -
Entry.524:
st
1918
We went out on Supplies to Ailly.S.S. &Fréchencourt. We generally stopped at Mme Bully Beef's Joint in the Boulevard in Amiens for a drink - lovely day.We had a swim down in a pool near the river it forms a backwater & was a nice depth for diving & quite big enough for a decent swim -several Fritz planes came over late in the evening with bombs & dropped them about two kilometres
nea
away.
Entry.525:
nd
1918
We went two trips to Ailly-S.S. for Petrol etc for the Park & then went to Amiens & took three loads of furniture

from a house in the place René Goblet to the Gare du Nord railway yards & loaded a truck for a French Sergeant & his wife - we had some good old wine,we got back to the Park at 5 pm& went down for a swim in the evening -
Entry.526:
rd
1918
We went to Ailly-S.S. for petrol & oil then went out for a load of wood for the cook house (scrounging) & incidently took a load of furniture to a place about eight Kilos from Picquigny, we had a lovely dinner with the Froggie at his country house - & on the way back to the park we picked up a load of light trees & were dry. We managed to drag them out of the wood & make a respectable load. We got back to park at 5 pm& went down after tea for a swim -
Entry.527:
th
1918
We went to Ailly.S.S. for Petrol & oil again & went out for another load of wood. We took another load from Amiens to the same place as yesterday & again had dinner with the French family & picked up a load of wood on our way home. We got to park at 3.30 pm& after tea went down for a swim -
Entry.528:
th
1918
We went to Ailly-S.S. for petrol & oil & then did a trip to Hangest for water with the trailer,
du
we did'nt do any job for the froggies to-day - We had a swim in the evening & rigged up a spring-board at the pool - it is very good -
Entry.529:
th
1918
We slept in till 7 am& took Ren & an escort to Bertangles for court martial for refusing to go on guard whilst we were at Allonville (he & two other men joined us there) We got back at noon & greased & oiled up in the afternoon.
Entry.530:
th
1918
We had to load up our echylon of amunition (the échelon is a reserve of ammo a full load for every lorry to be ready in case of emergency, a very fine idea but incidently the cause of a lot of trouble etc) & delivered it to a dump at Querrieu& went to Flesselles for another load which we had to keep on the lorry all night. We are supposed to have a load of ammo always on the lorry but we would so often have to unload & load it as ocasion required, that we did'nt keep to the letter of the law & we put it off at the side of the lorry & covered it against the weather -
Entry.531:
th
1918
We delivered our load of ammo.

to a dump at Blangy Tronville & went to Ialeuxrailhead & delivered a load of ammo toCorps reserve dump on the Paris road & again to railhead for a load to take back to Park - my engine started to run very stiff but I was able to get back to park alright. We saw two German tanks at the railhead which have just been captured,they are heavy & ugly looking things & dont look as efficient a weapon as ours
Entry.532:
th
1918
We put off our load of ammo & pulled into the5
th
M.T. Workshop in the square in front ofthe church We took offthe cylanders & found a big end seized up. the dowel pin had sheared & the bearing had turned covering the oil holes & causing seizure. We took the engine out of the frame & dismantled it,but left the main bearings alone. We had a parade called & were informed that "Ren" had been awarded 90 days No 2 field punishment & he went to Poullainville bird cage to do it -

The stuffed hawk that I souvenired on the 14
th
I mounted on the canopy of my lorry where it looked as though it had just
ali
landed there & it

looked perfectly natural & created quite a comotion when we went through a village & every one stared at it & pointed.I have never seen such a unique decoration on any lorry. As the lorry travelled over the road the wings flapped or quivered slightly which made it look more life like than ever - under the bird I hadthe inscription "OnLesAura" which being interpreted means"we will get them", referring to the Germans of course. It is an historic phrase from General Petain at Verdun & is used for advertising the French war loan (Comprunt)
Entry.533:
th
1918
We cleaned the engine up thoroughly & generally tightened up loose bolts etc. ASergt was put to work fitting a new bearing & taking up the other three big ends. I found the valves in terrible condition,two of them almost burned away & absolutely no seat. I got four new valves & ground them all in - We went for a swim in the evening.I received a parcel - fine day -
Entry.534:
st
1918
We worked all day cleaning the lorry as they intend to paint it - we went down for a swim in the evening - the weather is beautiful.
Entry.535:
st
1918
We worked on the cleaning process all day & in the evening went for a swim, we are making plenty of use of the springboard which works very well - Jno& I practice life saving the first time he practiced on me he put the wind right up me & I fought him & he did'nt realise that I was in earnest till we were both pretty well exhausted with struggling,then he left me alone & we went in quietly, I was more played out than he was - after that we practiced it regularly & got on very well -

Memo - The weather has been grand all this week past. Warm sunny days & cool nights - Fritz is pushing on the French front -
Entry.537:
-We worked on the lorry till 12 noon - had dinner & went down for a swim with Jno,stayed in the water two hours swimming & diving. We returned & had tea & in the eveningJnointroduced me to some French people he had got to know & he, Bluey & I took (or went with) three madamoiselles to Church & afterwards went home with them & talked till midnight.

Jue 3
rd
1918
We worked on the bus all day. Jno& I went down for a swim at noon. I had a letter from Marion in which she mentioned the Etaples bomming incident when Fritz bombed the hospitals there heavily, killing nurses & patients etc. Marion was sent to another unit in England a few days before the incident. No 1 Canadian Gen (her late unit) was one which suffered a number of casualties.
Entry.538:
th
1918
We worked on the lorry all day breaking off at noon for a swim with Jno,they are very long winded with my engine

as they have a lot of work of their own & dont want to do too much work on our lorries, they have decided to patch it up & let it go at that.Joe Grim asked me if I could keep it on the road for
fours
four months as it is & I told himyes if the radius rods were re-bushed, so I will soon be out. Jno& I went round & spent the evening with Zita improving our french & her English,we are doing well. Zita is only sixteen & was going to school in Amiens until Fritz closed the school - Marie is twenty & works on the farm. Madame their Mother works around the house & looks after the cows, milks etc. & is a very kind motherly soul - Monsieur their Father is a business man & travells around the country with a fast pony & trap buying & selling cattle—
Entry.539:
h
1918
We worked on the car all day going down for our usual swim at noon Jno& I are not able to spare the time for a swim in the evening since we go regularly to Zita's,she is very inteligent & clever, & a nice girl. Marie is too quiet & simple but also very nice. I am on guard to-night - the boys spend lots of money at the estaminets in the evening & there is much noise when the said estaminets

close at 9 pm.
Entry.540:
th
1918
We worked on the lorry (not too hard) all day - Went for our usual swim at noon - Jnowas kept working late in the evening & I went to Zita's on my pat.We are looked upon as fixtures now, not visitors. We feel very much at home & enjoy the society of a family -
Entry.541:
th
1918
Worked on the lorry as usual - Jnowas a bit crook & we did'nt go for our swim - We went to Church in the evening with Zita & Marie going home with them after & spent the evening there (it was a fête day at the Church)
Entry.542:
th
1918
Dull morning but it turned out beautiful at noon & Jno& I went for a swim. Frank was on guard last night so did'nt work this morning & I did'nt do too much either - Jno& I went as usual in the evening for our french lesson (so we called it).We learned a useful phrase with proper prononciation every day & Zita learned the English of it,a very good system & it helps out, with what one picks up in conversation -

Memo
The weather has been lovely this

week - We are getting on well with the bus & we should be out about Tuesday.The Americans are doing a bit of fighting now down South & we hear that there are a great number of them in France now -
Entry.543:
th
1918
Sunday.We started work at 8 am& knocked off at 12.30 & had dinner - I went down to the pool directly after dinner & repaired the spring board & the others came down later with a boat they brought home from the^Sommecanal at Amiens,we had a swim & took the boat back to the cache. There was a cold wind blowing - We walked to Picquigny with Zita, Marie & a friend of theirs, & went up to the old castle, bought some fruit etc. & returned to Belloy at 8 pm,stayed with them till 10 pm.
Entry.544:
th
1918
It rained a bit in the morning - we had the engine running & pretty well finished the other work,putting two re-tyred rear wheels on & one front. We did'nt go for a swim to-day as it was too cold. We attended our French lesson in the evening as usual.
Entry.545:
th
1918
Finished the job & took the bus out for a test run in the afternoon

we went to Picquigny to the canteen. We went for our French lesson in the evening & I took a letter I had written in french (to Suzanne, who with her family hadevacuated La Crêche when Fritz came through up North & they now live south of Paris) for Zita to correct for me. I was so confidant that it was pretty well correct that I told Jno I'd give him a franc for every mistake that I had made & I may say that the same letter cost me twenty francs.
Entry.546:
th
1918
We just eye-washed the lorry in the morning (washed with a mixture of petrol & oil to please the eye of the beholder, if said beholder be an officer) & rested in the afternoon,we were ready for the road. We took Zita & Marie to a concert in the evening,given by some Tommy cavalry (6
th
or 7
th
Brigade) who were camped in the neighbourhood. Jno had to leave us at 9 pmto mount the guard but returned before the end & we all went home to-gether.
Entry.547:
th
1918
We went out empty (
once again we leave an echylon of amunition behind
) & picked up a load of ammo at Saleux & took it to Querrieu,going through Amiens we cut a lot of cabbages &

onions & took them home with us to the cook house, we got home at 4.30 pm& after tea went for our French lesson.
Entry.548:
th
1918
We picked up a load of A.X. from our 
echelon
& work it to Querrieu & returned Saleux for another load which we brought back to Park, we got more vegetables in Amiens for the cook house & I also picked a beautiful bunch of roses for Zita - we spent the evening with her as usual.
Entry.549:
th
1918
We went to Querrieu with the load of ammo we slept on & returned to Saleeui for another load to take to park. We had our dinner on the boulevards of Amiens, cooking new potatoes & also rhubarb & custard. We took home more vegetables (including potatoes) to the cook house. I also took some for Zita's mother & some more roses for Zita. Amiens is the capital of Picardy & Picaroy is the rose garden of France & there are hundreds of gardens of roses which though no longer looked after still bloom in profusion & are beautiful -We are pleased to be on the road again & enjoy to the full the gardens & the life.
Entry.550:
th
1918
We took our load to Wagga dump & then went to Saleux sailhead & put on another load & got home at 1 pm. I had dinner & camouflaged the lorry a bit. Ihad a bath &we went to Church in the evening with Zita & Marie. Going home with them after service- I was on guard so had to leave at 9 pm.
Entry.551:
th
1918
We left park at 4.45 am& took our load to Daours, returning to Saleux railhead we got another loadto take back to Park, we picked as many strawberries as we could eat & took a lot home also plenty of rhubarb for the cook house & a huge bunch of beautiful roses for Zita. We spent the evening with Zita in her home as usual, Jno & I -
Entry.552:
th
1918
We dumped our load of ammo & went out on supplies to Frechencourt. On the way home we picked up a very nice girl (Gisele) & her mother at Montieres& took them to La Chausse where they were living. Jno was too busy in the evening to come to Zita's,but I was with her all the evening. Jno looked in just before bed time. Frank is on guard tonight.
Entry.553:
th
1918
We went to AillySurSomme & Fréchencourt on Supplies & on the way home picked up some stuff for Gisele & her mother at Montières & took them to La Chaussée. Their home was at Mesnil before the war (near Albert) when they had to evacuate they went to Montières just out from Amiens, since Fritz has been shelling Amiens they stay at La Chaussée, spending the day at their house at Montières & catching a lorry back to La Chaussée every evening a distance of thirteen kilometres. Frank was enoculated when we got home. We have all to be done as Spanish Flu is prevalent amongst the troops -
Entry.554:
th
1918
We went toFréchencourt on supplies again & on the way home picked up a load of furniture from a house in the Dutch quarter of Amiens of which we had been given the key, & took it to Picquigny for a Mademoiselle, & they would insist on giving us five francs each which we tried to refuse. We missed a bonzer job through it too - I picked a bunch of roses coming through Amiens for Zita. I was enoculated when we got back to Park - Jno & I spent the evening as usual.
Entry.555:
st
1918
We went out toFréchencourt with supplies & on our way home took a load of hay about three kilos past Longpré les Amiens & one of the 4
th
M.T. lorries was on the same job - We called back to Montières & picked up Mademoiselle & her Mother for La Chaussée. I had two bunches of roses to-day & gave one to Gisele & the other to Zita. The living room of Zita's house opens onto the road & always when the door is open . the scent of the roses permeates the atmosphere outside, the roses are added to every day & the wilting ones thrown out.
Entry.556:
nd
1918
We went out toFréchencourt with supplies & on the way home picked up a load of furniture & took it to Picquigny, unloading it, & carrying it past the A.P.M.S office, to the back yard,orders came out to-day that carying furniture for the civils would in future be a court martial offense - Jno & I spent the evening with Zita as usual.The weather has been rather cold with a little rain this week & we never have time for a swim now, even if the weather invited it, which it dose'nt -
Entry.557:
rd
1918
Sunday -We went toFréchencourt with supplies, we stop at La Chaussée every morning on our way to Ailly-S.S- & pick up Gisele & her mother drop themat Ailly-S.S- go to railhead for supplies & pick them up again on our way through at a café by the railroad crossing & take them on to Montières where they stay for the day & we call for them on our way home & take them back to La Chaussée It is forbidden to take Civies to-wards Amiens, but always passing the sentries we put the storm sheet up & hide them. I got a lovely bunch of roses & other flowers at the big gardens by the Canal - In the evening Jno & I went to Church with
Entry.558:
th
We we
Zita & Marie,going home with them afterwards -

June 24
th
1918
We went toFréchencourt with supplies. We stay out atFréchencourt & have a comfortable dinner & go home at our leisure, when it is warm enough we stay awhile on the boulevardes of Amiens,we always spend some time in the flower & fruit gardens & parking out at Belloy-S.S. amongst the civilians we almost forget there is a war on & we very much enjoy our privilages,not granted but taken nevertheless
Entry.559:
th
1918
We called for Gisele & her Mother on our way to Ailly-S.S- as usual & took them by stages to Montières. We delivered our load & had to go an extra trip to Vignacourt for canteen supplies for the battery. There was nothing there for them, so we returned toFréchencourt,on our way home picked up the ladies & proceeded home.I was late but they had waited for me instead of going on one of the other lorries. Jno & I spent the evening with Zita.
Entry.560:
th
1918
Gisele & her Mother stayed at La Chaussée to-day to ship their furniture from Picquigny to their
future
home for the duration of the war, at a place near Beauvais (Aise) they aregoing there to-morrow for good - they asked me to call & see them in the evening^​and Prend une tasse de café- we did our trip toFréchencourt & back & I took Gisele a bunch of roses & also Zita & in the evening I called round to say good-bye to Gisele, & they asked me if I could take them to
the
Saleux on the following morning, as they would catch a train there for Beauvais. I had been warned to stay in the park for an inspection so I told themthat I would get another lorry to stop for them

which I did - I said good-bye & they asked me to be sure to come & see them at their home if I was ever able to -
Entry.561:
th
1918
We were kept in for inspection. We cleaned up the lorry & Joe Grim inspected & passed it. I made a few adjustments. In the evening we went round to Zita's but she had just had a tooth extracted at the Cavalry field ambulance & it caused her much pain, consequently no french lesson.Ted called for Gisele & mother & took them to Amiens & put them on the Saleux road.
Entry.562:
th
1918
We left Park at 5.30 amfor supplies & had to wait at Ailly-S.S. till 10 amto draw - we took three tons of coal & several bags of oats. We made our trip & returned to Park,in the evening I was with Zita but her mouth is very sore & all the time bleeding - Jno went out with a detail of six lorries at 8.30 pmfor a night stunt.
Entry.563:
th
1918
We left Park at 9 am& drew at Ailly-S.S. at 10 am& took our load toFréchencourt.Jno was back when we got back to Park,he has been celebrating to-day & was very happy, however he was'nt too bad in the evening, which we spent with Zita.

Memo - The weather has been fine but not too warm - This dog disease, as the soldiers call the spanish flu, is going right through the army now,they have an isolation camp here.
Entry.565:
1918
Sunday -We left park at 6 am& drew supplies at Poulainville & hauled toFréchencourt getting home at 4 pm. I got cleaned up & went to Church with Jno & the girls in the evening. Bob the Sergt is crook with the flu.
Entry.566:
st
1918
Several of the boys are down with the flu,Jno amongst them,he stayed in bed most of the day. Madame, Zita's mother sent down milk & eggs to his tent during the day. We went out at 6 amto Longpré les Amiens & took a party of 182 tunneling Coy-R. engineers up to^Bois d'Aquinne nearVillers Bretonneux. Fritz was shelling the road heavily between 12 noon & 1 pmthen he put over some gas. We had to take cover under the railway bridge where the casualty clearing station was - We got back home at 5 pm. I spent the evening with Zita -
Entry.567:
nd
1918
We left park at 5 am& went to Saleux railhead for Amunition & took it to Daours dump & back again to Saleux with empty shell cases

We then went on to Flesselles railhead & drew another load of ammo^which we took to Daoursarriving home at 4 pm. Jno was better this evening but anything but well - He was up & we spent the evening with Zita.
Entry.568:
rd
1918
There was no detail in for the morning, we went out at 12 noon to Flesselles railhead & drew a load of ammo & took it to Glisey dump & loaded up with empties & took them back to Saleux railhead, & from there went straight home. I was not feeling too good all day & in the evening I went to bed instead of visiting Zita.
Entry.569:
th
1918
I was feeling too sick togo out to-day - Frank took the lorry out, & I went down to Jno's tent & went to bed. Jno was like a father to me & brought me eggs & milk from Zita's, & he would'nt let me get up in the evening when my lorry came home,he slept in my bed & I remained in his.
Entry.570:
th
1918
I was feeling much better & we left park at 6-30 am& went to Longeau for a load of stone & took it forward. I broke a driving chain & not having a spare with one, I drove home on one tightening the brake band up on the other

drum. We got a new set of chains when we got back to park & put them right on keeping our good old one as a spare - I was feeling very weak all day -

July 6
th
1918
We left park at 6.30 amfor Flesselles railhead & we took a loadof amunition to a dump atFréchencourt. & went back with empties to Saleux railhead - The roses are just about finished now but I got a beautiful bunch of lillies for Zita from a garden on the Saleux-Amiens road - Jno was busy on the old mans mower all the evening. They are preparing for haying & we are preparing for a big stunt expected to come off within the next month or so.We had heard that there would be a great demonstration by the American troops on July 4
Entry.571:
but we heard nothing beyond a local success here by the Aussies & Yanks to-gether.

The battle of Hamel is the success above referred to -
Entry.572:
th
1918
Sunday -No detail came through to-day. We cleaned the lorry in the morning & in the afternoon Blue, Jno & I went for a walk with the girls to Picquigny & then home by way of the canal foot path as far as the swimming pools, where we turned off as they

were full of swimmers. We went to Church in the evening as we usually do on Sunday,it was a lovely day & very warm -
Entry.573:
th
1918
We left the park at 10 amfor Flesselles & took a load of ammo to dump atFréchencourt, returning with empties to Saleux.We got back to park at 7 pm. Jno & I spent the evening with Zita, we are very consistant with the way we spend our evenings,& if there is less French learned than there used to be, it is because Zita is advancing so rapidly with her English, & it always leads to us speaking our own language. Jno sees her so much through the day & he always speaks English for preference, as he finds more pleasure in her bare company than interest in her language, however I keep them up to the phrase per day, if Jno does slip a bit in the prononciations -
Entry.574:
th
1918
We left the park at 7 amfor Flesselles & took a load of ammo to Daours dump & loaded up with empties & took them to Saleux railhead. We got home at 4 pm. Jno was busy in the evening & I spent the evening alone with Zita & talked to her on Religion & was very much surprised

at her broad mindedness on the subject.
& I am sure she feels the limitations of her Church which of course is R.C. I propounded some of my views to her & she was interested—

Frank was put on another lorry as first driver & Tiny came on with me as second
Entry.575:
th
1918
I was supposed to be on guard on the last shift but I did it in bed & got up & called the boys when it was time for them to get up, there being no detail in we slept till 8 am.We left park at 11 amfor Flesselles railhead,the train was late & we did'nt get our load of ammo till 5 pm& we took it to Ballarat dump (nearS
t
Gratian) We got home at 8.30 pm& looked in at the Maison before I went to bed.
Entry.576:
th
1918
No detail to-day. We cleaned up the lorry & generally tightened up bolts etc. in the morning. I received a bunch of mail in the afternoon - Jno went to Abbeville on the motor cycle on a message in the afternoon, we had a couple of very heavy showers. Jno was caught in the last one & got home wet through to the skin - We spent the evening as usual.
Entry.577:
th
 1918
We went out at 7 amto Saleux for ammunition & we had to wait at the railhead hill 10.30 amfor our load & when we did get it we only had to take it up to Wagga dump about a couple of killo's away - we had a good dinner at our leisure & returned to park at 5 pm& spent the evening as usual.
Entry.578:
th
 1918
No detail to-day. We worked on the lorry all the morning & slacked in the afternoon. Madame, Zita's mother is pretty sick to-day but will try & do her normal work. She will never give in, I think she will die working. We went round in the evening as usual. The weather has been very showery this week but very little steady rain. The country needs a bit of rain now.
Entry.579:
th
 1918
Sunday -We left the park at 7 am& went to Saleux railhead for a load of ammo & took it to Daours returning with empties to Saleux then straight home where we arrived at 4 pm. I cleaned up & walked back to Picquigny & met Jno & the girls there (Blue came with me, his girl also was there). We walked home & went to Church as usual.
Entry.580:
th
1918
We went to Saleux railhead & took a load of oats to a
dum
supply dump on the Daours road. We got home at 4 pm. We went round to the "maison" in the evening -
Entry.581:
th
1918
We were the only lorry out to-day We went to a workshop at Berteaucourt (the place we had to go to one other time when we came down to the Somme & we went to the wrong Berteaucourt) for a radiator - we came back via Flexicourt & had dinner there at the top of the hill,we got home at 2 pm. I had a letter from Gisele & answered it (in French,she dose'nt know a word of English) we spent the evening as usual.
Entry.582:
th
1918
It rained heavily during the night but was fineby day break. We left the park at 7 am& went to Wagga dump & took a load of smoke shells up toFréchencourt, we got home at 4 pm.P.M. In the evening we had a terrific rain & hail storm. All the gunners & corporals tents were blown down & flooded out.We found little Tommy struggling under the heavy wet bell tent when it was over & we extricated him. Zita's people offered to billet all the men comfortably

for the night, but they came & slept in the lorries -
Entry.583:
th
1918
We left Park at 11 amfor Flesselles railhead
in convoy
because Joe Grim was with us (we always worked individually, as a great deal more work can be done that way in a shorter time & there is less chance of traffic blocks, but it says in the books that army lorries shall move in convoy so they try & make us do it - We never do & never will). Three of us went to Daour with ammo & the rest went toQuerrieu - we got home at 5 pm.The hail last night destroyed a lot of crops in this locality, it took a belt of about one kilo on each side of Belloy & went up as far as Vignacourt -
Entry.584:
th
1918
We left Park at 11 am& went to Flesselles railhead (on our own) & took a load of ammo to Wagga dump & picked up a load of salvage amunition there & took it to the salvage ammo dump. We got back to park a 6 pm. Zita had gone into Picquigny with a married sister to do some shopping so we went in & met them arriving home at 8 pm.
Entry.585:
th
1918
We went to Wagga dump & picked up a load of ammo (the same that we dumped there last night) & took it to Glisy dump - We took a small load of stuff for some people to Saleux railway station & came back & took another small lot to Ailly-S.S- railhead on our way home - we discovered some beautiful cherry trees well loaded & we picked our fill - We spent the evening as usual with Zita.

Sunday -
Entry.586:
st
1918
We left Park at 6.30 am&
too
went to Ballarat dump & picked up a load of small arms amunition & took it to Rivery (4
th
D.G.C.) We had dinner comfortably & got back to Park at 2 pm. I cleaned myself up & Jno & I went for a walk with the girls to Picquigny & got back in time for Church in the evening - a lovely moonlight night -
Entry.587:
nd
1918
I was on guard last night from 12.10 amtill 3.20 am. Fritz came over about 3 am& dropped a few bombs near Flexicourt,Jno slept in his billet provided for him by Madame. I had no sleep at all as we were called at 4.15 am& had to leave Park at 5.15 amfor Ailly-S.S- where we picked up a load of supplies & took them to
Querrieu
Petit Camonfor the American

Machine Gun battallion just arrived back to Park at 11.45 am& greased up in the afternoon - I went to bed early in the evening -
Entry.588:
rd
1918
We left Park at 6 am& went to Saleux railhead for amunition which we took to Querrieu. We then went to Flesselles railhead for another load & took it also to Querrieu, & returned to Park at 5 pm.We had several heavy showers during the day -
Entry.589:
th
1918
We left Park at 5.45 amfor Ailly-S.& took a load of coal to 1
st
Aust Corps supply dump at Saleul - getting back to Park at 4.30 pm.We spent our evening as usual.
Entry.590:
th
1918
We left park at 6.15 amfor Ailly-S.S. & took a load of spuds to the 1
st
Aust C. supply dump at Poulainville,we got home at 4.30 one or two showers of rain only - there are rumours of a shift in three days & also great talk just now of a big stunt which is expected here shortly if the rain dose'nt interfere
Entry.591:
th
1918
We left Park at 8 amfor a dump between Flexicourt & Vignacourt & took a load of ammo toFréchencourt &

returned to the same dump for another load & took it also toFréchencourt. On the way home through Amiens we saw one of our tanks towing the German tank "MEPHISTO" captured by 26
th
Aust. Batt. We got back to Park at 7.30 pmafter covering about 95 miles to-day - we spent the evening at Zita's place as usual.
Entry.592:
th
1918
We left Park at 10.15 am& reported to 4
th
M.T. Coy at S
t
Savour, then went with some of their lorries to Flesselles railhead for a load of ammo which we took to Daours dump. & loaded up with empties & took them to Saleux - I found a few nice roses on my way through Amiens brought on by the recent rains. We got home at 7 pm,it rained all day,have heard no more about moving (it was the family who told us that we were going to shift)
Entry.593:
th
1918
We left the park at 7 amfor Flesselles where we picked up a load of ammo (the coloured battalion of British West Indians help us load from the train always at Flesselles railhead) which we took to Wagga dump - we had a good dinner on the boulevard & after dinner we picked up a load of

furniture & took it to the Gare du Nord railway yards & loaded it on a truck for a Froggy & got back to Park at 4 pmonly to hear that we were moving, so we had to load up with our echylon amunition & sundry other camp fixtures & after a lingering good-bye to the Family, left at 7 pmfor Saleux where we dumped our loads & went to bed.
Entry.594:
th
1918
We left at 7 amfor Flesselles railhead & put on a load of ammo & took it to Glisy & returned to park at 3 pm. In the evening we went for a swim in the river, but it was very cold - the weather has turned fine.
Entry.595:
th
1918
We went to Saleux railhead at 6.30 amloaded with ammo & took it to Glisy, loaded up with empties & brought them back to Saleux & returned to park. We put a new tarpaulin on the lorry, putting two extra ridge poles along the top making it more roomy inside.We pinched the new tarpaulin at Ailly-S.S. railhead a few days ago. We have to be satisfied with our own company in the evenings now & we miss our little homes. Our workshop (such as it is) has stayed behind at Belloy-S.S. for a while

& Jno has stayed with it in charge - a number of Canadian lorries "Kelly's" arrived in the evening & parked near us.
Entry.596:
st
1918
We left the park at 6 amfor Wagga dump, loaded amunition & took it to Daours dump, returning to Saleux railhd with empties & to put on another load of ammo which we took to Boves a new Canadian dump the Canadian lorries were on the same stunt - Canadian infantry(2nd & 3rd Divies)came into Saleux all day long train load after trainload the artillery also put in an appearance travelling by road, the whole corps is supposed to be on the way down for this next stunt,shortly expected. Jno came from Belloy for good.
Entry.597:
st
1918
Lovely day - We left park at 6 am& took a load of ammo from Saleux railhead toDaours dump returning with empties. We put on another load at Saleux & took it to Glisy - got home at 8 pmto find that both Tiny (my mate) & I were on guard. He took first shift & I took second. Jno secured a billet paying for it by the week. Doc went in with him - Jno pinched a bicycle & went to Belloy in the evening.
Entry.598:
nd
1918
We left park at 6.30 amfor "Bois du Garde" dump (on road from Flexicourt to Vignacourt) we went past Belloy at the bottom of the hill but I did'nt go up. We took a load of ammo to Daours dump - had a good dinner & got home at 6.30 pm. In the evening we got umpteen bottles of Banyuls (very good wine) between about six of us & made a night of it in my lorry singing & acting the nanny. Tiny's eyes shon, & we had to take bluey back to his lorry when we were through - Three infantry men who could'nt find their way home, having been in Saleux for the evening, came to the lorry before I went to sleep (about midnight) & I made them a bedon the floor & they stayed for the night. It rained most of the day - Canadians are also coming in fast at Picquigny - (4
th
Div)
Entry.599:
rd
1918
We got breakfast for our three guests & ourselves & left Park at 10.30 amand did two trips from Saleux to Glisy with ammo returning with empties - The amunition is rolling up for the offensive - I have felt no bad effects from last night. It had rained a bit during the day -
Entry.600:
th
1918
We left park at 8 am& took a load of ammo from Saleux railhead to the Canadian dump at Boves. From there we went to Poulainville & reported to an R.E. dump there,had dinner & loaded up with camouflage nets & took them to Querrieu arrived back to park at 6 pm.
Entry.601:
th
1918
We left Park at 6 amfor "Bois du Garde" dump near Flexicourt,picked up a load of ammo & went through Belloy to Glisy dump. We stayed in Belloy for about an hour and bid Bon jourà tout le monde - We were told to go back for another load but we had a bad tyre & so one of the other lorries had to make a third trip & we went back to Park - I found the two Canadians that I spent my time in Paris with last January, in the 31
st
Battalion, they were camped at Pont de Metz & were standing to expecting to go forward at any minute.
Entry.602:
th
1918
We went up to Belloy for a new tyre (5
th
M.T. Coy) & other little fixings. We worked hard all day as I want to get on the road again as soon as possible,we are expecting the big stunt to start at any time now. - After tea we cleaned up & went to see our respective families

I spent the evening with Zita. Jno arrived at 9.30 pm"en bicyclette" & went back to Park at midnight -
Entry.603:
th
1918
We worked on the lorry got our wheel on & ready for the road at 3 pm,went & reportedto get permission to return to Park & they sent a Tommy staff sergeant over to inspect the governors. They did'nt work to his satisfaction & he started monkeying with them & kept me in for the night,he broke the butterfly in the intake pipe & had to get a new one made. I went around in the evening to Zita's & spent a good evening
Entry.604:
th
1918
The stunt started this morning early - The Tommy Staff took all day fixing the governor & I left him to it, & spent the day with Zita, & as soon as the staff had finished his monkeywork & duly sealed the governor under the Captains supervision. I got ready for the road & left for Saleux at 8 pm,fine day - the stunt this morning was a great success - the boys took Ammo to Villers Bretonneux -
Entry.605:
th
1918
We went for the Park rations in the morning & I met a friend in the Canadian Light Horse which came in

yesterday & are going forward to-morrow. We left Park at 12noon for Flesselles & took a load of ammo to Villers Bret. & returned to Flesselles for another load.Jno came back with us on the second load which we took to Wagga dump - on the way to Wagga from Flesselles we pinched a big tarpaulin, it was all three of us could do to get it in the lorry, & we were only just in time getting away before the sentry came along (Jno wanted the tarp. to build a hut for the gunners) We dumped our load at Wagga & returnedto parkat 1.30 amto find that I was on guard from 3.20 amtill 6.30 am.
Entry.606:
th
1918
I went to bed when I had finished my guard & got up again at 9.30 am& went up & found Walter(Can. L.H.) & stayed with him till 12.30 pm. We left park at 5 pm& took a load of ammo to Warfusée Abancourt, five kilos past Villers Bret. Fritz came over bombing whilst wewere at Warfusée, & we all got into the ditches at the side of the road - after he hadgone by without dropping any bombs on our dump (he was'nt too faroff) we finished unloading & returned toPark, we had to pass miles & miles of cavalry going out & it was very trying work

passing them, they were all over the road & twice I was mesmerised by the strain of watching the road, was called again to consciousness just in time to save running amok, at last we passed them & got back to park shortly before 1 am(a man after doing a certain amount of driving (especially if he has'nthad as much sleep as he needs) & at night is liable to lose consciousness for the moment & if he is called out at, he will wake up & have instant presence of mind & control of the machine. I think it is mesmerism it certainly is'nt sleep - at the time a man dose'nt realise that he was'nt all there, & will go crook at a person for saying look out! but he realises afterwards & apologises to his mate for going crook.

Memo
The weather improved about the middle of the week & the advance which started on the morning of the 8
th
has been going on well,the Tommies on our left & Canadians on our right.
Entry.607:
th
1918
We left park at 7.30 amfor Vacquemont siding (Daours) & waited all day. They are starting a casualty clearing station there & the wounded were arriving all day & as they had'ntcover enough (Marquees)

for all the wounded, they had to leave a lot out in the warm sun, & they suffered with flies & thirst caused by the sun & pain - they were given water of course - We saw about 1200 Fritz prisoners being escorted back towards Amiens by a few mounted men of 13
th
Aust. Light Horse. (The Devils own)
the train came
some of us helped carry the wounded (on stretchers) who had been fixed up by the doctors, to the Red cross train at the siding,in one instance there was an Aussie we carried to the train & put him in a compartment & he asked us to fetch his mate. a Fritz,he said that the two of them had been together all the way through, sowe went back & brought along his Fritz mate & put him in the same compartment - There were four stretchers to a compartment, as it was an ordinary train fixed up as an ambulance train - Our train came in at 9.30 pm, & we had a very bad place to load from especially as it was getting dark,however we got our load & took it to Warfusée Abancourt dump & returned to park at Saleux at 4 amonly to find that we were to shift our park at 6 amso it was'nt worth going to bed
Entry.608:
th

We put on our load of echylon ammo & (I invested 25 francs in condensed milk and butter before leaving, as we did'ntexpect to be anywhere where we couldget any again for some time) & we moved off at 6 amfor Blangy Tronville where we made our camp (our camp consisted of what we called the office (the boss called it orderly room) a knock-down frame & canvas hut, about 10'x8' which accomadated a table for the boss & a table for the office rat.
Jos
Master Willietwo other knock-down huts very much the same, one was Joe Grim's (the boss) living abode & the other which was painted royal blue & we called the "blue birds inn" was the abode of Jno & Bob - then there was the big tarpaulin which we pinched at Flesselles, rigged up over a ridge pole to form a shelter for the gunners, whose numbers were gradually dwindling as they became second drivers, when a driver went to hospital etc. but the camp was never complete without the workshop, which was another tarpaulin stretched anywhere there was room (at Belloy it
was
formed a lean-to on the church & when Tommy was erecting it & he put a pole through thestained glass window of the church, the priest came out to see who was intruding & by way of explanation Tommy said "beaucoups regrets monsieur")

& contained a bench,vise etc. & the usual acumulation of junkcalled spare parts & when a man wanted a spare part, there was every other part than that he wanted - however Tommy & Earlie kept things going in that department fairly well.) I say we made our camp, the drivers part was to shift their lorries into a position assigned to them, in this case it was a blind bye road where there was very little room to manouver, & as there was very little room for passing we had to move out from the front,so the last man in would have to be first out - it did'nt make very much difference in these days, as we were all out, pretty well every day - When we got to our new camp we heated some mac
h
onochies for breakfast (I forgot to mention the cook-house,^the stoveofwhich was a hole in the floor of a ruined houseif there were any houses around & provided work for one man as cook, & a gunner to help if necessary - We each drew our own dry rations & generally had one meal per day from the cook house we were very seldom in at noon & the cook was'nt generally up in time to give us any breakfast -) & went out again to Glisy put on a load of ammo & took it to Warfusée Abancourt, loading up with empties we took them to Vacquemont & arrived back to Park at 5 pmhad tea

& went to bed. Wewere very tired as we had only spent a meagre eleven hours in bed from the morning of 9
th
Friday till the night of 12
th
Monday.
Entry.609:
th
1918
We left park at 7 amfor Vacquemont railhead drew our load of ammo off the train & took it to "Guillecourt".We saw the big eleven inch naval gun complete as it was captured from Fritz at Marcelçave, there was also a complete hospital train & a ration train captured there at the same time & train of reinforcements just escaped the Canadian Cavalry & Australian infantry captured them - We went through "La Mort en Santère" & found two Peerless lorries abandoned on the side of the road. They had been caught by shell fire & were burned & otherwise crippled. I managed to salve a radiator in good order from one & a bonnet which I needed badly for my lorry,also numerous grease cups - & I took the radiator back to Park for Fips lorry whose radiator was leaking badly - lovely day.
Entry.610:
th
1918
We left park at 9 amfor Vacquemont siding &
took a load of ammo to Vaires
had to wait for the second train & got our load of ammo & took it to Guillecourt & got back to Park at 8.30 pm.
Entry.611:
th
1918
We left park at 11.30 am& went to Petit Blangy railhead (just constructed) & took a load of ammo to Hamelet to a map reference, we found the map ref. but there was no dump there the officer had'nt arrived to say "there shall be a dump here" we were ahead of him so we waited four & a half hours & at last got our load off,we got back to park at 8 pm,lovely day -
Entry.612:
th
1918
No detail through for to-day - We are standing by - We cleaned our lorries in the morning & were swimming nearly all the afternoon in a very good pool about 150 yards from our lorries,where a seven, fourteen & twenty foot stage was erected for diving off & also a good spring board. The place had been used for aquatic sports by our boys all the summer.Tiny is on guard to-night.
Entry.613:
th
1918
We left Park at 8.30 am& went to Vacquemont siding for a load of ammo & took it to Vaires, we pulled up at Hamelet on the way back & had dinner & just got back to Park at 2.30 pm. We cleaned the lorry up a bit & had a swim - I struck guard for to-night second shift.

Memo
The weather has been fine this week. The advance stopped at the beginning of

the week & towards the end of the week our work slackened off perceptably - & we enjoyed quite a bit of swimmimg -
Entry.614:
th
1918
Sunday -We cleaned the lorry inthe morning & in the afternoon I went out with the Boss & Jno on no 47 lorry to tow in a couple of Fritz busses that we had heard about
near
betweenRosières^& Harbonnièresbut they had gone (Joe Grim was glad to get away as Fritz was shelling a bit).We saw a big petrol tractor which Fritz had left behind & also several lorries in different stages of overhaul, but none worth towing away. We went up to the Brigade to get our mail then we made for home,the Boss was driving all the time & he made an awful fist of it - We got back to park at 8.30 pm,lovely day -
Entry.615:
th
1918
We left park at 8 am& went to Glisy & picked up a load of ammo & took
it
it to Cérisy, loaded up with empties & took them back to Vacquemont siding,had dinner & returned to Park at 1.30 pm. We cleaned the lorry & had a swim.We had to clean the lorries every day after our work was done, it was merely spraying them over with a concoction of petrol & oil to make them look pretty, an officers idea of efficiency,it took about half an hour

generally & a gallon or so of petrol & a little oil.
Entry.616:
th
1918
We all went out to-gether with Remph. in charge & Doc. of course in charge of the amunition, & owing to having been given a wrong map reference,we went through Boves & Moreuil^In egières & Le Quesneltowards Montidier to get to Caix, which was our destination,we had toured all over a large piece of devastated country on the French front. No wonder they refer to us as 8/-per day tourists. We picked up a load of ammo at Caix & took it to Warfusée Abancourt & got back to park at 3.30 pm& had a swim.
Entry.617:
st
1918
We cleaned the lorry in the morning & had a swim - In the afternoon I wrote to Zita & Giselle - The 2
nd
pioneers had an aquatic carnival at our swimming pool, there were some fine swimmers. Jno went up to Belloy on his bicycle.
Entry.618:
nd
1918
We left the park at 7 am& went to Maison Blanche for a load of Ammo which we took to Céresy. Fritz was shelling near the dressing station between
Harbonières
Bayonvillers& Céresy when we passed, & they came very close to us - We pulled up at Hamelet on

our way home & had dinner & a swim, there is a beautiful lake just behind the Village & a spring board of a sort, the water was beautifully clear & deep - We got back to park 3 pm& cleaned the lorry & had a swim,had tea & another swim - later in the evening Fritz came over with bombs but he only dropped them close enough to us to make it interesting, not exciting -
Entry.619:
rd
1918
We left Park at 8 am& went to Boves an old Canadian dump, we took a load of4.5
s
to Vaires. Doc. came with us & we had dinner in Hamelet & a swim & a sun bath (I had a swim at 6.30 ambefore breakfast) We got back to Park at 3.30 pm& had a swim after tea,two or three of our boys go off the twenty foot dive, but the most I will attempt is the fourteen ft.
Entry.620:
th
1918
We left park at 7.30 am& went to Boves & took a load of ammo to Céresy.We picked up two Canadian nurses
at Vi
between Boves & Villers Bretonneux, they were out to see a bit of the country so I took them as far as Warfusée & advised them to come no further as Fritz shelled the road ocasionally, I pulled up an ambulance which was going back empty

& the nurses got in & made their way towards home. We got back to park at 4 pm. The weather has been beautiful this week & I have been enjoying as many as four swims per day. The advance after a short halt to let the Tommies on the left come on, started again & still continues, the prisoners coming in steadily.
Entry.621:
th
1918
We left park at 7 am& went to Saleux dump (past the railhead) for a load of ammo & took it up almost to Brangy sur-Somme.The roads were very dusty & the day warm but threatening rain on our way home where we found several new tins of aeroplane petrol which wecaptured. They belonged to a tank that had been hit by a shell & stopped. There were several tanks destroyed along that road mostly all burned - We got home at 7 pm,had tea & then a swim -
Entry.622:
th
1918
We went to Warvillers for a load of ammo & took it to Cérisy. There was some rain last night, & to-day
is
had beenquite cool. The advance continues & 17,000 prisoners have been brought in the last five days -
Entry.624:
1918
We left Parkat 7.30 am& went to Boves & picked up a load of ammo & took it to Vaux.Sur.Somme & had dinner there before returning to park - we got home at 5 pm. Ben borrowed a bicycle & I got Jno's & we started for Belloy after tea. We made the best time we could, but not having ridden a cycle for years I felt the strain,the distance is about 27 kilos each way - We spent the evening with the family,Ben with Marie & I with Zita & we started for Blangy Tronville again at 11 pm,it was very dark & my saddle came loose & I had no tools. I patched it up a bit at Longeau with a piece of wire

Aug.28
th
1918
I found & we got home at 2 am& had a feed & I had to go on guard at 3.30 amso it was no use going to bed. I did my guard & called the boys at 4.45 am& we left park at 5.45 for Petit Blangy railhead on the main Villers Bret road. We took a load of Ammo past Warfusée almost to La Flaque,there was a German cemetary there & we had a look round. They were mostly Fritze's graves, there were a few English & the crosses of these bore the inscription "Hier ruht in Gott" An Englander & I have seen the same inscription over any English graves where he had burried them & erected crosses - I have seen in

in other places where the Aussies have burried a Fritz a rough wooden cross with an inscription such as "Here lies a Fritz who met a Digger" the crosses that Fritz used were much superior to the ones used in our Military Cemetaries but I think that they are only temporary in ours & will be replaced with better ones after the war.

We got back to Park at 4 pm.Weather very cool.
Entry.625:
th
1918
We left Park at 7 am& went to La Flaque railhead,just opened & drew two loads of ammo to Assevillers - There were plenty of dead Fritzes laying about & a burying party composed of R.F.C. men the crew of an observation baloon near by were disposing of them,there were also a lot of dead horses laying about - fine day -
Entry.627:
1918
We left Park at noon & went to La Flaque & drew two loads of ammo

from the train to a dump nearby - we took a walk over the fields to a Fritz plane which had been shot down a couple of days previously also one of ours which was forced down (whilst we were there with bullets through the petrol tank the pilot got out (he made a bad landing on account of hitting some rough ground & he broke the under carriage & tipped the plane on its nose & broke the propellor) unhurt & put a guard (very necessary to prevent losing magneto, spark plugs & anything else useful) on & walked to an aerodrome not very far away - we also looked around at the underground amunition dump consisting of well built dug-outs with a roof of earth covered with grass, they were full of his amunition - We got back to Park at 8 pm.

Memo 
The advance is progressing favourably, it has been wonderfullyorganised for a wonder & unlike any previous stunt there has been no limited objective which so gauls the Aussies - The supreme command in charge of General Foch is proving itself,& the battle cry is now "Nach Berlin" instead of "Nach Paris".
Entry.628:
st
1918
Sunday -We left park at 7 am& went to La Flaque & took a load of ammo to Assevillers & returned to La Flaque for another load which we took to the other side of Dompiere on the Gappy - Peronne road we got back to park at 7.30 pm& were paid - I drew 40 francs.
Entry.629:
nd
1918
We left Park at 8 am& went to La Flaque for a load of ammo. We had to wait for the train which was late & did'nt get in till 3 pm. We took our load to a place near Clery-sur-somme & dumped it on a piece of ground covered with shell-holes where they made the dump, it was difficult manouvering,we got back to Blangy Tronville at 7 pm& had supper after which we had to shift camp to Chuignolles, three kilos from Cappy - we loaded up & set out in the dark on an unknown road to find a place that we had never heard of & we arrived there & dumped our load at 1 am. Some of the lorries had already arrived & others came in at intervals till 3 am.
Entry.630:
rd
1918
We left park again at 7 amfor
Chuignolles
Merignollesrailhead & got a load of ammo & took to Assevillers & got back to park at 4 pm. After tea we went

(several of us) to see the fifteen inch gun on a concrete base & worked by electricity which Fritz had destroyed & left behind him, it was about a mile from our camp & a revelation. It was built in a hollow just behind a wood & well camouflaged with nets etc & fed by a railway line,the barrel had been blown off at the
back
breach& all the base work bent about by the force of the explosion & most of the Camouflage destroyed, there was a deep covered in trench running along a bank where there were a lot of dug-outs for the crew & there was an underground ammo dump but not one shell had been found, the gun is mounted on a sliding ark with the centre of the ark (of a circle) facing Amiens & it is supposed only to have fired one shot, it must have taken a long while to construct & had been done between April & August. I had seen one of our 12' naval guns, in action, but never had I realised what a big gun was -
Entry.631:
th
1918
Only seven lorries went out to-day,the rest were standing to (We stayed in).We cleaned the lorry up a bit in the morning & in the afternoon we explored the German dug-outs etc around of

which there were many. There was a house (right where our lorries were parked) filled with boxes of broomstick bombs all detonated & the strings tied to-gether & secured to the lid. It was a booby trap but Earlie discovered it before anyone tampered with them (a good job he was early) & we took the strings off & amused ourselves practicing throwing them, we took two or three boxes of them about 1/3 of a kilo away from the park & got in a trench & threw them. They are different to our Miles bombs, in that they are made to cause a heavy explosion, the concussion of which is felt for several yards, there are practically no pieces to fly except the hollow wooden handle the rest was of a light tin construction - We also found several boxes of Fritz flares & as we had'nt a flare pistol made a contraption for firing them with two boxspanners & a base plate with a nail projecting. The flare was dropped in the first spanner like a trench mortar shell and the other spanner put over it & tapped with a hammer. We had a lot of fun until it was forbidden then we had more

Sept.5
Entry.632:
1918
We left park at 11 am& waited atMerignolles railhead nearly all day. We got our load at about 8 pm& took it to corps dump on Cappy-Herbecourt road returned to Park at 11.30 pm. It rained.
Entry.633:
th
1918
We left park at 9 amfor Merignolles railhead & took two loads of ammo to Corps dump between Cappy & Herbecourt.We went out in the evening throwing bombs & firing flares - Tiny & I are both on guard to-night - Gal under open arrest for letting off flares -
Entry.634:
th
1918
I was on guard last shift so slept in till 10 am. I wrote a letter to Gisele & gave it to Bill to post for me in Paris as he is proceeding there to-day on ten days leave. We left Park at noon for Merignolles railhead & took two loads of ammo to Corps dump between Cappy & Herbecourt. Got back to camp at 7 pm.

Memo
The advance continues & the weather is good except for a few heavy showers of rain, but no steady rain -
Entry.635:
th
1918
Sunday -We left Park at 7.30 am& went to Clèry dump & picked up a load of ammo & had orders to take it about two kilo's the other side of Peronne but when

we got there we got fresh orders to take it on to Tincourtanother seven kilo's, we returned to Cléry again & picked up another load & took it also to Tincourt- We saw several Fritzes dead on the sides of the roads & also one of our tanks out of business. We got back to Park at 9 pm.
Entry.636:
th
1918
We shifted the Park to a new camp at Bussu. I loaded the cook house & Joe Grim drove my lorry,I sitting with him. I had to get out & put chocks under the wheels whilst he changed gear down - going up the hill at Suzanne & he nearly murdered the men riding in the back when he went over bad roads,he's some driver, I don't think - however we arrived there at about 4 pm& we all helped making camp & had some tea ready when the other lorries arrived with the rest of the camp & our echylon of ammo.
Entry.637:
th
1918
We left Park at 8 amfor Marchélepot railhead. We had to go Via Cléry as the Peronne bridge was destroyed & anothertemporary bridge under construction - We had to haul some coal from the train to a dump close by - it wasraining all the time & we had to go over soft ground

with which we had troublebut we managed to unload & get out again alright & returned Via the Peronne Bridge just finished. They took off the R.E.
s
& put on a gang of Aussie engineers & they soon finished the job. There was a Peerless lorry on it's side in the river. We passed through Villers Carbonnel & all that was left of the village was
be
pavé roads with bricks scattered about the land & at the cross roads the inscription "This was Villers Carbonnel - Tiny stayed at home to-day as he was too sick to work.
Entry.638:
th
1918
We left Park at 7 amfor Marchélepot railhead & took supplies to the Brigade at Tertry (5 lorries of us) It rained nearly all day. Tiny is feeling better & came out with meto-day. We got back to Park at 5 pm. We took a walk & look around in the evening. There was a stable at the bottom of the hill with five dead horses in it & each horse had a chunk cut out of its rump & all the dead horses we see by the wayside show this same evidence of Fritz having cut his ration of meat from the beast before leaving it,the skin is peeled back & the meat cut out.We also saw a Fritz lying on a stretcher under an improvised shelter, apparently badly wounded & left there for our

boys to look after,but he was dead so we decided to bury him when we would have time. Further up the Valley was another Fritz, his face perfectly black, must have been gassed. We did'nt stay long in his vicinity as the air was'nt too pure.
Entry.640:
1918
We left Park at 6.30 amfor Marchélepot railhead & took supplies out to the Brigade at Tertry. The weather was showery - We got back to Park at 2 pm. In the afternoon we went down with shovels & buried our Fritzie taking great care how we shifted him as
cases
bodieshad been left like that
wit
attached to bombs which would explode when the body was removed. I wrote letters in the evening.

Sept.13
th
1918
We left Park at 6.30 amforMarchélepot railhead & took supplies to Brigade at Tertrygot back to Park at 3.30 pm. Fritz was over all the evening dropping bombs & one machine dropped five bombs in succession coming straight for us,had he dropped a sixth it would surely have landed on our park as they were about two hundred yardsapart & the fifth one was about two hundred

yards from us. We spent a few anxious moments, he also tried for the bridge at Peronne again but missed. He caused about fifteen casualties just up the valley from us where some of our infantry were camped. The search-lights picked up the machines quickly & one of our airmen was patrolling the sky very high & he brought down two machines in flames,it was a very pretty sight to watch & as the machines fell all their signall lights went off giving the effect of a firework display. They alsocaught five other machines in the lights at intervals through the evening but only brought the two down.
Entry.641:
th
1918
We left Park at 7 am& went to Corps dump on Cappy Herbecourt road loaded ammo & took it to Tincourt,returned for another load & took it also to Tincourt. Fritz was throwing shrap. over at noon, trying for a baloon just close to the ammo dump. We got backto park at 7.30 pm,to-day was fine & warmer - Jno has been in bed all day with rheumatism - No Fritzes came over to-night,perhaps they are assimilating last nights experience or perhaps it is too cloudy for bombing
Entry.642:
th
1918
We left Park at 7 amfor Corps dump on Cappy Herbecourt road & took a load of ammo to Tincourt & returned with a load of empties,took another load of ammo to Tincourt & returned to Park at 7 pm.Doc. comes to check the ammo at Cappy & Scotty stays the other end & we go like sixty.
Entry.643:
th
1918
We left Park at 7 amfor Merignolles railhead & took as a load 67 cases of ammo instead of 56 cases & took them to Tincourt, loaded with empties & took back to Merignolles, put on another load of 67 cases & returned to Tincourt. The roads are very rough & the distance is great,we had to go all outall day. We got back to park at 9 pm.Orders are issued that motor lorries shall not exceed six miles per hour & they are governed at 8 per & sealed - and yet they give us more work than we could do in twenty four hours per day & their speed limit - We fix up our governers (there is always a way to fix them without touching the seal) & go like the hammers of Hell. Cuddy was caught in a speed trap one day between Assevillers & La Flaque & immediately came back & warned the rest of us as to its whereabouts & so

we passed through it at about three miles per hour - (Cuddy was fined 10 days pay) We used to watch for traps & always warn every driver we passed if we knew of one. If we carried out their silly orders Fritz would still have the goods on us.
Entry.644:
th
1918
We left Park at 7 amfor Merignolles railhead & had to wait for the train which did'nt come in till 3 pm. We loaded up & took it to Hancourt returning with empties,loaded up again & took it back to Hancourt - Fritz came over bombing again & we saw another machine brought down in flames by the patroling airman.We got back to park at 1 am& I had todo a guard of three hours twenty minutes on the last shift. see memo -
Entry.646:
1918
We left park at 7 amfor Merignolles railhead & took a load of ammo to Vendelles & got back to park at 9 pm. Tiny got leave to go to Ligny Fulloy near Bapaume to try & find his brothers grave as he was killed there in 1916 - Jim came out with me

Sept.20
Entry.647:
1918
Tiny got back last night, he could'nt find his brothers grave, half the men who fell there were never buried.

We left Park at 7 am& waited for the train again.We got our load at 2 pm& took it to Vendelles & got back to Park at 7 pm.
Entry.648:
st
1918
We left Park at 7 am& went to Tincourt railhead just opened, & had to wait all day for the train. We took a walk & found a lot of mushrooms which we cooked for dinner & had a big feed of them - Fritz threw over a few shells in the evening & nearly got Doc. our ammo corpl. The first train got in at about 8 pm& we got in for our chop, & took it to Hamelete just to the right of Marbaix returned with empties & took a load from thesecond train also to Hamelete,& returned to park reaching there just after midnight.

Memo
I was on guard in the early morning of Wednesday,whenthe barrage opened up with great intensity & our troops took the last outworks etc of the Hindenburg line around Bellecourt - We are now up to the Hindenburg line all along -
Entry.650:
nd
1918
We stayed in Park all day & I made some mechanical ajustments &

cleaned up the car a bit. I fixed a petrol connection which had been leaking. Tiny is getting ready to go with a draft to Aussie 1914-1915 men. It rained in the afternoon & evening -

Sept.23
rd
1918
Tiny, Bud, Hector John & Doc left with the draft for Aussie - We left Park at 9.30 am. Ben came on with me as second driver. We went to Tincourt railhead & waited all day for the train which did'nt come in till 10 pm. We took two loads each to Hamelete. the roads were muddy & we had some trouble at the crowded dump as the ground was soft. We got back to park at 2.15 am. The 27 div of Yanks are relieving our boys & are going up in droves.
Entry.651:
th
1918
We left Park at 8 amto a place between Bussu & Tincourt where the 1
st
Div Headq
rs
were camped & we shifted the Hdqrs to Suzanne into the Chateau there We got back to Park at 5.30 pm.
Entry.652:
th
1918
We left Park at 8 am& went to a Tommy heavy Ammo dump 6 inch & 9.2 howitzer shells - We took one load to Roisel (the dump we shifted was

on the mainTincourt road between Doingt & Tincourt) & two loads of 9.2 to Villars Faucon. we got back to Park at 8 pm. We found the heavy shells very different to handle than our old eighteen pounders & 4.5
s
we lay the big ones down & roll them -
Entry.653:
th
1918
We left Park at 6.30 am& took a load of smoke shells from Tincourt railhead to Roisel & returned empty to Peronne railhead (just opened, the railway bridge has only just been reconstructed) & got a load of A.X & took them also to Roisel got back to park at 9.30 pm- it rained a little.
Entry.654:
th
1918
We left Park at 6.30 am& took a load of ammo (BX) from Moislains railhead to Villers Faucon & returned to Peronne railhead (bringing back empties from Villers Faucon to Quinconce railhead) & had to wait till 11 pmfor the train & took a load of AX Estrées-en-chaussée - on leaving the dump (in the dark) we ran along some wire laying on the ground & it caught on both rear wheels & wound round & round the brake drums etc. & the first I knew of it was that held me back, I stopped & had to jack up the wheels, borrow a pair of snips & labouriously

cut it away by the light of a side lamp. I fixed that up & was about to pull away & Frank who had just pulled into the dump found that his differential had given way & he could'nt travel so I had to wait for him to unload & towed him back to park where we arrived at 2.30 am. A Fritz was over Peronne bombing just as we left & we saw him brought down in flames.
Entry.655:
th
1918
We slept till 9 am. We are standing to in case of being wanted, anyhow I had a job. I towed Frank to the 5
th
M.T. Workshop in Peronne & on the way home picked up our Park rations got back to Park at 2 pm. We went out again at 7 pmto S
t
Denis near Mount S
t
Quentin & picked up a load of small arms amunition (Machine Gun) & took it to the 27
th
American division
at Templeux-le-Guerard
,on the road between Villers Faucon & Roisel.the ground was very slippery owing to rain & it was all we could do to get up the hill from Villers Faucon & Fritz was shelling the road also. We got our load off & returned to Park,we passed Budge in the ditch half way up the hill & asked him if he wanted help he said no, he was going to leave the lorry there till morning,which he did & rested in a dugout close by - We got back to

Park at 2 am& I found that I was on guard at 3 amlast shift.
Entry.656:
th
1918
Sunday -Foch's great push all along the line which all this last advance has supposed to be preparing for started this morning. The object is to capture the whole Hindenburg system & then proceed as fast as possible to Berlin or the end of the war. The 27
th
American division is opposed to Fritz at Bellecourt with the Aussies in support.

We picked up a load of ammo from our echylon & took it to Ronssoy & returned to Peronne railhead for another load which we took to Park & slept on for the night.John came on with me as second driver.
Entry.658:
1918
We left Park at 7.30 amwith our load & took it to 5
th
D. A. at Hangicourt & returned to Tincourt railhead for another load which we took back to Park & slept on. It rained quite a bit during the day. Fritz is retreating & Bellecourt gained. Ken picked up a discarded Triumph motor bike in the ditch & brought it back to Park to get spare parts off it for our own machine -
Entry.659:
st
1918
We left park at 8 amwith

our load & delivered it to 5
th
Don Ack backat Hargicourt, they had shifted to the other side of the village. Trying to go over a very soft place to unload where they wanted it we got stuck & had to get two of our own lorries hitched on to gether & pull me out. Then I hitched on to a Tommy also in a hole & with the help of another lorry we got him out. Fritz was dropping shells in our vicinity so we lost no unnecessary time, we unloaded. We returned to Tincourt & put on another load & got back to Park at 6 pm. The weather has turned fine,& everything is going well.
Entry.660:
nd
1918
We left Park at 8 am& delivered our load at 5
Entry.661:
D.G. at Hargicourt. Fritz was still shelling the village & also the back road at Ronssoy which way we had to go back as the traffic was too congested for us to go via Templeux. Two Americans were killed just before we passed by,some lorry got into difficulties a little further on & the whole of the traffic was stopped for about fifteen minutes giving Fritz a good chance to play havoc had he known. There were several Fritzes laying in the ditch where they fell along this road. We returned

to Tincourt railhead & picked up another load of ammo & took it back to Park.

Oct.3
rd
1918
We dumped our load at the park & left park empty at 7 amfor Tincourt where we picked up a load of ammo & delivered to 3
rd
Don Ack at S
t
Emilis. near Bony - returned to Tincourt for another load & took that to the same place & went back to Park empty. At 6 pmwe were paid in the evening. I drew 40 francs. The exchange of a franc has gone up & the£1. is now. 26.25 francs.
Entry.662:
th
1918
We left park at 7 amfor Tincourt & loaded BX & took it to Corps reserve dump at Villers Faucon (the same men are running the dumps as were at Wagga dump. We got back to Park at 5 pm. Fine day but dull & cold - The cavalry have broken through Fritzes lines yesterday & are said to be still going - Turkey has thrown in the sponge. It is the beginning of the end I think.
Entry.663:
th
1918
We left Park at 7 amfor Tincourt & loaded ammo (AX) & took it to a point on the S
t
Quentin canal between Bellecourt & Bellenglise - this canal formed the crux of the Hindenburg system.

& it ran underground from Bellicourt to Le catelet a distance of about kilos - I bought a pair of Fritz field glasses for 30 francs from a Tommy machine gunner. When the Yanks passed through Bellicourt & passed on they were taken in the rear by the Germans who had remained in the huge tunnel formed by the canal where it ran underground. They had not left sufficient moppers up as the tunnel was unsuspected by them as an ambusch,however they were hard pressed & the Aussies came in & saved the situation & extricated the Yanks from their difficulty -
Entry.664:
th
1918
We left park at 7 amfor Tincourt railhead where we picked up a load of ammo & took to the 2
nd
D.A. between Bellicourt & Bellenglise. After we had delivered our load we parked the lorry out of the way & went down to the tunnel. Fritz had bricked up the end & left a door for entrance - inside the tunnel ran the canal with a footpath right along & in the canal were barges parked in a long string. They were used by Fritz for living quarters. The whole place was bricked & fitted up with electric light fittings but, in darkness

when we were therewe used a candle. We went through a doorway in the wall & up a narrow set of stone steps to a room fitted up apparently as a cook house & it is this room which was said at the time to have been the terrible corpse factory, where Fritz boiled his dead to get the fat. I fancy what gave place to the yarn was that there were about four Fritzes found dead in the place (probably from concussion) & there was a concotion ofsome sort of soup in one of the coppers - the place stunk, but was thickly strewn with cloride of lime.
