The tunnel is said to finish at Le Catelet & to be the same allthrough, it has connections by passages & stairs to all the dugouts etc above & formed an ideal strong point & as in this instance,ambusch —we got back to Park at 6 pm. The time has been put back one hour & is now winter time.
Entry.665:
th
1918
We left Park at 7 amfor Tincourt railhead & waited till 1 pmfor the train which was'nt in then so we loaded up from the dump alongside (any ammo left over on a train was stacked by the labour corps) & took it to Roisel & returned to the railhead again & took a load from the train which had come in, in the meantime & took it also to Roisel We got back to park at 6 pm& find my Paris leave is through.
Entry.666:
th
1918
I now left this busy scene for a brief spell in the "gaie Paris" - Ken, Earlie & I left the park at 6 am"à pied" & went to the 5
th
M.T. workshops & hopped onto one of their lorries going back to Senarpont beyond Amiens (the workshop is moving back) we got to Amiens at 9.30 A.am& caught 4 pmtrain to Paris. We evaded the conducting party which would take us to the barracks to report & went by Metro straight to the Army & Navy leave club,Place de la Republique - had a feed & got rooms for the night.
Entry.667:
th
1918
We arose in the morning refreshed and at peace with the world with sufficient money at our disposal to enjoy eight days in Paris (which we made into 10 days & 12 nights by not reporting at the Barracks till the 10
th
) We went to the Monte Carlo Hotel & booked rooms,had afternoon tea at Corner of Blighty run by Miss Butler for the soldiers by voluntary contributions by said soldiers & others.
Entry.668:
th
1918
We reported to the barracks & went to pay office & drew some dough. In the afternoon we went on the Seine & Marne on the Y.M.C.A. boat trip, it was very pleasant. We went to the Casino de Paris in the evening. We saw Gaby Deslys & Harry Pilcer

in Suzette. It was beautiful.
Entry.669:
th
1918
Wet miserable day. We went to the Musée Grevin in the afternoon &
the
a theatre in the evening -
Entry.670:
th
1918
We went in the afternoon to look at a second hand car with an aquaintance who was out tobuy one - however on our reccomendation he did'nt buy this one. In the evening we went to the "Concert Mayol" with this same man & "Sa femme" the show was very good & they had a great Jaz band which played during the entre-acte. We sported a glass of champagne each & sat in the salon,watching the evolutions of the players.
Entry.671:
th
1918
We went to Hotel les Invalides in the afternoon & also on the big wheel.
Entry.674:
1918
passed without much to mention, on the evening of 16
th
we went to Luna Park & tried roller skating. I got on alright except that I couldn't stand up, but there were others in the same plight & it was very amusing.
Entry.676:
th
1918
Lille has been entered by the British troops & the Lille statue

in the place de la concorde was duly decorated by the entheusiastic population. we went down & had a look at it & the demonstration - also at the park of captured guns,aeroplanes & we saw the German tank Mephisto which I saw being towed through Amiens just after it was captured by 26
th
Battl. We had afternoon tea at "Corner of Blighty" & in the evening, my last evening in beautiful Paris,we went to Olympia theatre.
Entry.677:
th
1918
We got up at 7 am& caught the 8.25 amtrain at Gare du Nord for Amiens after a very fine holiday which baffles description here. The weather has been dull but that really cuts no ice in Paris. We got to Amiens at 11 am& spent the day trying to get out towards
Entry.678:
th
Sunday
- the line we were just about broke & when night came & we had'nt been able to find a lorry going out,instead of running the risk of getting lousy at the army rest camp & as we had'nt money for anything else we went to the railway yard & found an empty truck & the three of us laid as close together as possible & got a little sleep.

Oct.20
th
1918
Sunday -We spent a very cold night in the truck with two overcoats between the three of us & we were very pleased to see daylight - we had some biscuits with us & we went to the Y.M.C.A. for a cup of tea & caught a 3
rd
M.T. Coy lorry out to Peronne where we heard that our outfit had moved further up, but we couldn't find further particulars - We left Peronne & by several changes hopping different lorries going in our directions we at last arrived at Estrees where we saw some of our lorries & went back to Nurroy where our outfit was camped. I landed back with 1 franc in my pocket. Ken had 5 francs & Earlie nothing - We have a new O.C now - well liked.
Entry.679:
st
1918
All the Australian infantry & all the troops (except 3
rd
6
Entry.680:
& 12
th
mobile brigades of Artillery) came out ofthe line during the week ending Oct.12
th
& the mobile artl.expect to go back soon,the corps will rest.

We left park at 7 amfor Montbrehain railhead (a light railway) & drew supplies & took them to the Brigade at Busigny - we had to return for a second load which we took out to the Brigade also & returned to Park at 11 pmto find

that I was on guard last shift from 3 amto 6.30 am. Verily am I back from leave.
Entry.681:
nd
1918
Got up at 10 am& worked on the lorry all day - Cuddy's buss is to be evacuated so I took off some parts I needed & replaced them with my worn parts - Frank's lorry caught fire just after the park moved to Nurroy & burned beyond repair, he had luckily just unloaded the ammo. I wrote letters in the evening.

Oct.23
rd
1918
We got up at 6.30 am& loaded up camp equipment as we are moving to Bohain - I towed Esq's lorry also loaded to Bohain a fair sized village with inhabitants & not much knocked about.Fritz had moved out in a hurry, taking everything that he needed but not destroying anything (except roads & bridges) he took all blankets etc. from the civilians - fine day & promise of fine weather to come.
Entry.682:
th
1918
Phil went on
W.E
leave ro Blighty We left park at 8.30 am & went on Supplies, drew at Brancourt & took to Brigade at Busigny - got back to Park at 4.30 pm. Some of the lorries which had'nt been

out during the day went out on ammo at 6 pm.
Entry.683:
th
1918
Fritz shelled our possie during the night & we were ordered out of bed & told to start up & pull out onto the Brancourt Road,to avoid casualties if possible which we did. I think we could have competed with a well trained fire brigade & come off well the way we hopped into our clothes & started up. The debris was falling on our tarpaulin & we could'nt have a light as the explosians blew it out.

We left Park at 7.30 am& drew supplies at Brancourt railhead & took them to Busigny & then went on to Ezigny railhead for another load which we also delivered at Busigny. We got back to Bohain where our Park was & found that they had shifted & we could'nt find out where to, but we knew that some of our M.T. were at Brancourt so we went that way & eventually found them at midnight -
Entry.684:
th
1918
We left park at 7 amfor Ezigny & we drew supplies & took them to Bellenglise to the brigade which had moved to there & are on their way

back for a rest. We got back to Park at 9 pm.

Memo 
The weather has been fair this week but we have had quite a bit of night work & the nights are black dark & the roads none too good - All the Australian artillery started moving out from the line on Friday & Saturday - - I painted out the URA of the inscription on the front of my lorry & it now reads "OnLes a",which means we have got them - I first got the "On les Aura" from the advertising posters in Paris fora great war loan & it is an historical phrase used by General Petain (I believe) & made famous when last I was in Paris the posters had been changed to "On les a" so I had perforce to follow suite.
Entry.685:
th

Five lorries of us were detailed to go back with the Brigade to supply them. We left Park at 10 am& drew supplies at Roisel (On Sept 26
th
 At Roisel we saw the imitation tanks which had been used at that spot to put the wind up Fritz, they were made of a framework of wood on wheels & covered with cloth & painted & at a short distance looked like dinkum tanks -
men were deta
volunteers were called for from

the 4
th
Pioneers to push twenty of them to-wards Fritz's line & leave them on a ridge in his full sight,they were expected to draw the fire of the enemy & the dinkum tanks would follow, it was a hazardus business pushing them - from five to ten men on each toy - but luckily there were no casualties, when one of the boys was conducting a party of prisoners down later, he showed one of the Fritzes who spoke good English & told him these are the new British invention, bullet proof etc. & he touched the fabrique. Fritz laughed, but when he saw later one of the real tanks on the move he looked more serious).—

We took the supplies to Hamelet where the brigade rested for the night,we found lots of mushrooms & had them for supper.
Entry.686:
th
1918
We got up at 8 am& had steak & mushrooms for breakfast & left Hamelete at 9.30 amfor Peronne railhead where we drew supplies at 11 am& took to Cappy where the Brigade were to rest for the night - dumped our load & parked for the night - we had a good hot bath in the lorry

& went out & gathered more mushrooms for supper - lovely day.
Entry.687:
th
1918
We moved off at 7.30 am& drew at La Flaque & hauled to La Mott Brebiere seven kilos from Amiens which was to be the destination & resting place for the Brigade - we dumped our loads & parked for the night - we hear that Austria has chucked it in - lovely day -
Entry.688:
th
1918
We moved off at 7.30 am& drew at Bonnay close to Corbie, & hauled to La Mott to the brigade - In the afternoon we went into Amiens - lovely day.
Entry.689:
st
1918
We moved off at 7.30 am& drew at Corby railhead & delivered at La Mott.I needed a front wheel re-tyred & I went to Camon in the afternoon to try & get one from a section of 5
th
M.T. Coy which was parked at Camon, but I could'nt get it - The rest of our park are down at Senarpont with the 5
th
M.T.Coy.
Entry.690:
st
1918
We stayed in to-day imobile on account of tyre.We worked on the car. Frank came up from Senarpont
as a spare driver
on the motor cyclewith a pass to

Paris for Greenie & I asked him to hurry up my wheel, which I had sent down by 5
th
M.T. Coy section - John took over Greenies lorry & took him into Amiens in the evening to catch the train -
Entry.691:
nd
1918
I got up at 8 am& worked on the make & break of my magneto, put fresh points in etc. & cleaned the maggie up - there is no sine yet of my wheel. All the Aussies are now well out of the battle area & dont expect to go in again - Turkey & Austria are both out of it & things look good - we get the Daily mailevery day now at noon - lovely day -
Entry.692:
rd
1918
I did a bit of camouflaging on the lorry in the morning & in the afternoon we fell to discussing post war problems. Lovely day -
Entry.693:
th
1918
Austria has surrendered unconditionally.Esq.came up from Senarpont with a rear wheel for me instead of a front & had to take it back again - Jim came up with him as a spare driver & Earlie was with me temporaly whilst John is on Greenies lorry—
Entry.694:
th
1918
It rained all day. The four lorries split the fifth load up between them as I can't go out. - Gal, Jim, Harold, John & Andy & I always spend the evening to-gether in my lorry & talk.We have a bit of a feed before we go to bed,we use two primus's (or is it primi).
Entry.695:
th
1918
Rained all day again - war news is still good - two of the lorries had to go to La Flaque for oats as there were none at Corby -
Entry.696:
th
1918
8145. came up & brought me a front wheel also some mail - they left again at noon. They gave us the news of the park. Budge went on Blighty leave last night& I am nearly due - I put on the wheel & am mobile -
Entry.697:
th
1918
We drew at Corbie,one lorry (88) had to go to Longpré for Ordinance, my engine gives me lots of trouble now two cylinders have no compression at all & she knocks some, but she has done over four months work which Joe Grim asked me if she was good for - it rained a bit to-day—
Entry.699:
1918
We drew at Corbie as usual my engine gave more trouble & I have to get a tow to start every time as my starting handle broke. John went to Longpré for ordinance. There was no paper to-day for some reason.

Memo 
The news has been very exciting all this week - On Monday another big offensive started, they overlap & keep Fritz on the move. On Friday German Delegates came over & met Marshall Fock to ask for the terms of Armistice & they were given the terms & 72 hours in which to say to them Yes or No.

Nov.10
Entry.700:
1918
The Brigade has got to go forward again destination unknown to us. We drew at Corbie & I had to return to Camon with some stuff for headqrtrs. I caught up the mob at Bray sur Somme & went on to Proyart where we were to park for the night. Gal got boozed & took the wrong road & got bogged in a ditch.Eddie went along with his lorry & got him out. I got to Proyart about 8 pm,it was dark & when Eddie & Gal got backit was midnight -

Nov.11
th
1918
Official news. The Armistice

is signed & the war finishes to-day at 11 am.We are all pleased but there was not a bit of excitement - we did'nt draw to-day - One lorry went to La Flaque & John went to Amiens with the Thorny& took some officers in to get some booze for them - they said there was great excitement in town & we find out that we were brought away from La Mott just to get us away from Amiens at this time of general excitement,it may have been a wise measure,but we sure resented it.
Entry.702:
1918
We drew big loads at Corbie to avoid a double trip. Eddie only had to make two trips. My engine was knocking terribly & boiling & killed herself I got back to Proyart close to the dump & she stopped absolutely done.I unloaded & was towed into place out of the way - I took off my radiator & gave it to Gal & put his on mine,also a front spring & I took off my other front spring for Eric.

Nov.13
th
1918
I got up at 8 am& had a hot bath.John & Jim stayed in bed till noon.I went up & had a look at the church which of course was badly knocked

about as was the rest of the village. The alter had been brought from Foucaucourt in 1914 & put in Proyart church for safety, but as events^haveproven it has'nt been much safer there - I went to the top of the tower where the bell used to be but is'nt now. In the afternoon Gal & I walked over to Chuignolles & hunted dug-outs etc for pistol amunition but could'nt find any - we brought back a lot of flares. (It was Gal who was brought up on a charge of firing enemy flares etc. etc. etc. & Joe Grim tried to get him for it but Gal was a bit too smart for him,he has been referred to by Joe Grim as the bush lawyer) in a German pack as Caddy was asking for some - we threw a few bombs to amuse ourselves.
Entry.703:
th
1918
The boss came through with Blue & towed my lorry to Montières where was the 4
th
M.T.Coy. & we parked there for the night -
Entry.704:
th
1918
We left Montières at 12.30 pmfor Senarpont, Blue towing us again with 32. We arrived there at 8.30 pm& parked at 5
th
M.T. Workshop - I hopped in & got paid 60 francs.
Entry.705:
th
1918
Last night was very cold - hard frost.We were sent back again to Montières. Blue towed us back again - towing is the hardest work a lorry can do, yet they send us from pillar to post this way - We went Via Picquigny & gottoMontières at 9.30 pm(we stopped & had supper at Picquigny) & parked for the night -
Entry.706:
th
1918
Blue towed us to the 2
nd
M.T. workshop half a mile towards Amiens & as it was half holiday in the shop we did'nt start work. I wrote to the bank to get some money through for another Paris leave as I have made application for Paris leave instead of my Blighty leave which is due now—
Entry.707:
th
1918
We started work on the engine, pulled it down & found it in terrible shape two big ends gone completely brasses & all only three complete rings out of twelve,the others in pieces in the sump one piston broken etc. We did a good days work - Gal came in during the afternoon with a big end gone.
Entry.708:
th
1918
I took two
comp
big ends complete with connecting rods & pistons from

another Peerless lorry which was for evacuation & fitted them to my crank shaft. - Cuddy arrived back off Italian leave - Gal worked all day on his bearing.
Entry.709:
th
1918
We carried on with the good work all day & made good progress. I finished fitting all the big ends & got new gudgeon pins & fitted also new rings. John & I walked to Amiens in the evening & had a hair cut - the weather is very cold now & it is hard to work in the open with metal work. This work shop is a Daimler shop & they dont attempt to give us a hand. We could just as easily have done the job at Proyart if we had been able to get the parts we wanted.
Entry.710:
st
1918
We carried on & made good progress. We had got the cylanders on & practically finished the engine & the W.O. came & told us to dismantle it again that they had decided to build up the other lorry & evacuate mine - after the work I had done on itI resented that & kicked up a row & the order was again cancelled & I carried on -
Entry.711:
nd
1918
We took the front springs from the other lorry & put them on ours

& at the end of the day were almost mobile. Gal also is almost ready - We pinched a drum of metho to keep us warm at night.
Entry.712:
rd
1918
We were mobile by noon & Gal was able to swing & start his engine by hand & when he had let it run in for a little while he gave us a tow to start. She started easily & ran well. As the workshop had not helped us in anyway with our work we did'nt ask permission to take our cars out& I took a run up to Belloy & saw the old people. Zita was away at her school in Oisemont - We got back to
park at
the workshop at 6 pm& found that they had been enquiring for us all the afternoon - we had to tow a 12
th
Bgd. lorry that they had just overhauled & we towed it to Amiens & back & they could'nt get it to start - it was very unfair to make my lorry tow like that after what I had just done to it, but they were spiteful - my engine ran beautifully with just a slight knock (one can't make a silk purse out of a sow's ear).We worked 5½ days on it with interuptions & in cold weather & it was in a disgraceful state when I started so I was quite proud of my work - We parked in the workshop for night.
Entry.713:
th
1918
The 2
nd
M.T. Workshop had to move to Brancourt about 75 kilos & we were detailed to help them move & to stay with them till further orders. We did'nt like this at all,but we had to go,we left Amiens at 10.30 amwith a load consisting of the painters shop & some blacksmith stores etc & after a cold run (we stopped at Villers Carbonell for dinner) we arrived at Brancourt at 6 pm. We unloaded enough so that we could get in the lorry & sleep. Gal came through Peronne & got in a couple of hours later with his load of Motor Cycles (a light load).
Entry.714:
th
1918
The 12
th
Bgd lorry that we had towed & they could'nt start did'nt come in last night,they had a heap of trouble on the road & it did'nt arrive till to-night some of their other lorries also spent the night on the road - We started up & backed into the workshop yard & unloaded our lorry & filled up with oil & petrol & did one or two jobs on the buss - still damp & misty but not as cold as yesterday - we made ourselves comfortable in the lorry & kept the primus warm in the afternoon. Gal & Harold came in & yarned -
Entry.715:
th

We got up at 10 am& stayed in the lorry all day,wrote letters & talked - the weather was still dull & damp & the ration trains haven't turned up for two days & tucker is scarce.
Entry.716:
th
1918
We got up at 8.30 am. Nothing doing to-day, the weather is better,the sun has shown through the clouds & some rations came through.
Entry.717:
th
1918
We got up at 8 am. I had a hot bath in the lorry & washed some clothes in the morning & at 2 pmwe got orders that the workshop had to move again to La Groise (near Landrecies) weloaded up & left the park. We had to call at the 3
rd
M.T. Section in Le Cateua for some spare parts for 2
nd
M.T. workshop.We went to Le Cateau & parked there for the night, dumped enough of our load to sleep in the lorry & made ourselves as comfortable as possible - It was raining all day -
Entry.718:
th
1918
We had to go to Avesnes also for some spare parts for2
nd
M.T. workshop & we started out at 8 amfrom Le Cateau Went to Avesnes & came back to La Groise Via Landrecies - We dumped our load

where we were directed & meeting Gal there we went back to Le Cateau together & spent the night there (we had orders to return as soon as possible for another load to Brancourt).
Entry.720:
1918
We moved off at 8 am& got to Brancourt at 10 amonly to find that a mistake had been made & we were sent again to La Groise to pick up our load again & bring it back to Brancourt.We went to La Groise & loaded up & went back to Le Cateau & spent the night - I never saw more of a mess up than the last few days with the 2
nd
M.T., we were travelling over the whole country dumping, & picking up the same load for nothing & then it was mostly junk.
Entry.721:
st
1918
We got up at 7 ammoved off at 8 am& got to Brancourt at 9.30 am. (It was just along a bit from Brancourt on the main Le Cateau road that Fritz had mined the cross roads & made a big crater there, it was gradually filled up & made good again - just down the hill from this crater was a whippet tank under which a mine had exploded as it was on its way forward during the

last few days of the War & the crew were killed. This grave was alongside the tank with a Union Jack over it - towards S
t
Quentin on this same Le Cateau road a little way from the big crater, there were a lot of our own Cavalry killed at about the same time & when we first came up (when we were parked at Nurroy) the horses were still lying all over the place) & we unloaded. I ground in the intake valves of the engine & spent the rest of the day inside the lorry over a pot of metho - the day was very cold - The 2
nd
M.T. were paying so I hopped in for 40 francs.
Entry.722:
nd
1918
Got up at 9.30 am. We have no starting handle ours broke, so I went to an evacuation park at Bohain in the afternoon to try & get one off an old lorry but there were no peerless's in there. Harold went by train from Bohain to Amiens to get our mail & see if we could get back to our own mob as we did'nt like this messing about.
Entry.723:
rd
1918
Got up at 10 am& received word at 2 pmthat our own unit was at Avesnes & to report there imediately (Harold went on a wild goose chase) so we lost no

time in getting away, in case they changed their minds - We went to Le Cateau & stayed the night - (when we stayed in Le Cateau we hopped in for meals at the 3
rd
M.T. Cookhouse, they never asked any questions -
Entry.724:
th
1918
We got up at 7 am& went up to Avesnes & joined our own mob,very glad to get back,we got a starting handle & fixed it on & the engine would start with a pull up - Andy & Greenie went on Blighty leave - Earlie was overhauling the Motor Cycle & Ken started for Eu on the coast near Le Treport on a detached job (& a good one).
Entry.725:
th
1918
We got up at 9 am.Gal had left the park at 7 amfor Camon on supplies (5 of our lorries stayed at Camon with the brigade for supply work) to relieve one of the other lorries that had broken down. We went down to 5
th
 M.T. workshop with a broken spring & a bad tyre.
Entry.726:
th
 1918
Worked on spring & put on a new wheel in the morning & went back to the park after dinner - An enquiry had come in from Headqr as to what lorry 8—3. was
dong
doing

in Belloy on Nov. 23
rd
 & I had to go & see the Boss & tell him. I also told him why I had'nt asked permission & of the way we had been treated since & the abuse of transport. He sent an answer to the enquiry.
Entry.727:
th
 1918
I got up at 8 am- left John till 11 am,he was on guard last night - No detail came in to-day. We cleaned the lorry. There was a heavy mist all day but it wasn't cold. The weather is remarkable for this time of year,very heavy mists but not cold.
Entry.728:
th
 1918
Raining slightly all day, we stayed in the lorry. In the evening we played Auction bridge with Phil & Billie - no sign of the lorry that Gal went down to relieve, we are expecting it up with the mail.
Entry.729:
th
 1918
No rain to-day - I was detailed to call the cook at 6.30 amto save putting on a guard. I got up & called him then went back to bed till 9.30 am. We went for a walk round the place in the afternoon & talked with the civies about the war etc -
Entry.730:
th
 1918
We left park at 8 am- two lorries of us had to report to Signals - we loaded up with material & took it to

Sans du Nord,the other lorry went to Solre le Chateau - We got back to Park at 1 pm. - M
r
Reynolds (education officer) spoke to us in the evening on the educational scheme.
Entry.731:
th
 1918
We left Park at 7 am(four lorries) & helped shift Corps headquarters from Avesnes to Ham se Heure. We were directed wrong at Beaumont & went through Phillipville,we got there at 4 pm& unloaded. The other lorries had already left for home - we went as far as Beaumont stayed the night.
Entry.732:
th
 1918
We left Beaumont at 8 am(John driving) & close to Solre le chateau (by a lumber mill) we ran into a 1st Div. lorry, or rather just touched as we passed on the narrow bad road & the lorries locked our left front wheel with his left rear & his left front with our left rear. We backed out & extricated ourselves & pulled up to mend the damage - our only damage was steering tie rod badly bent,fender buckled & axle out of place (pushed back on front spring). I took the tie rod off & straightened it out by getting the first lorry that passed to slow

up & run over it a couple of times,fixed the other damage & returned to park. I had to put a report in about the accident & we went down to the 5
th
 M.T. Workshop & worked on the lorry all the afternoon.
Entry.733:
th
 1918
We worked on the lorry all day the shop was busy & we had to wait for the parts which required straightening etc. also had to put new springs on as centre bolt was sheared & some leaves broken. It rained all day—
Entry.734:
th
 1918
We worked on the lorry all day to get it fixed up to-day, we are shifting park to-morrow,Bill went on Blighty leave.
Entry.735:
th
 1918
We got fixed up & towed Cuddy's old lorry (ready for evacuation since Proyart & been towed round the country ever since) to our new camp at Cousolre seven kilo's from Beaumont on the Maubeuge road - the gear lever broke off at the gate when we were four kilo's from our destination & I had to leave the lorry I was towing as I couldn't change gear & I went to Park on second gear. The long expected lorry came up from Camon with mail etc.
Entry.736:
th
 1918
Took off broken lever etc & did a bit of work on the buss, but could'nt get a replacement. We had to fill in demobilisation forms - Cuddy's buss was brought in to park.
Entry.737:
th
 1918
Worked on the car all the morning & did nothing in the afternoon - Casserole came in during the afternoon his buss was crook. The brigade is on the road up & he left them at Sivry & they go on to Bussu les Walcourt on the Phillipville road to-morrow. Casseroles & Whites passes are through for Blighty & they left for Blighty -
Entry.738:
th
 1918
We got up early & fixed a new gear lever on & left Park at 10 amfor Beaumont railhead in place of Casseroles lorry - once more to draw supplies for the brigade with the four other lorries which I met at Beaumont.We waited at the railhead all day for the train which did'nt come in till midnight then we took it to Bussu les Walcourt to the brigade & parked there till morning.
Entry.739:
th
 1918
We got up at9 am& went to Beaumont Railhead. We waited

all day for the train again but it did'nt come in,so we went to bed - raining all day.
Entry.740:
th
 1918
We got up at 10 am& had breakfast. The train came in at 11 am. We put on a load of hay & delivered it & had to return to the railhead to wait for the next train which also was overdue.I took "Master Willlie" back to the park at Cousolre (he had come out with mail) & returned to Beaumont rhd. I had obtained a new pair of boots from the Q.M. of 106
th
 bat. as mine were worn out. No word of the train & we went to bed.
Entry.741:
st
 1918
We got up at 9 am& waited all day for the train. It came in at 5 pm& we loaded up & delivered to brigade & returned to Railhead to park for the night & wait for the next train - "Master Willlie" got his special leave to Blighty & went on leave.
Entry.742:
nd
 1918
Sunday -We got up at 6.30 am. The train was in & we got our first load (the other train was expected in) at 8 am& delivered it & returned to railhead. We got our second load at 6 pm& delivered & returned to railhead. It was raining

hard & we got soaked & muddy. We broke our starting handle again (the bearing is worn).
Entry.743:
rd
 1918
We got up at 11.30 am. There is no train expected in to-day - we did one or two necessary jobs & filled up. We had some bonzer meals. (we live well on this supply job) Tuck came in & ate with us & we yarned. I wrote some letters in the evening -
Entry.744:
th
1918

We got up at 6 amas train was reported & we waited all day expecting it every minute. It came in at 7 pm, & we got our load at 8 pm& delivered to the brigade & arrived back at the park (the five lorries are parking now just outside Beaumont on the Phillipville road by the railway bridge (Fritz was preparing to destroy this bridge in his retreat) so as to be near the railhead) at midnight -
Entry.745:
th
 1918
Xmas day - We got up at 10 am. The train came in & we got our load at 2 pm& delivered to the brigade. We had our Xmas dinner in the evening in the home of a Belgian family, they had cooked & prepared it for us out of stuff we gave

them amongst which was a turkey that the Brigade gave us - I also fetched them a few bags of coal from the railhead which was like diamonds to them it is so scarce. We also had a jar of rum that Cuddy had pinched at the railhead (he had got a new lorry in place of his old one,or rather an overhauled one from the base).
Entry.746:
th

Two trains came in to-day so we had to do twoloads - we caught up on the day lost & got back to park at midnight. I got another starting handle -
Entry.747:
th

We slept in till noon & went down to the railhead at 3 pmbut the train did'nt come in^till late- the 3
rd
M.T.Coy lorries turned up & waited but in the evening they told their officer that they would'nt be fooled about like this & they returned to their park at 10 pmat Solre le Chateau.
Entry.748:
th

We slept at the railhead last night & we drew to-day atthe Anzac corps dump in Beaumont (they had a dance last night that is why they did'nt turn up to clear the train when it came in - they cleared it after & we drew at their dump) & delivered to Brigade. We had some snow this week & there

was snow on the ground for Christmas but it wasn't cold -
Entry.749:
th
 1918
We got up at 9.30 am& went to railhead & hopped in for our loads & delivered them & returned to our little park & played cards with Tuck & Wilson - We yarned all the evening.
Entry.750:
th
 1918
We got up at 9.30 am& went down to railhead & got our loads, delivered to brigade & returned to our little Park. Eddie came along to relieve my lorry & I returned to Park at Cousolre.
Entry.751:
1918
We cleaned the lorry with the help of a couple of French kids who voluntarily attached themselves for duty. All the kids in the Village seemed to chum up with the boys & they told us all kinds of things about Fritz troops.They did'nt like them at all & shunned them absolutely. They had to salute all officers or be gaoled for two days if they did'nt - etc. etc. We went to bed at 10 pm.It was a very quiet new Year only motor horns etc sounding & a few of the boys who had been drinking made a bit of noise.Thus ends another Year, the beginning of which was

not too hopeful, in fact things were very wonky in March & April - there was a great deal of work all the summer & as soon as the armistice was signed the bottom seemed to drop out of everything, the lorries which had done such good work all seemed to know that the war was finished & konked out. every one was discontented & everything seemed to be disorganised -

1919
Entry.752:
st
 
1919
We got up at 10 am& spent the rest of the morning at the hotel across at the corner & had some coffee & talked to Madame. There is nothing doing to-day it is being kept as a holiday - I went for a walk with Odon (one of the kids who come into the lorry & talk to us) in the afternoon.Cousolre was a great marble working place this part of France & Belgium was one of the wealthiest parts. It is full of factories of different kinds & if Fritz culdnt take away all the machinery etc. he destroyed what he left.
Entry.753:
nd
 1919
We got up at 10 am& went to Solre le Chateau with the lorry for some parts for the motor cycle. The Sergt came with us. We got back to park at 2 pm. Eddie came in from Beaumont

with ignition trouble.
Entry.754:
rd
 1919
We got up at 9 am. John went to help Tommy in the workshop with Casseroles buss which he is overhauling. I cleaned the lorry in the morning. Eddie went out again to the brigade, I wrote letters in the evening -
Entry.755:
th
1919
I did nothing to-day. I wrote a couple of letters - John is working with Tommy. In the evening I went over to Madames, there were three French officers there & some of our boys. We had some dancing -
Entry.756:
th
 1919Sunday - 
We got up at 11 am,nothing doing - Frank & I went down to the next village for a walk & to try & buy a writing pad, but could'nt get any. I read "Pratts Patients" a very amusing book -
Entry.757:
th
 1919
I started up the engine to warm it up & then took the old oil out of the crank case, cleaned the sump & put in fresh oil. Frank & I have been talking of having a trip over America in a car after the war -
Entry.759:
1919
We got up at 10 am.My pass was through for Paris with four others - & Lansdowne's & Tommy's were through for Blighty - I went up to the brigade to see Gal about the trip & discus a little scheme (Gal. Jim. Bob & Rem. were the others for Paris) We went back to the Park & got ourselves ready. We went to Beaumont hoping to get a lorry to Solre le Chateau - Bob was on a job so we left word that the rest of us had gone on - Lansdowne was coming with us to Amiens & meet Tommy (he had a seat in a box car leaving for Amiens next day) there the following afternoon - so Gal, Jim, Lansdowne started walking to Amiens at 7 pmhoping to improve our method of travel before we had gone too far. We had to walk twelve kilo's & were pretty tired by the time we came across what we were looking for. We waited till 1 am& had a trip to Amiens in a Box Car. We drove all night & got to Amiens at 7 am.We had breakfast & a wash & clean up & had a look at the town, the population are coming back fast & the place is cleaned up very much since I last saw it. We had dinner in Amiens & I left the others. I caught the 4 pmtrain to Paris (Gal & Jim wanted to

spend the night in Amiens & come to Paris the following day) I arrived in Paris at 8 pm& got a room at the MonteCarlo Hotel. I did'nt report to the barracks. (I am on 14 days leave in lieu of Blighty)

Jan9
Entry.760:
1919
I got up at 9 am& went up to the club for a hot bath then I walked about the streets to get my locality & in the afternoon I met the train but somehow missed the boys,but met them later at the Club & we went together to the Alambia theatre -
Entry.762:
1919
I got up at 10 am& took a room at Hotel Central, Cité Bergere as Gal & Jim had booked their rooms there. Everything has gone up very much since I was last in Paris - Hotel acomodation has gone up about 75%. We knocked round the boulevards all day doing nothing special & in the evening went to Casino de Paris
Entry.764:
1919
I went to the club in the morning for a hot bath -

Jan.13
th
 1919
We went up to the pay office in the afternoon & met Bob up there. He arrived in Paris last night after spending two days in Bruxelles on his way down.
Entry.767:
th
 1919
I went up to "Au Printemps Magazin & bought six yards of crêpe de chine at 30 francs per yard for John & I had it sent through to his Mother.
Entry.768:
th
 1919
We went up to the Sacré Cœur de Montmatre in the afternoon - Jim & Gal caught the night train back to Amiens as they were only on eight days leave & had'nt sufficient money to stay A.W.L., they intend to stay a day or so in Amiens -
Entry.769:
1919
Bob & I had dinner together & we went to the Olympia theatre in the evening - I sent a telegram to Gisele that I would catch to-morrow mornings train to Beauvais -
Entry.770:
th
 1919
Sunday - Bob caught the morning train back to Amiens. I missed the Beauvais train & sent another telegram to Gisele.

Jan.20
Entry.771:
1919
I caught the 7.10 amtrain to Beauvais & got off at Méru as I was advised that it was nearer to La Houssoye than was Beauvais

I sent a telephone message to the Post office at La Houssoye that I had arrived & at noon Madame A arrived with an automobile to take me home with them. They had received my message without delay - Gisele had gone to Beauvais to meet me with the horse & trap - Beauvais was 16 kilos & Méru about the same, they made me very much at home & were genuinely glad to see me. They were sorry that I could only stay four days with them -
Entry.772:
st
 1919
I got up at 10.30 am& had breakfast. Gisele's sister was attending to a bicycle & on looking at it I found one or two things wrong with it & it ended in me taking it all to pieces & finding some ball bearings broken etc. I had a quiet day but very enjoyable & got on well with my french. none of them understand a word of English.
Entry.773:
nd
 1919
Gisele & I went to Gisors with Monsieur her father "en voiture" had dinner there & got some balls for the cycle & other things & returned home. Gisors is about 14 kilos from La Houssoye.
Entry.774:
rd
 1919
I fixed up the cycle in the morning & we went for a walk to La Bosse station in the afternoon. In the evening we talked & sung. I learned some french songs that I had brought from Paris "Quand Madelon" "Crie du Poilu" &
"nos Poilus
"Pour nos Poilus" etc. My leave finishes to-day -
Entry.775:
th
 1919
I got up at 8 am& Gisele & her Mother drove me to Gisors & I caught the 11.20. train, said good-bye to my kind friends & promised if possible to visit them again some time - I reached Paris at 2.30 pm& went to the club for a hot bath - I bought an "Onoto" fountain pen & sent it to Gisele (30 francs) - I met Len from 5
th
 M.T.Coy, he was A.W.L. having a fly round Paris for four or five days -
Entry.776:
th
 1919
I stayed around Paris all day,did nothing special -
Entry.777:
th
 1919
I got up early & went to the station to catch the 8 amtrain but there was no room & I could'nt do anything else than buy a ticket for the next day,the tickets were numbered & reserved only a certain number sold for each days train. I went out to St Mande

in the afternoon saw the Fort at Vincennes
Entry.778:
th
1919
I caught 7.30 amtrain to Bruxelles, Via Lille - we arrived at Lille at 3 pm,the train was very crowded already & more passengers got in at Lille. We left for Lille & travelled very slowly & stopped often before we reached Bruxelles at 1 am. I went down town & had a feed of fried
Che
"Cheval" & chips (called steak & chips) & went to the Y.M.C.A building & lay on a big table till

Jan.28
th
1919
5.30 am. The building was full of all kinds of soldiers resting in all positions on the floor, in chairs, on tables - I walked up toward the station & had a piece of bread & butter & cup of very weak tea at a Café for 3 francs & caught the 6.25 amtrain to Charleroi arriving there 9.30 am. I got a lorry to Beaumont where I was lucky enough to pick up our own ration lorry at the dump & I got to park at 3.30 pm.Our park has moved to Ferrière la Grande, three kilos from Maubeuge which was entered on Nov 9th by the English Guards division just before the Armistice but not before Fritz had destroyed the bridge over the river - Lansdowne & Tommy had also returned from Blighty.

Jan.29
Entry.779:
1919
I did nothing to-day but talk & get used to my surroundings - I wrote to Gisele & had a hot bath in the evening John went to a dance in the Village - My old lorry is going to be evacuated,but I am still living on it -
Entry.781:
1919
Got up at 10 am. Washed some handkerchiefs,did nothing all day - Ben & Bill came back from Blighty leave I am on guard to-night.
Entry.782:
st
 1919
I got up at 10 am& continued the lazy life. I had some letters.
Entry.783:
st
 1919
Got up at 10 am& did nothing all day as usual. I wrote letters in the evening -

Feb.2
nd
 1919
Frank & Cuddy went away for demobilisation. I am taking over Cuddy's lorry,it is in good shape. John went to Cousolre in the evening with the bunch in the Thorny -

Feb.3
rd
 1919
We transferred all our kit from the old lorry to the new one & fixed things up comfortably. Cuddy left another primus for us & we had the lorry "bien chaud"
Entry.785:
1919
We left Park at 8 amfor Boulers ten kilos the otherside of Maubeuge. We reported to 15
Entry.786: Brigade & carried troops to Beaumont for demobilisation to Aussie - go back to Park & changed a rear wheel & made a few adjustments.
Entry.787:
th
 1919
I had a bad eye so I reported to the doctor & got it fixed up,it was conjunctivitis - I did very little all day - John went to the dance in the Village in the evening - I had a hot bath & went to bed early -
Entry.788:
th
 1919
It snowed heavily last night about 3 inches fell - I got up at 9 am. John did'nt get up till noon - We did nothing all day - I wrote letters.
Entry.789:
th
1919
Got up at 10 am,nothing doing to-day,I did a bit of French - the weather is very cold now.
Entry.790:
th
 1919
We were called at 7 am& given detail to report to 3
rd
 Don Ack headqrs^at Hautment.for detached work with them - which we did - We went to Beaumont for clean clothes for the Corps baths - (One of the 5
th
 M.T. lorries
caught
also attached to the 3
rd
 D.A.H.Q caught

fire in the morning & all the body was burned off before we could put it out). We got back as far as our Park with the clean clothes & had supper there. Another of the 5
th
 lorries caught fire at their workshop & I started towing lorries out of the workshop, in case they also should catch - they soon got the fire down but not before it had burned the body off - We parked with our other lorries & stayed the night John went to the Village dance in the evening.
Entry.791:
th
 1919
We got up at 7 am& had breakfast & moved off at 8.45 back to Hautmont the baths were closed so we took the load back to the place (at Hdqrs) where we were parking & drained the radiator the weather is very cold but bright - We went for a walk in the afternoon.
Entry.792:
th
 1919
Wegot up at 8.30 am& got ready to go to Charleroi for canteen supplies etc. I went up tot he baths & dumped the clean clothes & returned back to the square & picked up some Aussies bound for Charleroi on leave & some civies & their luggage, including some cases of cognac which they

had'nt to pay duty on if we took it across the border for them - We left 11 am& arrived at Charleroi at 3.30 pm. We parked in the square - & went up & saw the Wax works (I think every Aussie who has been to Charleroi has seen it). We had tea at a restaurant.
Entry.794:
1919
We got up at 8.30 am& pulled round to the canteen but could'nt get our load till 3 pmso we left the lorry & stayed around town. We had dinner at the Café de la Bourse 8 francs 50c each. (more expensive & not as good as Paris). We loaded up the canteen supplies & picked up the civies who wanted to go back & left Charleroi at 3.45 pm, arrived at Hautmont 7.15 pm after a good run - we unloaded at the canteen. I strained myself lifting a heavy case.

Feb.12
th
 1919
At 3 am. I felt much pain from the strain - we got up at 8.30 am& went to Ferrière la Grande (our park) to get another radiator as ours was leaking badly & repair the petrol pipe - We worked on the job for the rest of the day & finished. We parked there for the night. Gal & Harold left for Aussie. John went to the Village dance in the evening.
Entry.795:
th
 1919
We got up at 7 am& went back to Hautmont. We had expected a four day trip with a party touring but it was postponed. We took a staff Captain to Sous le Bois & got back at 11.30 am.We did nothing for the rest of the day. I was feeling crook & went to bed at 7 pm.
Entry.797:
1919
We got up at 8 am,had breakfast & reported to 7
th
 Brigade headq
rs
 at 10 amto take a party of men sightseeing round by Mons Charleroi & Bruxelles a two day trip. We went through Ferrière & I called at the park & got Snow to take my place as I was'nt feeling good enough. I stayed behind & made my home with Black in a lorry waiting evacuation (Casseroles old lorry) the weather is wet.

Feb.13
th
 1919
I got up at 8 am,had breakfast & reported to Medical Officer on Sick prade at 9.30 am& he gave me instructions
for
& told me to rest as much as possible. John got back from his trip in the evening but I could'nt go back with him as I was too crook - he had a hard trip - the weather is still rainy.
Entry.798:
th
 1919
I got up at 9 am& wrote several

letters. I feel a bit worse to-day. The rain is steady but very
fine
light - Tuck came back from Blighty leave.
Entry.799:
th
 1919
Feeling a bit better to-day, still raining lightly - All lorries are to keep off the roads for three days because of the bad state of the roads. (except necessary jobs as rations)
Entry.800:
th
 1919
I stayed in bed till 11.30 am- Ed. & "le
Compt
Comte" came back from Paris leave. "Comte" as we call him works in the office & Master Willie is Q.M. for the section.The weather is still rainy -
Entry.801:
th
 1919
I stayed in bed till 11 am, there is nothing to do these days & I am resting all I can - I wrote to Gisele & also wrote a couple of letters in French for some of the other boys at their dictation - John & Snow walked in from Hautmont in the evening to get some stuff & went back at 10 pm.
Entry.802:
th
 1919
A beautiful day & sun very warm,the so called thaw precautions are lifted & traffic may once again use the roads - John went through to Charleroi this morning

Feb. 21
st
1919
Wet again to-day - John
got
came through on his way back from Charleroi at 7 pm& delivered some comforts at our office. He went on to Hautmont. Black & I are on guard to-night. 1st &
Entry.804:
nd
 1919
I got up at noon & went up with Earlie in the afternoon to work on a two cylinder car for a Froggie,not being used to a two cylinder car the trouble was hard to diagnose - we suspected the valves so checked them & ground them in. John came in during the evening with
Entry.805:
rd
the lorry & stayed for the dance he camped on the road to Hautmont last night as he had engine trouble & it was very dark & raining -

Feb. 23
rd
 1919
I got up at noon & went again with Earlie & worked on the Froggies car,Earlie did the work, I looked on & advised we took a run in the car,it is better but not right.
Entry.806:
th
 1919
I got up at noon & went again with Earlie to the Froggies & worked on the car - Raining again a little, they make beautiful cocoa up at the Froggies. (to-day is my birthday)
Entry.807:
th
 1919
I got up at 11 am. I stayed in the lorry during the afternoon & in the evening we went up to the Froggies & put new carbon brushes in his maggie on the slip ring - we had some cocoa & yarned a while - I am 20
th
 on the list for Aussie
Entry.808:
th
 1919
I got up at 8.30 am& went up to see the Quack at 9.30 am. I am getting on fairly well but think he could help me more than he does - we are giving up all our good lorries to the 5
th
 M.T. Coy & taking duds in their place. There are also rumours of our little unit being split up, which we will very much resent.
Entry.810:
1919
I got up at 9 am& took the Froggie to
Ad
Aulnoye in his car (he cant drive it) to get some coal, it went tip top & he was very pleased with the job - I stayed in in the evening.I was very tired after the trip.I had supper with the Froggies.
Entry.812:
1919
I got up at 8 am. Master Willie went to Corps headquarters to work in the orderly room - Eddie handed his lorry over to 5
Entry.813:
M.T. Coy & got an

old dud Thornyfor it - I stayed in the lorry all day - it is raining again.
Entry.814:
st 
1919
Scotty went to Paris this morning.I got up at 9 am. After dinner Black & I walked into Maubeuge & had a look round for a change of scenery. We got back at 4.20 pm& I was very tired - lovely day - sun quite warm -
Entry.815:
nd
 1919
Black & I walked to a Belgian friend's house & saw his stamp collection in the evening & he told us a lot about the german Occupation, it was very interesting - John got back from Lille with the lorry & returned to our parkas he is finished with 3
rd
 D.A. Hdqrs.
Entry.816:
rd
 1919
Black & I walked into Maubeuge in the morning & we saw our Belgian friend he works at the Mairie.We got back at noon,it rained all day -
Entry.817:
th
 1919
We gave over our lorry to the 5
th
 M.T. Coy & got an old burned one in its place - John & I went out to Jeumont & took over Kens lorry which was attached to a Prisoner of War company for shifting amunition etc.Ken was to go on leave to Italy - We brought Ken & Andy back to Ferrière la Grande & stayed at the

park for the night -
Entry.818:
th
 1919
We put on a tye rod from one of the other lorries as ours was badly worn & we went back to Jeumont at noon. They asked us where we had been, as we hadn't said anything about going & there was going to be all kinds of trouble & I was told to report to the officer in charge in the evening - We had to go to Beaumont with a couple ofhaw-haw - officers & when we got there we found that it was only a joy ride - We got back at 7.30 pm& the sergt Major told me I had better go & see the officer, as he wanted to see me but I was tired & I went to bed instead. Our Sergeant & Eric left for Aussie this morning.
Entry.819:
th
 1919
We went out at 9 amwith a load of Fritz prisoners to shift some amunition & explosives (Fritz material) from Esqueline to Jeumont Railhead. It rained all day - we did two loads in the morning & one in the afternoon & returned to the compound with the prisoners at 3.30 pm.We have very obliging Fritzes to wait on us, they get us all the water we want, wash our clothes & if we want the barber he comes along to the lorry gives a beautiful shave - I tried it right away & gave him a razor to hone for me. We give them cigarettes & any tucker we can spare.
Entry.820:
th 
1919
We left the compound at 8.30 pmwith twenty Fritzes to carry the ammo & load us up & we went to Maubeuge & hauled Fritz nine inch shells to Ferrière la Grande railhead. We broke a front spring so stopped at the Workshop & put on a new one. Our outfit was being paid so I hopped in & drew 60 francs. The O.C. goes on Blighty leave to-day - We were finished at 4 pm& returned with our Fritzes to the P.O.W. Compound.
Entry.821:
th
 1919
We left the compound at 8.30 amon the same job as yesterday & hauled three loads of 9" shells - We got back to the compound at 4.20 pm. After we had tea Fritz came in & washed up & swept out for us, he told us some of his history,he was a Pole & did'nt like Germany as his father had to pay so many taxes - he was a machine gunner in the War & was proud of the way he fired to the last,& was captured by the New Zealanders.
Entry.822:
th
 1919
Sunday - We got up at 10 am,the Fritzes dont work on Sundays - Fritz (the barber) came in & cut our hair & shaved us. He also brought my razor back beautifully honed. After dinner our batman (the Pole) Snowy we call him, asked us if we would like a hot bath & he led us to the bath house & prepared the bath for us one at a time, & rubbed our backs for us & when we were finished rubbed us down with

a towel & we left our dirty clothes with him to wash for us. The Fritzes were having baths in the next compartment & they were some of them in terrible condition, thin as rakes, some of them were alright - Our batman was fat as butter,he always was fed well by the Aussie drivers attached to the compound whom he served,though it was forbidden to feed them so the Tommy drivers kept the rules & did'nt get very well attended to in consequence - I wrote to Gisele in the evening.
Entry.823:
th
 1919
We left the compound at 8.30 amwith a load of Fritzes & went to the Aust. corps. Amunition dump at Requignies,the Fritzes worked all day stacking the amunition that was brought in by G.S. Waggons & we took them home again at 4 pm,lovely day—
Entry.824:
th
 1919
We left the compound at 8.30 amwith our load of Fritzes for Requignies,we left them there & had to go to Ferrière la Grande picked up a 3
rd
 Divy Artillery officer & went to Charleroi for comforts.We got to Charleroi at 2 pm. We had a good supper for 10 francs each & chocolate & cakes at 9.30 pmfor 4 francs each & stayed the night,parked over in front of the station close to Combien street - The Fritzes would be sent back to the compound by another

lorry -

Mar.12
Entry.825:
1919
We left Charleroi at 10.30 amwith comforts & went to Requignies & dumped them at the Chateau where the men in charge of the dump were staying then we took the officer back to Ferrière le Grande & returned to Jeumont, through Requignies to pick up the Fritzes but they had already left when we got there - We got back to the compound & there was'nt a word said about us staying away, I think they were tired of telling us off as we always agravated the sergeant major very much.
Entry.826:
th
 1919
We left the compound with our load of Fritzes & went to Maubeuge & went round the town acompanied by a guide with a list of addresses & we had to go to all these places & pick up dud amunition. The civies had reported these to the Mairie,if it was only one small shell we had to go & get it & when we had a load which was in the afternoon, we took it
up
back with our Fritzes to Jeumont railhead - Our park shifted from Ferrière la Grande to Googée on the Beaumont Charleroi road - I had a hot bath in the evening attended by Snowy our batman -
Entry.827:
th
 1919
We got up at 7 am& left the compound at 8.15 for Maubeuge & as yesterday collected

duds & took them to Jeumont railhead. We souvenired some aeroplane petrol - We got back to the compound at 4.30 pm& I had another bath in the evening - lovely day.
Entry.828:
th
 1919
We got up at 8 am& I went & saw the officer & told him I had two broken front springs that I would have to go back to park, this being Saturday we said we would be back on Sunday night - we left for the parkat 9 ambut had engine trouble this side of Beaumont. We had dinner & fixed up the engine & arrived at Googée at 4 pm.The park is doing nothing & all 1915 men are expecting to be demobilised very shortly. We pulled in off the road & reported our trouble - they said that the 5
th
 M.T. Coy would send a lorry to Jeumont in place of mine.
Entry.829:
th
 1919
Sunday - We got up at 10 am& rested all day. It was a dull cold day - some of the boys went to the dance at Ham-se-Heure in the evening. I went to bed at 9.30 pm& read the "Edge o'beyond" by Gertrude Page.
Entry.830:
th
 1919
Tommy, Blue & Bill went for three days leave to Bruxelles - We did nothing all day & are quite content

to keep on doing nothing.

Mar.18
Entry.831:
1919
I got up at 11 am.In the afternoon I took a walk with Bob to Ham-Se-Heure & saw Master Willie at S.M.T.O.salso saw Len there. Bob got his pass for Blighty in the evening & leaves to-morrow morning -
Entry.832:
th
 1919
We got up at 11 am& after dinner went for a walk - We were paid in the evening,I drew 40 francs. I wrote some letters. & read the paper - John played poker in one of the other lorries -
Entry.833:
th
 1919
I got up at 6.30 am& went with Tuck in his lorry to Maubeuge for a joy ride - we got back to park at 6 pm(had dinner at Maubeuge) cold bleak day - The 3
rd
 Div. races were on at Thuin this afternon & some of the boys went up, some of them lost money on the races but most of them came back in pocket. I wrote letters in the evening - John played cards.
Entry.834:
st
 1919
We worked on the lorry all day, the truss rod was broken & we had had it welded & now assembled it, whilst the Fritzes worked on the springs - Kanger went on leave to Paris.
Entry.835:
nd
 1919
The 1915 men went into Charleroi for a medical examination. I worked on the truss rod & finished it,the Fritzes worked on the springs but did'nt finish them - cold bleak day -
Entry.836:
rd
 1919
Sunday - We got up at 10.30 amas we had all to be on Parade at 11 amfor a recognition stunt. Someone thought one of our fellows had been implicated in some crime, but we were all on parade & they called the roll & had a look at us, all & seemed to be satisfied that none of us happened to be the man they wanted. After that we all went to the races at Chatelet the other side of Charleroi. Snow took us in lorry 26. White's old lorry - We had a bet on most of the races & I was losing but pulled up even on the last race at six to one - We went into Charleroi & had a good feed all in a bunch fourteen of us & got home at 10 pm.
Entry.837:
th
 1919
Raining all day & as cold as charity - The Fritzes finished the springs & made us mobile - I read the "Knave of diamonds" by Ethel M. Dell & wrote letters. I had a hot bath in the evening (in the lorry. I missed

the bath at the compound & the attendant)
Entry.838:
th
 1919
They gave us a detail to go back to Jeumont (the 5
th
 M.T. Coy gave us the detail) & as we did'nt want the job again & they had some lorries of their own, I fixed up the engine & told them that I could'nt start up so they sent one of their own lorries out & told me to get the engine going & get out of the place they were using as a workshop - when our lorry came home in the afternoon with the rations I got him to tow me across the road with our own lorries to save starting my engine. The boss came back from Blighty leave. John & some of the other boys went to a dance at Ham-Se-Heure in the evening -
Entry.839:
th
 1919
Jim went to Aussie - Tuck & I walked up to Thuin & had dinner there at a Café 4 francs 50 c each for Cheval & chips & it was no good.
Entry.840:
th
 1919
We got up at 11 am& did nothing all day,it was a cold day & we sat round the old primos & kept them warm.
Entry.842:
1919
We got up at 8 am& cleaned the lorry with a Fritz to help us,we are going to the reception Park to

hand all our lorries in - We left Goozée at 4 pm& went to Marchienne au Pont & pulled into the reception Park just being formed, the 3
rd
 Brigade brought the first lorries in & we were the second lot to arrive. We parked for the night just in the entrance as the ground was soft further in. The weather was cold & snowing -

Mar.29
th
 1919
I got up at noon, feeling crook.I caught a cold in the side & back when I was having a bath in the lorry two nights ago it was very cold &
drafty
draughty - We had tea in Tuck's lorry & played nap in the evening. I felt much better at night.It snowed all day & got very cold in the night.
Entry.843:
th
 1919
Sunday. We got up at 10 am.I am feeling better to-day - Snow squalls all day & windy - John went out with Tuck in the evening to Charleroi.I spent the evening with Scotty & went to bed at midnight.
Entry.844:
st
1919
We got up at 8 am& went on parade at 9 am. We had a mobile lorry so we had to pull

cassie lorries into position all day through the soft ground with the help of about a hundred Fritzes pushing & pulling. We got all our lorries into line in the park & we backed in & drained the radiator etc never to go out again with it & hoping never to drive a lorry in this country again. Ken came home from his Italian leave & John & Ed & Jimmie left for Paris (on a three day Bruxelles pass)
Entry.845:
st
 1919
We got up at 8 am& thoroughly cleaned up our lorries with the help of a few Fritzes, took Maggies Carburetters etc off - Beautiful day warm & sunny - Ken tuckered with me.
Entry.846:
nd
1919
We shifted all our kits outof the lorries into some huts
& handed
& slept in the huts - fine day but a cold wind - We had all tools etc checked & we handed the lorries over -
Entry.847:
rd
 1919
We went on parade at 9 am& were warned to be ready to move outin the afternoon with all our

worldly posessions,we got our kits
all re
already - discarding a lot of stuff & at 4 pma lorry came for some of us to take us to 6
th
 M.T. Coy to await demobilisation. We put our kits on the lorry & asked our mates to take care of it & Ken & I got off the lorry just outside the park & made our way to Charleroi & caught the 9 pmtrain to Paris - fine day -
Entry.848:
th
 1919
We arrived in Paris at 9 am& had breakfast at a dairy on Boulevard Montmartre & called at the New Hotel Miss Routes (New Zealand Voluntary Worker for the troops & a trump) called at the Luxor Hotel to see the others but they were'nt in, so we left a note for them as they would be back before they left Paris, however we did'nt see them during the day so we went to the
Bre
Charleroi train in the evening & saw them on their way back - we told them all particulars of where to find the mob etc & told them we would be back in a few days - We went to bed at 9 pmas we did'nt have any sleep last night. The train was crowded & the only seats we could get were third class & wooden seats—
Entry.849:
th
 
We got up at 9 am& had breakfast at the dairy on the Boulevard Montmartre a very nice breakfast, eggs, rolls & butter beautiful chocolate & a couple of cakes for five francs. I packed up my pair of Fritz field glasses that I got at Bellecourt & sent them home by the American Express Agency - we spent the day about town & in the evening went to the Follies Bergères.
Entry.850:
th
1919
Sunday. We got up at 9 am& breakfasted at the creamery - we had afternoon tea at 3 pmat the Leave Club & then went to see the Pantheon de la Guerre near Champs de Mars - it is a circular hall wonderfully painted (the walls are painted & it is viewed from a platform in the centre) representing the different nations of the Allies & their part in the war. The British Empire tableau is represented by several of the leading British statesmen also Kitchener & several other staff Officers the army Generals. etc. Some Flying Officers including Major Bishop the Canadian Ace,the soldiers of the Dominion are very poorly represented being indistinct - Nurse Cavell is shown with a halo round her head -
Franc
there Canadian, Australian & English

Hospital Sisters represented -

France of course holds the most prominent position in the hall & is a wonderful painting & includes multitudes of soldiers the chiefs easily recognisable also the leading statesmen - in the forefront are some German colours (flags) on the ground & two French 75 m.m. guns standing on them. The whole thing is most wonderfully & beautifully carried out.— We went to the Alambra theatre in the evening -
Entry.851:
th
 1919
We got up at 9 am& had breakfast as usual at the dairy, booked our seats on the train with Miss Route (she buys the tickets & has carriages reserved for the soldiers going up the line from leave,saving the boys a lot of bother & ensuring good seats & no overcrowding) & then went to a liquor store & purchased 13 bottles of XXX Cogniac & put them in our packs they cost us 16 francs 50
c
 per bottle. We went back to Miss R.
s
 at 7 pm& all went across to the station to-gether & took our seats. We had a second class German carriage, beautiful comfortable roomy seats & six men in a compartment - We took off our boots & made ourselves

comfortable for the night. The train left at 8 pm& when we got hungry we ate of the sandwiches which Miss R. had provided.
Entry.852:
th
 1919
We slept well, got out at Mons (where we stopped for 20 minutes) & had a good cup of hot coffee & sandwichesat 7am& reached Charleroi at 9 am. We went straight to a café in the Square & sold them for 25 francs per bottle showing a profit of 8½ francs per bottle on 13 bottles - they are not allowed to import spirits into Belgium. We went on the tram as far as Marchienne Au Pont terminus,picked up a lorry as far as Goozée & had to walk the rest of the way to Beaumont about 15 kilos. We arrived there at 6.30 pm(we stopped on the road at a Tommy cookhouse & had a feed) & were put under open arrest - we procured a billet at 1f apiece per night, it did'nt look too clean but the bed was comfortable.
Entry.853:
th
 1919
We got up at 8 am& had to go up before a lieutenant in the morning. Heasked us a few questions & remanded the case for the Major, before whom we paraded in the afternoon & were

duly charged with having been A.W.L. from 7 pmon 3
rd
 till 7 pmon 8
th
 five days - (he had us before him separately) he asked why we had gone away & we both told him about the same, that we had wanted the trip & as we were coming to a fresh unit, we did'nt expect to get too good a spin with leave etc - & he assured us that we would have been able to get leave by asking for it (I doubt it) & he treated all alike, however he said you lose five days pay automatically & I fine you five days pay - making a total of 10 days pay or£3.10- not too bad but my only crime in the A.I.F. & seeing that the war is over I dont look on it as a crime.— We went to the cinema in the evening—
Entry.854: We got up at 9 am& had breakfast & did nothing all day - some of the boys are on lorries & the others dodging the sergeants to avoid being put on lorries - John is on with Lansdowne. Jimmy with Eddie.
Entry.855:
I was caught for the job of looking after the store, but as they told me there was nothing

to do I took it, I was told it was the best job on the column. The weather is dull & wet & the place we have our meals at the top of an
ho
empty house in the attic isnt too comfortable & a primus wont make an impression on it.
Entry.856:
th
 1919
I showed up at the store & was there on & off all day (principally off) I had nothing to do but make a note of anything being taken out. It was dreary cold & wet all day - we all went together in the evening to the farewell cinema show.
Entry.857:
th
 1919
Sunday - Ken, Tuck & Tommy went on a draft of 10 men from the column for demobilisation. They went by lorry to the rest camp at Charleroi & would go by train to Le Havre from there to Blighty. Lansdowne took them to Charleroi - Phil & I spent the night in Kens & my billet. We intend to look for a better one to-morrow.
Entry.858:
th
 1919
I stayed at the store all the morning & absented myself therefrom in the afternoon - Phil & I found a good little billet & sat round the fire all the afternoon. I did'nt feel too

good all day &
eat
ate nothing -
Entry.859:
th
 1919
They were stocktaking in my store so I had to stick to the job all day - I felt better to-day & am eating again. I wrote some letters in French for Ed & Bob. in the evening - Weather Blustery & wet.
Entry.860:
th
 1919
We were stocktaking all day & finished at closing time - Cold bleak day - We like our billet fine,it is clean & comfortable with white sheets, & they are nice people, they tell us lots about Fritzes occupation etc -
Entry.861:
th
 1919
Thursday (Market day in Beaumont.) I stayed in the store all day, the weather still cold & bleak.
Entry.862:
th
 1919
Good Friday. I stayed in the store all the morning, & this being a half day holliday. Eddie & I went up into the Salamandre Tower - I wrote my name on the ceiling of Napoleons room, there were the names of hundreds of soldiers there, Fritzes, Italian,
Pol
French & of course Aussies.It was a lovely day, for a change.
Entry.863:
th
 1919
Blue & two men from the 6
th
 M.T.C. went away on early repatriation in the afternoon. Snowy went on 14 days leave to Italy - fine warm day but not sunny - I wrote a couple of letters.
Entry.864:
th
 1919
Sunday (Easter) Got up at 8.30 amhad eggs & chips downstairs at our billet like gentlemen - Phil & I went for a walk - I read in the afternoon, raw cold day but fine evening -
Entry.865:
st
 1919
We got up at 8.30 am& went along for breakfast. John. Phil. & Andy went away for a draft of 11 men from the 6
th
 M.T.C. at 3 pm,every time we say good-bye to some of our fellows we know our turn is coming soon. I hung about the store all day - fine day but not too warm -
Entry.866:
nd
 1919
We shifted the store across the road to the old Y.M.C.A. headqrs,the Workshop also shifted across. I had lots of help to shift. Warm day but not sunny. I wrote to Frank also other letters in the evening.
Entry.867:
rd
1919
Sunny daybut cold - I sat out in the sun & read all the morning

at the back of the building right on my job. It rained a bit in the evening.I hada bath & a change in the evening at the top of the house where we eat -
Entry.868:
th
 1919
Cloudy damp & cold day, I had to shift the store again to a room in the front of the building,but did'nt do too much.
Entry.869: ANZAC-DAY. I finished shifting the bulk store, had the afternoon off as it is a general holiday.We played 500 in Eddie's maison where the Madame likes to make ourselves comfortable. - We played there again in the evening - we call it our Y.M.C.A. We had a few chips in the evening at my joint.
Entry.870:
th
 1919
Miserable cold day. I spent the day reading magazines in the store room. - We played cards in the evening -
Entry.871:
th
 1919
Sunday - I got up at 11 am. After dinner, Eddie Jimmy & I went up on the roof of the Tower & read but the sun went & it got cold & started snowing so we retired to our Y.M.C.A.

where there was a fire always burning -
Entry.872:
th
 1919
There are many rumours circulating these days,some of them we aprove of & others we dont like - "Comte" took a run along from Hdqrs where he is - to see us - I am 31
st
 on the 6.M.T. list for repatriation.
Entry.873:
th
 1919
Cold day, it rained all the afternoon.I read magazines all day - Bob & Ed returned from Namur where they went to a couple of days ago with their lorry -
Entry.875:
1919
It snowed last night & the snow lay on the ground all day. Also it rained heavily in the afternoon & it was very cold all day - I received some letters & answered them -
Entry.876:
st
 1919
The store is packing up & checking to send everything to the base. I was busy all day packing it is supposed to finish on 20
th
, Eddie went away with a draft to-day.
Entry.877:
nd
 1919
I was taking lists of stock from the store waggons all day - Wet & miserable day - I read all

the evening at our Y.M.C.A.
Entry.878:
rd
 1919
I was busy all day with the stock - beautiful day for a change.I spoke to the Major about leave & he told me to make application,which I did, asking for five days to La Houssoye to visit Gisele's family.
Entry.880:
I saw the Major & he told me that he was sorry but no leave could be granted as I am due for repatriation with a draft on May 10th.I was very pleased to know it - (I did'nt get up till noon to-day) We went for a walk in the afternoon
seveen
seven of us & all that remained of the 6th Acros. at the 6th M.T. C. Bob & Ed took photos of the bunch -

May 5
th
 1919
Glorious day. I sat out in the sun nearly all day, on a petrol tin across the road from the store as I had nothing to do. I had a hot bath in the afternoon & we went for a walk along the Charleroi road in the evening then came back & had a feed of chips at my joint.
Entry.881:
th
 1919
The morning was fine & sunny & I sat out in the sun, the afternoon was dull & damp - We went for a

promenade in the evening.
Entry.882:
th
 1919
Glorious day. I sat out in the sun nearly all day. We handed our spare kit into Quarters Master store in the afternoon - I had my hair cut. We went for a promenade in the evening -
Entry.883:
th
 1919
Glorious day again - I sat out in the sun all day - in the evening Bob & I went & had a yarn with Dr Turner over a bottle of wine in his room. He is going away for a weeks shooting near Germany& we said good-bye to him. He can talk good English & he told us lots of interesting things.
Entry.884:
th
 1919
Lovely day but we had a heavy shower from 4 pmtill 5.30 pm. We played cards in the evening - Lansdowne & Joe got back from Namur with the lorry. They went there on duty two days ago -
Entry.885:
th
 1919
I got up at 10 am& got my kit etc ready for the road. We had dinner & left for Charleroi at 3 pmin a lorry (Bob. Ed. Jimmy & I) & got to the rest camp at 6 pmafter one or two slight accidents on the road. The driver knocked a

Froggie's cart & caused a boy to fall out & get his hand run over. We stopped & bandaged up his hand & took him to a dressing station about a kilo away & continued - We saw Charleroi by night,the Saturday night hurdy gurdy & fair was in full swing - We booked rooms at a Hotel for the night.
Entry.886:
th
 1919
Sunday - We got up at 7.30 am& went along to the rest camp for breakfast We were on parade all
day
the morning met the "Comte" he also is on this draft. - We all had a good supper to-gether in a restaurant,we met Kanger & he came in with us,lovely day,we went back to ourHotel for the night.
Entry.887:
th
 1919
We got up at 6 am& went round to the rest camp for breakfast & entrained at 8.30 am. We left Charleroi at 9.30,twenty five men in each box car with a bale of straw to spread out on the floor. We made ourselves fairly comfortable & we had plenty to eat in the way of dates & bully beef,Bread & cheese & jam.
Entry.888:
th
 1919
We passed through Amiens at 3 am& stopped for about five minutes

We all got out just as we were & there were two girls on the station, some of the boys hooked them, someone else played a cornet & they danced. The all aboard sounded & away we went again. We passed a train of Fritzes further on & stopped opposite them & had a yarn a few wittycisms were passed - then we went on & lay ourselves down to sleep again. We got up at 7.30 am& stopped some place for breakfast. They provided us with a cup of tea but the queue was about a mile long & it took about¾ of an hour before we were all served. We arrived at Le Havre at 2 pm,de-trained & after some standing about, marched five kilos with our packs up, rifle & equipment to a camp,had tea & a bit of a clean up & sat around & talked - we had huts to sleep in. The three blankets we brought down with us we handed in at the railhead & were issued with two each at the camp.
Entry.889:
th
 1919
We slept pretty well on the board floor. Ed & I doubled up to economise with the blankets. We went through what they call the delousing process which consists of a hot bath & a clean change - & the change fitted



where the garments touched. They were very umpty. - We sat on the verandah of the salvation army hut all the afternoon & read - Joe who left Charleroi on a special draft for non military enjoyment in England - the day before we left, arrived in the camp after having been all over France - We had some hard boiled eggs & bread & butter & tea at the salvo in the evening.
Entry.890:
th
 1919
First parade 9.45 am- We shifted camp at 2 pm- the next camp was only about 100 yards away.No 49. Quota left for Blighty to-day (We are with no
46
52Quota) - We went to the cinema in the evening, but it was very poor. We waited in the hall for the concert which followed & it was'nt too bad. - the day was dull with a little rain -
Entry.891:
th
 1919
Lovely day - We had a lecture in the morning on the method of demobilisation telling us just what we would go through before we were put on board for Aussie. The four of us put in application for leave to le Havre & got it, we caught the 1.30 pmtrain from the station just below.

the camp. We met Joe in Havre just going aboard the boat for Blighty - We saw nothing much in Havre to interest us,we had a nice afternoon tea; cakes & chocolate & we had supper at a restaurant & caught the 8.20 pmtrain back to camp -
Entry.892:
th
 1919
First parade 9.30 am- lovely day - We went through the Q.M.s & had some more stuff issued (completed our Q.I. forms) I lay out in the sun all the afternoon - We went to the cinema in the evening & went to bed at 9.30 pm.
Entry.893:
th
 1919
Sunday - First parade 9 am,compulsary church parade - In the afternoon we went to what they called the Fun stunt in the dell, the band blazed & a Y.M.C.A. officer held sway & amused the boys with simple competitions writing things in the air with a stick & the men who guessed what wrote, he threw out packets of cigarettes etc as prizes. It was very amusing & all the boys seemed to enjoy it - a man of the Anzac Provost corps rode by on a horse & the crowd boohed to some order, his ears must have tingled, they also whistled pretty Joey -

a couple of officers also rode by & they gave them a hoy - We spent the evening at the Salvo. eating eggs etc. & laying on the grass -
Entry.894:
th
 1919
Some of us were on a fatigue party & when we reported, we were told to make ourselves scarce & we imediately melted away.We lay in the sun all the morning - We had a steam bath followed by a cold shower in the afternoon & went to the cinema in the evening - lovely day—
Entry.895:
th
 1919
We had our embarkation cards issued on the 9 amparade & at noon we got on lorries & went to Le Havre with our sea kits. We embarked on the S
t
 George & left Havre at 4 pm,arrived Southampton at 10.30 pmafter a good smooth trip - We were anchored in the streem all night & we slept as best we could about the deck, but were too cold to sleep much -
Entry.896:
st
 1919
We welcomed daylight & queued up for a cup of hot cocoa,we disembarked at 8.30 am& after some waiting were served with a cup of tea & some cake - entrained

at 10.30 amafter being issued with noon rations which were very well put up & very aceptable. We got off the train at Fovent siding about
se
nine miles from Salisbury & we marched to no 12 camp Hurdcott & were put into huts & issued with blankets etc. John looked us up in the afternoon & after tea he took us round to no 10 camp & we met Ken, Tommy, Andy & Tuck. Eddie was on leave - We went to bed at 9 pm-
Entry.897:
nd
 1919
We got up at 6.30 am& had a cold shower, had breakfast & attended first parade at 9 am.We were enoculated for influenza - no parade in the afternoon - lovely day -
Entry.898:
rd
 1919
We were paid in the morning,I drew£4.10- I put in application for early repatriation, as there were rumours of all M.T. drivers going to Parkhouse Camp for duty. In the afternoon we paraded to Q.M.s for dungarees etc. In the evening we walked about the camps, watched two up & crown & anchor rings - I lost 5/- on the crown & anchor. I was winning 10/- at one time but stayed till I lost it & some of my own —
Entry.899:
th
 1919
Ed & I acted as mess orderlies for the day & so did'nt go on parade.I did some washing. We were paid 24/6 each for ration allowance whilst on leave - 1/9 per day for 14 days -

We went for a walk in the evening. I had another go at crown & anchor & lost another 5/-
Entry.900:
th
 1919
Sunday - Fine warm day but dull - I was on camp fatigue in the morning, emptying rubbish tins & picking up paper - We had a warm shower when we got up this morning at 6.30 am— We handed in our kit bags in the afternoon preparatory to going on leave to-morrow morning - In the evening we went up to see the boys in the other camps & Ken decided to come up to London with us in the morning A.W.L.
Entry.901:
th
 1919
