We left camp by Ford car for Salisbury at 8 amhad breakfast at Y.M.C.A. in Salisbury & caught 9.45 amfor London - Jimmy was going down to Torquay & Bob was coming up with Comte, Ed. Ken & myself to London & going to join Jimmy at Torquay the next day.

We went to "Joy Bells" at the Hippodrome in the evening. It was very good - Comte & Ed stayed at the Shaftsbury & Ken, Bob & I walked down to Victoria to a place Ken knew - on the way there we got mixed up with a brawl between the Police & the crowd, but not knowing the strength of it we did'nt interfere.
Entry.902:
Ed went up to Headqrs & saw about his application for early repatriation which he had put in some time ago & he was told that if he went back to camp at once he would probably go very quickly, so he went. I met Comte in the afternoon (Ken had gone back to camp & Bob had gone down to Torquay) & he was to meet a Girl friend of his Fiance's so we met her & all three went up to Kings Cross Station & saw Harry Hawkers triumphant entry into London on the back of a Policemans horse behind the Policeman - there were diggers at the top of lamp posts & every other place - I saw Jno there in the procession that followed Hawker & he saw me & joined me. I had'nt seen him since he went on Blighty leave from Bussu. He had been in hospital ever since & was

this day discharged from hospital & intended reporting at Hdqrs to-morrow. I gave him the address of the place I was staying at in Victoria & said I would meet him there at bed time as he had some place he wanted to go - Comte, Evelyn & I went & had supper at the Shaftsbury & took her home & I met Jno & we went to bed -
Entry.903:
We met Comte at 11 am& the three of us went for a swim at the Gt SmithSt Baths near Horseferry road. I went to
the
see a dentist in the Strand at 1 pm& we went after to Lyons Corner House & had dinner. Jaco & I went to Chu-Chin Chow in the evening (Oscar Asche) Jno had decided to spend the day with me & report to-morrow—
Entry.904: We got up at 8.30 am& I went with Jno to Headqrs & found out that he was going to Sutton Veny camp & said good-bye - I met Comte & we had dinner at Lyons Corner house.I went out to Kingston in the afternoon to my Aunts - Mr M. & I played putting on the lawn & also shooting with an air rifle in the evening -
Entry.905:
th
1919
I got up at 9 am& spent the morning on the lawn in the sun - in the afternoon I went to Hampton Court Palace with my aunt & cousin. I was very interested in the old grape vine in the court gardens, in the evening we had a game of bowls on the lawn - lovely day -
Entry.906:
st
 1919
I met Comte at the Chiswick baths at 3 pm,we were going in for a swim but it was crowded & the queue was too long - We went & had afternoon tea at the Corner House & I booked a room at the Shaftsbury for the night. We went to see "The Boy" at the Adelphi in the evening.It was very amusing - We lobbed in at the Hotel at 12.30 am& went to bed -
Entry.907:
st
 1919
Sunday - We both had an apointment with the dentist in the morning & we went along at 11 am. We had dinner at the Corner house & went to Richmond & spent the afternoon on the river - the river was very crowded & the tarrif was very high accordingly we came off at 8 pm& had tea & I got the train back to Kingston - Comte went back to London
Entry.908:
nd
 1919
I went up to see the dentist at 10 am.I went to the Bank & drew some money & met Comte & Ed (Ed had gone back to camp & been removed to Sutton Veny & as things were slow down there applied for leave as he had voluntarily forfeited his 14 days leave & he was granted 48 hours leave only -) We had dinner to-gether & I went out to Taplow to see a cousin of my friend who was in the Canadian Light Horse & was killed last September - Mrs & Mr M lived in a home fronting on the river & they took me out in their skiff & gave me a good time. I was almost persuaded to stay the night but thought that I ought to go back to Kingston as I was expected, so I caught 9.20 pmtrain back to Paddington & arrived at Kingston 11.30 pm.
Entry.909:
rd
 1919
I visited the dentist at 10 am& again at 11 am. I bought a song (Good bye Khaki) from "Joy Bells" & sent it home to my sister - I went back to Kingston for dinner arriving there 12.45 pm.In the afternoon we had a little tea party on the lawn under a large mulberry tree. In the evening we played Bowles.
Entry.910:
th
 1919
Dull day with a little rain.The Derby was run in the afternoon & Grand Parade came in first 33 to 1,Panther the favourite did'nt get a place.I went to the dentist in the morning & went to Dulwich in the afternoon,got back to Kingston at 8.30 pm& played bowles with M
r
 M.
Entry.911:
th
1919
In the morning I went to the dentist at 10 am& afterwards went to Sutton to meet some people but they were not home (probably at Epsom) I got back to Kingston at 2 pmby buss & tram - We played bowles in the evening - fine warm day -
Entry.912:
th
 1919
I said good-bye to my Aunt as I intended going down to Torquay for the last few days of my leave,but after I had been to the dentists & got fixed up (£9.13 it cost me) I met Comte & I decided to stay out the time with him,so I booked a room at the Shaftsbury.We had lunch at the Shaftsbury & went to Grove Park for the afternoon - lovely warm day -
Entry.913:
th
 1919
We went on the Thames for a while in the morning as fares had

dinner at the Corner House - I bought a book & sent home "Q boat adventures" all about the "U boat" decoys during the war.
Entry.914:
th
 1919
Sunday - We stayed in bed late & got up & had dinner. We went out to Grove Park in the afternoon by buss & came back by train at 9 pm& had supper at the Corner House.
Entry.915:
th
 1919
We met two lady friends at 11.30 am& went out to Grove Park for the day - came back by train in the evening & had supper at Lyons Corner House - We got back to the Hotel at 1 am.
Entry.916:
th
 1919
We met the ^ladyfriends at noon & had dinner at the Corner House & they came to see us off at Waterloo at 3 pm.We arrived in Salisbury at 4.45 & went out to Hurdcott by Ford - arriving there at 5.30 pm,our camp is shifted from No.12. Camp to No.7. We met the other boys in the evening & comparred our experiences on leave etc. & went to the cinema - Ken is in London on Back sheesh - fine day -
Entry.917:
th
 1919
We were on Camp fatigue

in the morning, shovelling refuse. The weather is dull & looks like rain but it keeps fine. We wrote letters in the afternoon in the Y.M.C.A. joint & went for a walk in the evening.
Entry.919:
1919
The weather to-day is windy & cold withshowers - Bob & Jim went to Parkhouse camp & I was shifted to No. 6 camp. (details) on account of my application for early repatriation. I had a letter from Frank which had been to France & followed me back. He sailed for America on May 18th - I wrote to him at his address in California that he gave me - also wrote other letters.

June 15
th
 1919
I received my second enoculation for influenza in the morning & in the afternoon went over to 46 Quota No.9. Camp - We all went to a lecture at the Y.M.C.A in the evening, the subject was "A Scrap of Paper" & the lecturer was Sir Somebody Something he used to be
an
Consul General in Belgium it was well worth listening to. After the majority had gone to bed in the camps a gang of two up kings (double nobbers) & other crooks came home from Salisbury raising Cain. They did some

damage in Wilton on their way & when they got to camp they were looking for trouble & going into one hut in No 11. camp, they knocked one man who was sitting playing cards (Patience) he was able to offer no resistence. They went to such excesses that no.11. camp was ordered out of bed & told to grab any man with a tunic on. The thugs jerried to this & were overheard telling one another to take their tunics off. They got one of the men & mauled him badly & the intervention of an officer saved his life & he was lodged in clink & given attention. The man that the gang had knocked was in bad condition,& expected to die but he pulled through—
Entry.920:
th
 1919
We went on 9 amparade & were dismissed - I did some washing - There were riots all day long following the demonstration of last night. The men woke up to this gang & decided to get them, several of them were known to be very intimate with some of the N.A.C.B. girls in one of the canteens & this is where the men started. They asked permission to search this canteen & were refused by the girls so they took the law into their own hands &

forced an entrance. They did'nt get their quarry but they got all the canteen stores & several barrels of beer - Massey was supposed to be the leader of the gang& that was the man they were after principally, once started they were hard to stop. They went to each canteen in turn & cleared all five of stores & beer when that was they turned their attention to the Q.M. Store & helped themselves to all they wanted, they carried a lot of stuff back to their huts & nearly every man in all the camps around was wearing new clothes - at dark the officers advised the boys to leave the rest of the store till next morning as they were destroying stuff by trampling on it.In the evening they caught one man known as Kelly & took him up to the clink & after putting him in were going to get him out again & do for him but the Padre interferred & told them that Kelly was able to give information that would
obtain
cause the capture of some of the others. (this gang is said to have been working since February, men have been found dead & robbed near the highroads others sandbagged & robbed) they all quitened down as the evening wore on and all was quiet at bedtime
Entry.921:
th
 1919
Sunday - It is mooted that Massey is caught & is in Codford clink. Some say that he gave himself up & others that he was captured - the gang have several friends in ourcamp & know of everything that goes on & it is said that a bunch of them were on the hill looking down into the camp while the canteens were being raided & saw the whole performance also one man is supposed to have taken a bucket of beer up to them -

Comte came over to 46 Quota & camped with me - The 35th Quota went away first thing in the morning carrying two kit bags each, most of them - these bags were filled with Q.M. stuff. Their regular kits had gone ahead - most of these kit bags were later picked up along the road to Fovent the men having realised that it was no good to them - lovely day.
Entry.922:
th
 1919
The officers asked the men to return all the stuff that they did'nt need with all their old stuff to the orderly room to be sent to the Q.M. store again then we had a kit inspection to see that we had'nt too much new stuff. After this inspection, Comte, Ken & I walked to Fovent bought a ticket to

Salisbury 2/6 (return) & went up to London, when we got to Waterloo we hopped over the wall to evade the ticket collector. Comte & I made arrangements for a room for the night but when we landed there at 1 amwe found out that some misunderstanding had occurred & our beds were taken so we tried at that hour to find somewhere to sleep - we were unsuccessful & at 2 pmwent to the Y.M.C.A hut at Victoria & had a lay down on the floor but it was too cold & drafty to sleep so we walked up to the Aldwych hut in the strand,got there at 4 am& found a window lounge vacant which we slept on till 7 am.
Entry.923:
th
 1919
We had a wash & clean up & then went to the Victoria Y.M.C.A for breakfast & met Ken at 9 am.We caught the 11.30 train from Waterloo to Ascot 15/- return 1
st
 class. 25 trains ran out there during the morning. We saw the Royal Ascot meeting & did a little punting in which I just held my own the others did better - I was just out my expenses - we got back at 7 pm& had supper at the Shaftsbury - lovely day
Entry.924:
th
 1919
We met Lansdowne in the strand, he was on leave from 58
th
 Quota. We had not been too well provided with money for our trip & had to go very easy, we saw what we came up to see: Royal Ascot,now we were broke so we caught 3 pmtrain from Waterloo to Salisbury & arrived in Fovent at 6.30 pm& walked to camp - We went to Mr Cotalinis lecture at the Y.M.C.A on India (he
w
is an Indian & speaks fluent Emglish) fine day—
Entry.925:
th
 1919
The 40
th
 Quota went away this morning (John with them).Phil came back yesterday after 28 days A.W.L. which he was duly slugged for he is on our quota but is trying to get off again as he expects to get leave to go back to Wales,if he dosent get leave he will take it. Comte & I walked into Salisbury in the afternoon & back in the evening15 miles there & back -
Entry.926:
th
 1919
It rained steadily all day.I was supposed to be on fatigue but I made myself scarce & wrote letters.Comte got his second enoculation in the evening we went to a lecture

on Russiaby McLeland held at Y.M.C.A. it was very good.
Entry.927:
st
 1919
I went to the Commonwealth Bank& drew £5.0.0 & in the afternoon Comte & I walked into Sallisbury had tea & spent the evening there & stayed at a Hotel for the night, the camp life is so monotonous that we must make a change. fine day—
Entry.928:
nd
 1919
We walked out to Wilton & had dinner there & walked back to camp - fine day—
Entry.929:
rd
1919
We went for a Walk to-ward Wilton & had tea in Wilton & walked back to camp. The boat roll came out to-day whilst we were away -
Entry.930:
th
 1919
We went to the orderly room to see about our names on the boat roll,mine was alright but Comte had slippedhis papers had somehow been mislaid.We spent most of the day trying to trace them but could'nt & anyway it is too late now & he will be going back to the 52
nd
 Quota - We went for a walk in the evening—
Entry.931:
th
 1919
I went on guard at 2 am. I fell to the last shift which was'nt due to go on till 10 pm.I was also on guard - I went on guard at 10 pm& as soon as the camp was quiet we went to bed, I think that all the guard was for was to provide the men with diversion, the post I was on was a place (store of some kind) & the men in charge slept in it, so why have a guard. Alittle rain fell during the day -
Entry.932:
th
 1919
We were not relieved till 4pm. We then changed huts, the men were split up into states. Queenslanders being No.1. Coy. N.S.W. No.2 Coy & Vic No 3 Coy - & others No 4.Coy - We walked into Wilton in the evening & had supper & walked back to camp—
Entry.933:
th
 1919
Spent the afternoon in the fields & later walked to Quidhampton near Wilton, had tea & walked back to camp. fine day—
Entry.934:
I went on Parade in the morning & was warned for
parade
 fatigue at 2 pm. We had comforts issued - Went for a walk in the evening -
Entry.935:
th
 1919
We walked to Salisbury,spent the day away from camp & came back in the evening - fine day -
Entry.937:
1919
First parade 9 am& medical examination, I did a bit of washing & wrote some letters - Comte got leave to London & left for that city in the morning. His Quota is expected to sail on "Main" on July 6
th
 & go via Suez - I went to a concert in the evening at No.9. Y.M.C.A. then went down to No 6 camp & said good-bye to Ken - he is waiting for Non Military Enjoyments.We leave here to-morrow for Aussie.
Entry.938:
st 
1919
Reveille 4 am& it was raining.We had breakfast & carried the tables & forms etc into the Camp Q.M. & marched to Fovant at 5.30 am,had a cup of coffee provided by Y.M.C.A. at the station then we entrained & left at 7 am& went right through to Devonport, stopping for about 20 minutes at Exeter to be provided with a cup of tea & a bun by the Lady Mayoress of Exeter - On landing from Australia & departing for Australia she has been consistent in providing this bun & cup of tea & I am sure the fact is appreciated by the troops. (No 1 & 2 companies came on

this train - Nos. 3 & 4 Coys came by a later train) We arrived at Devonport at 1 pm& went on board the "Frankfurt" by tender from the wharf at 2.30 pm. We had a hot dinner at 3.30 pm- I and another man at our mess volunteered for permanent mess orderly duties, the men of the mess to pay 1/- each per week for the orderlies, it is more satisfactory than taking turns.We were on No 5. lower deck - 12messes 14 men to the mess,each man provided with a hammock & two blankets & a life belt. Nos. 2 & 3 companies & details came on board at 6 pm. The weather was cold & showery - We had supper at 8 pm& I turned in at 9.30 pm.
Entry.939:
nd
 1919
Reveille 7 am- breakfast 8 am,mess orderlies had to draw bread, butter (margarine) & jam at 7 am& 4 pm.We sailed at 10 am. We passed the "Karmala" at anchor in the bay & left so quietly that most of the men didnt realise we were moving till we were in the open sea.In the afternoon the troops began to feel the sea,it wasnt rough but she gently rolled & pitched. I felt sick in the afternoon & fed the fishes a few times before I had finished. I turned in at 8 pm& even the swing of the hammock
d
made

me feel a bit dizzy - the day was fine but decidedly cool. The log was read at noon (it is read at every watch but at noon each day the total milage is given out) & registered 33 miles - The clocks were also put back one hour which is true time (not English summertime)
Entry.940:
rd
 1919
I got up at 6.30 amfeeling much better & so were the
rest
majority of the troops, two up which was started as soon as the troops got aboard & was played with gusto (also crown & anchor) stopped yesterday afternoon, but started again to-day & one had difficulty in passing along the after deck on the Port side because of the crowd with their eyes following the pennies - the sea gotvery smooth in the afternoon & the band(4th Pioneer band on No 5. lower deck) gave a few selections - the weather was dull & cool - the milage at noon was 294 & the clocks were put back 36 minutes.
Entry.941:
th
 1919
The games of house & under & over started,affording amusement for the troops,also a profit for those running the games - We are getting used to the life now & are feeling fine. The weather was lovely to-day & the sea smooth - the milage at noon

was 301 & clocks were put back 17 minutes.The "Frankfurt" is as the name implies a German boat of I think about 9.000 tons & (has on no cargo & 1200 odd troops) was handed over to the Allies by the terms of Armistice with other shipping. She was laying up in German docks since 1915 & since being handed over has been fitted up at Glasgo shipbuilding yards for troops & this is her first trip. The crew are practically all Scotch & most of them demobilised men picked up in a hurry,a lot of them on their first trip. The flag used on these boats is white with a horisontal blue bar through the centre & is flown aft in Ports. The Kaiser at the beginning of the war (So some German papers stated) that though it needed a great number of ships to bring the Australians across to Europe it would only need two to take the remnants & records home after the war. I wonder what he thinks now some of his own boats are being used for this purpose (of taking the remnants home after they have done their share (& perhaps more) of dishing him up.)
as
besides lots of other boats.
Entry.942:
th
1919
The weather is beginning to get warm now & I have started cold salt water showers & discarded my uniform & boots for singlet,shorts & canvas shoes, no socks & no hat - & being a sun baby I spend a lot of time on deck in the sun. In the afternoon I joined the elementary French class^to beheld on No 2. lower deck daily from now on. I also drew a book from the library "Prentice Mulfords story" to read in my spare time. The milage at noon was 308 miles & clocks were put back 15 minutes -

Awnings stretched over the decks.

Sunday -
Entry.943:
th
 1919
As the awnings were over the decks I had to go onto the boat deck to sit in the sun - We had tinned salmon for tea & tinned fruit issued by comforts fund. I speculated in two-up during the day & won about 6/- to the good, since the awnings have been put up the pennies cant be used, but three three penny pieces are used & shaken in a dice box & tipped onto a board. Using three coins instead of two means a result every time, it is always two heads or two tails. The weather is beautiful & the sea smooth - The milage at noon was 305 - & the clocks were put forward 15 minutes
Entry.944:
th
 1919
I slept on deck last night in my hammock slung from the rail to a ventilator handle - the wind changed during the night from S.W. to N.E. I went to bed sheltered from the wind but in the morning it was blowing right on me & was cold - & a fair seawas running on our port quarter& made the boat roll a bit - I attended the French class in the afternoon & we also had boat drill - we had to parade up on deck with our life-belts on & wait till the signal all clear sounded - I am reading "The common touch"^Austin Phillip our milage at noon was 303 - & the clocks remained the same - I feel fit now but a few of the men are feeling a little sick & are not eating too well -
Entry.945:
th
 1919
I slept below last night as the wind was strong & cold - The wind which blew all day died down at Sunset - I attended the french class in the afternoon as usual & am able to learn some useful grammar - our milage at noon was 296 - & the clocks remained the same - The tucker is pretty good. the main differences in it for the days of the week are the soup at dinner,we get pea soup two days

next week & it is very good. The soup for the other five days is very poor. The pudding at dinner time is generally Sago,a very gluey concoction made with practically no milk, sometimes we have rice & raisins - for tea we have a dish of stew or some German sausage or braun & a dish of stewed dry fruit, apricots pears or apples - & sometimes buns. (for dinner we also have duff twice per week) we are issued with 3 pkts of cigarettes per week & 4 tins of condensed milk & 4 tins of fruit per mess per week also some biscuits -
Entry.946:
th
 1919
I slept on the after deck under the awning last night & it was grand.I slung my hammock from the sail to the platformover the steering mechanism.I got up at 5.30 amwhen the crew came along with brooms & hose to wash the decks - I attended the french class in the afternoon - I met one of the divy - Signallerswho came over on the "Medic" on our troop deck& had a yarn with him. I have also seen another man on the boat who came over on the Medic - The

weather is very warm now, most of the boys think it is too hot but I like it so. Our mileage at noon was 295. The clocks kept about the same.
Entry.947:
th
 1919
I slept on deck again last night but was not disturbd by the crew when they came along to wash the decks. The canvas baths were put up, one for'ard & one aft & were filled with sea water, there were great doings for'ard men were dumped in the bath clothes & all & two officers were put in. The adjutant of the Quota was one he was carried in his deck chair & put in chair & all - I had a dip just before I got into my hammock for the night, some of the boys were playing in the bath till about midnight when they were told to get out & keep quiet or the baths would be emptied as they were keeping the would-be sleepers awake, including the crew. The firemen are surely feeling the heat down in the stoke hold. Our mileage at noon dropped to 287 - we are travelling slightly east now & the clocks are going forward again they were put forward about 7 minutes
Entry.948:
th
 1919
We ran into a heavy rain & wind storm in the morning & it rained all day the sea also got up a bit - I read "The Patrol of Sun Dance Canyon" by Ralph Connor but did'nt care for it. Our mileage is still going down,at noon it was277 miles & clocks were put forward 7 minutes.
Entry.949:
th
 1919
I tried to sleep on deck last night but was forced belowby the rain. It is very stuffy below these nights. Talk is beginning to veer round towards Cape Town where we are making for - I read "The Special Messenger" R.W. Chambers. I find that with my mess orderly duties & the education classes & a certain ammount of letter writing etc. the time passes well & I dont have much time dragging - I do quite a lot of writing.Our mileage at noon was 272. & clocks were put forward 6 minutes.
Entry.950:
Sunday - I slept on deck last night,there was a church
at
service held in the morning,attendance voluntary - there is an inspection by Ships & Military officers daily of the troop decks etc but on Sunday there is no inspection. AStrong South wind was blowing all day but the sun was shineing & it was'nt cold

I saw the Southern Cross plainly at 8 pm& slept on deck - Our mileage was 239 - so far the lowest recorded - clocks were put forward 6 minutes.
Entry.951:
th
 1919
Sports were held to-day on the for'ard deck - Pillow fights over the water tank -
on a round pole
the contestants two at the time sat astride a round pole over the water tank & slogged at each other, it did'nt take much of a hit to dislodge an oponent & the effort used often dislodged the slogger. Egg & spoon races. Potato races - jumping. cock fights,obstacle races & tug-o'war in which I pulled for our deck. The deck was not well represented & losing the toss we had to pull up hill twice out of three pulls so we did'nt get a look in (the forward deck of a boat always slopes up towards the front) - We crossed the line at 10 pmlast night. The wind has been blowing hard all day& our mileage was. 252. the clocks went forward 7 minutes
Entry.952:
th
 1919
I slept on deck last night we had a slight shower early this morning but not enough to chase us below. The awnings were taken down from the for'ard deck & our deck but

the one over the after deck was left - It was read out in orders this morning that it is proposed to hold a sports meeting at the Oval in Cape Town the day after our arrival there,any applications for entry etc - fine day but windy. Our mileage at noon was 276 & clocks put forward 6 minutes
Entry.953:
th
 1919
Wireless reports that R.34 (Airship) leaves New York for East Fortune which I presume means that it has made a successful flight from England to America. It is still very windy & there is a fair swell. We are getting very light as the coal & tucker is being used & the propeller comes out of the water at every dip. Our mileage was 265 & clocks were put forward 7 minutes
Entry.954:
th
 1919
It still keeps very windy & though the sun shines all the time, the wind makes it cold - I attend the french class every day that it is held. Saturday Sunday & Sports days the Sergt dose'nt hold a class - several of the boys are getting colds,but so far I have escaped. Our mileage was 275. & clocks were put forward 7 minutes -
Entry.955:
th
 1919
I sleep on deck these nights & find it quite cold enough - the weather still keeps windy - The two-up kings who have been having a spell lately have started again with the pennies on the deck & once more money is changing hands but the men who are steadily making money are the ringkeepers - Sea gulls have made their appearance & are following the boat - Our mileage at noon was. 258 - & clocks were put forward 9 minutes -
Entry.956:
th
 1919
The proposed sports at the Oval in Cape Town are declared off, I presume because of insufficient entries - I am reading a book entitled "Nature & Nurture in Mental development" by F. Mott. It is a book that I think should be widely read & is very interesting - It was very windy all daybut the wind dropped in the evening - Our mileage at noon was 246 & clocks were put forward 14 minutes.
Entry.957:
th
 1919
Sunday - The sea is beautifully calm with a fair swell,the sun is beautiful & there is no wind. I lay out in the sun all the afternoon & dozed. We saw a shark cruising along with it's fin above water not

far from the boat. We have seen many times porpoises in schools gamboling along near the boat & sometimes they would swim along within a yard of the side of the boat & we could watch them under the water - We have also seen a few whales some distance out. We have seen them spouting,one was seen only about 100 yds from the boat but I did'nt see it -

There are plenty of gulls following the boat now all the time - Our mileage was. 281 & clocks were put forward 15 mins.
Entry.958:
st
 1919
There was a pay parade for No 1. Company (Queenslanders) at 9 am& it occupied all the morning. Aman in credit could draw £3- & without credit 14/- most of them drew 14/- particulars were also taken of where the men wanted their money sent to after they dis-embarked - There was a very big swell running & the boat rocked very much no classes were held to-day - Our mileage was. 296. Clocks were put forward 15 minutes - a singing competition was held on No 3. deck in the evening -
Entry.959:
nd
 1919
Windy & a very heavy swell still on. We expect to reach Cape Town to-morrow & uniforms are coming to light & boots etc polished up ready for

going ashore when the time arrives - I played cards all the evening by way of a change. Our mileage was 261 - clocks were put forward 14 minutes.
Entry.960:
rd
 1919
We came in sight of land at 10 am& the rails were lined to watch the coast. I had a bet at two-up to see if I was lucky but lost 9/- so quickly that I came to the conclusion that I was'nt & cleared - We pulled into Port at 12.30 pm.We had dinner & cleaned up & all went off at 2.35 pm,several of us stayed to-gether. I went up to the post office & mailed some letters first thing - then we went into a Café & had a good meal. I had lobster mayonaise & it was delicious & very cheap it cost us only 2/- apiece & the tea was a treat after the wash we get aboard. In the evening five of us went to the Tivoli theatre, but it was'nt much good - The Karmala which we passed at Anchor in Devonport & sailed shortly after us arrived here three days before us - & the Norman which left Blighty on July 5
th
 got here yesterday - We went into the Café & had cakes & tea & returned to the boat at 11.30 pm.
Entry.961:
th
1919
All men except those on duty on the boat & mess orderlies went ashore at 9.30 amto form a guard of honour to General Botha who arrived in this morning from Blighty in a Castle boat & is expected to go ashore at 10.30 am. We got our work finished & went ashore & waited up town & saw the procession. There was an unfortunate accident happened just before the procession arrived,a horse ran away with it's attendant vehicle & knocked down a girl (white) & a coloured man,the girl had her face badly cut & walked away escorted by a Digger - We went up & saw the gardens the museum & art gallery & then had a hot bath at the Municipal baths, came out & went into Joe's Café & had a feed of Fish & Chips - it was very good & only 1/- - The "Wiltshire arrived with troops this morning & leaves to-morrow for Durban to coal, there seems to be a shortage of coal here. The Norman (with troops)
col
took on all her coal here 2.300 tons - the Karmala (with troops) put on some coal but had to go to Durban for more. We are supposed to get some here & go to Durban for more. We are also loading 500 tons of maize & vegetables, meat etc

I wrote to Comte in Vic. & posted it as I expect the Norman will carry mails from here & will get to Aussie several days before us & as Comte was going Via Suez he would be home before we were in sight - We met some of the other boys at 10.30 pm& had a feed of cakes & tea & returned to the boat -
Entry.962:
th
1919
It rained nearly all night but cleared up in the morning. I went ashore by myself. I walked part way up the mountains & picked a bunch of silver leaves. I had a fine view of the town & Table Bay from the ridge I climbed to where there is a seat & a couple of old canon mounted. I bought an Ostrich feather at a place where they made them up & claims to be wholesale.I paid 10/6 for it & as far as I could judge it was a good one. I sent it by post to my Aunt in Kingston. I also sent some South African lucky beans to my sisters kids & wrote some letters. Fruit is very cheap here, bananas 25 for 1/- Mandarines as many as 50 for 1/- We are supposed to sail to-morrow for Durban so I took some fruit aboard with me. Fine day—
Entry.963:
th
 1919
The blue Peter was flying at the fore but they hauled it down at 9 am& continued coaling as some more coal had come to light that would save us going to Durban. - We were allowed ashore for the day - The "Prinz Hubertus" came in yesterday^with troopswith a big list to Starboard & is going to Durban (she is another German boat handed over by terms of Armistice) the Port Melbourne came in this morning also with troops - I did some more letter writing & in the afternoon went out & saw the "Cap Polonio" a large German vessel of 23 000 tons,three funnels which had experienced some difficulty in making the trip from England with South African troops & passengers. Water pipes were soldered up &
tw
bombs were discovered in different places, the bakers overn exploded & killed
two
two of the bakers & she had to call in at all ports to coal as she can only carry five days bunker - she is supposed to be the most luxuriously fitted up boat afloat. but visitors were not allowed aboard,so I couldnt go - she is about 750 feet long & on account of her build she only draws 29 feet of water (the Port Melbourne draws 31 ft - she was to have made a trip round the coast

but she has cancelled that & will sail on Aug 6th for Blighty - I went to the orchestral concert at the City Hall in the evening & it was beautiful, there was also dancing - I took some more fruit aboard with me - Bob & Jimmy were aboard the Port Melbourne & one of the boys met them in Cape Town, so I learned when I got aboard & it was too late to see them - Two Castle boats came in this morning with men & their wives from Blighty (Aussies)

Memo
My impressions of Cape Town
Entry.964:
are not the best the population consists of more Blacks than white people. There are a great number of half castes & apparently a very small percentage of pure whites - most of the whites are Dutch, though perhaps none the worse for that -

July 27
th
 1919
We pulled out at 8 amall very pleased to be on the way once more "The lone trail, the long trail, the trail that is always new. The "Norman" pulled out just ahead of us & is bound for Adelaide. The "Prinz Hubertus" pulled out just behind us & hugged us all day,she still had the same list on her that she had when she arrived

in Port. We hugged the coast all day until we passed a light house which was the last sight we had of land at 9 pm. The Prinz passed behind us & made in a Northerly direction headed for Durban. The boat was rolling heavily all day - it was fine but a cold wind blew all day. Our mileage at noon was 34 - on
leaving
arrivingat Cape Town the time was put forward one hour to coincide with Town time & on leaving Port it was altered back to true time -
Entry.965:
th
 1919
The nights are too cold now to sleep on deck. As we got further away from land the boat rolled less,the sea meeting us head on she pitched more,fine day & not so windy. I played cards in my spare time. Our mileage at noon was 258. & clocks were put
back
forward 30 minutes.
Entry.966:
th
 1919
Lovely day & the sea is calm but for a large swell - I attended french class to-day all talk now is centered on the next port of call Melbourne, where quite a few of the boys will be home & others very near home. Our mileage at noon was 259. & clocks were put forward 21 minutes -
Entry.967:
th
 1919
Fine day but strong North wind blowing towards evening the sea started to raise & we had to close our port holes on the weather side as the sea was coming in. Sea gulls or Albatross (I dont know one from the other) are still following us,though we must be some distance from land.We played five hundred in the evening.Our mileage at noon was 258. & clocks were put forward 24 minutes.
Entry.968:
st
 1919
The weather is dull & windy though not so windy as last night,& the sea is choppy. Ee are now having oranges issued every day sometimes by the comforts dept. & others by the
commi
cook house dept. Our mileage was 279. & clocks were put forward 20 minutes.
Entry.969:
st
 1919
To day is fine but still a bit windy, the nights are very wild, dark treacherous seas, scudding clouds & cold windy atmosphere, they
moon
make one think of the sailors life & be glad to have chosen a life ashore - In the daytime if the sea is smooth & the sun shining & warm a sailors life seems very pleasant but even then

one might as well be at the front as on the sea,right away from mankind in general (& the Women in particular)

The fresh water is only on three hours per day for all the troops,from 7 am- 8 am 12 noon - 1 pm. 5 pm. - 6 pm& it is necessary to stand in a queue to have a wash in the morning & those who lie in bed till breakfast time have to go without a wash till noon - The salttwater showers are always procurable.I generally patronise these just before dinner as it is the warmest time in the day - Our mileage at noon was 294 & clocks were put forward 20 minutes.
Entry.970:
nd
 1919
Fine day with a shower in the afternoon. The sea is calmer now than we have had it at all but the weather is too cool to be really pleasant. The sea looks cold & forbiding. We had a medical inspection in the afternoon & our deck had a whist drive in the evening,with fifteen games going on at the time,half of them were immaginery ladies for the evening & there was great fun especially when the booby prize was awarded,wrapped up in about twenty issues of paper,when it was
subs
at last unwrapped, it caused great hilarity

being an indiaruber head
with
which when it is pressed a tongue comes out. The Y.M.C.A has offered a first prize of £5- & a second prize of £2.10 - for the best rag time bands produced on the troop decks,costumes & instruments to be
ma
original. The competition is to be held next Friday. Our mileage at noon was 285. & clocks were put forward 25 minutes.
Entry.971:
rd
 1919
Sunday - Cold day & some rain the sea is still smooth - the rag time band has started practicing with tin whistles, mouth organs,a home made drum,a two string tin fiddle & some home made horns. If it has to be harmonious,I am sure that our deck will not get a place, unless it is the best of a bad lot - I got into my hammock in the afternoon & tried to sleep but could'nt on account of the infernal noise of this band.Early in the afternoon we had life boat drill which consisted of going up on deck when the alarm sounded,put on our life-belts & stand in a freezing wind till the all clear sounded. We are told off to rafts mine being 52. I dont know what we are supposed to do with the

rafts they would only hold about three men & about 14 men are told off to each one, I hope we wont have to use them. - I wrote some letters in the evening - Our mileage at noon was 311. the biggest run we have made on the trip - clocks were put forward 23 minutes.
Entry.972:
th
 1919
Cold & windy day - sports were held in the afternoon on the fora'rd deck. The same competitions were held as at the last sports meeting - I was again in the tug-o'war for my deck & again we lost the toss this time to pull twice out of three times on the slippery side of the deck,apart from the footing the pull was equal as they ran a rope from one side of the deck to the other with a block each side & both teams pulled up hill through the pulleys,but anyway the team we had was too light to win anything had we won the toss.

We heard rumours last night that the Norman had broken down & needed assistance & our increased speed gave credence to this rumour but things seem to be as usual again & no other word is heard of it - Our mileage at noon was 270 & clocks were

put forward 20 minutes.
Entry.973:
th
 1919
It is five years to-night that England declared war on Germany. What a lot has happened since then in every branch of science & in every persons life. I am glad that it is all over instead of just starting.

There was a heavy swell all day fromthe Starboard quarter & the wind is in the South & very cold - The Albatross are still with us,we have never been away from them since we left Cape Town. Our mileage at noon was 279. & clocks were put forward 23 minutes.
Entry.974:
th
 1919
To day the weather is very wild, a little rain & very windy & a big sea We are in wireless comunication with Perth & also with the Wiltshire which is said to be 6º south of us & to have run into a snow storm, the Norman told us that she had struck a gale & we are expecting to run into it also. We were all enoculated in the afternoon Our mileage at noon was 277. & clocks were put forward 20 minutes.
Entry.975:
th
 1919
We ran into a bit of a gale during the night & crockery began to fall

up on the sergeants deck, above us & soon our enamell ware took a Gaby glyde & with the noise of the things sliding & falling & cheers from the men all of whom the noise had awakened. In the morning it snowed a little & the wind was very cold - The wind shifted suddenly in the afternoon from South to North,& the sea was very big all day - There was no french class to-day on account of the discomfort of sitting any place sliding down the form every time she rolls. At meal times it is necessary to hold on to plates etc to save it sliding down to the other end of the table, it causes a lot of fun but is not comfortable.Ourmileage at noon was 253. & clocks were put forward 22 minutes.
Entry.976:
th
1919
The seas are mountaneus & the ship rolled & pitched very much, getting breakfast was the funniest stunt carying dishes down the quickly advancing & receding stairs,porridge spilt all over the place & if we got to the mess without casualty it was more by good luck than good management. After breakfast I carried a bucket of water up to empty overboard & was coming back again just put my foot on the

stair & she rolled & sat me down & I slid right down & brought up in the scuppers & I wasnt the only one to cause fun to the onlookers in the same way.I am still wearing shorts but wear also puttees & shirt & sweater & on deck, tunic.Our mileage at noon was 239. clocks were put forward 20 minutes.
Entry.977:
th
 1919
The wind has dropped & the seas are going down gradually, the boys have been below all the time the last day or so but they are able to spend a while on deck now withour freezing - it wa'nt too cold in the morning. Every one .seemed to be in a bad humour in the morning perhaps because of having been below so much in the stale air - We hear now that we are calling at Adelaide to disembark all South Aus. & West Aus. men.We are then going on to Melbourne to put all the rest of the troops off. Our mileage at noon was 243 & clocks
Entry.978:
th
were put forward 20 minutes.

Aug 10
th
 1919
The wind rose again in the West & veered round to the north, the sea is about the same, the Albatross are with us all the time. Being Sunday to-day there is no inspection & no classes

Our mileage at noon was. 265. & clocks were put forward 20 minutes.
Entry.979:
th
 1919
A beautiful day the wind shifted round & blew from the South - Wireless message from Aussie says the amount lost in wages on account of the strikes is estimated at three million Pounds - For some reason, our Starboard propellor was motionless for sometime during the morning, but it started again at noon. I was up on deck
last night
in the eveningtill 10.30 pm,there was a full moon & a big sea running from astern, it was grand, great rollers coming up from astern & rolling past us,the white crested waves, & foam looked fine in the moonlight, the wind changed round to the West again. I did'nt like leaving the deck to go to bed.

The Jaz-band competition which was postponed on account of the weather & the seas, was held during the afternoon & caused much amusement, the forward deck & rigging etc was crowded. There were four decks competing the Sergeants & No 5 deck were very poor,in costume & performance,there was absolutely no music in their bands, but No 4 deck which took first prize was well got

up, as a negro band, in light uniform made out of dungaree suits with stripes etc & silver buttons, & there was real music, they had a hand made violin & a splendid xylophone made out of enamelled cups etc. No 3 deck took second prize & was also very good being got up as Sundowners,carying their swags they all had white beards & walked with individual limps etc. their music was good but not nearly up to No. 4. -

No. 4 band also performed in the evening at a concert which was held on No. 3 deck. The signal lamp was being used from the bridge during the evening,presumeably to a ship somewhere ahead of us, perhaps the Wiltshire, which I believe has caught us up & is not far off.

I was up to the electricians cabin during the evening & was surprised at it's palacial or rather, homey apearance; about ten ft square, with two berths with chests of drawers underneath & curtains to draw, a Wardrobe, electric fan, electric heater & rose shaded fancy lamps, the cabin had three port holes. I could have enjoyed sleeping in it ahead of my hammock slung to the ceiling on the troop deck - Our mileage was 252 & clocks were put forward 22. mins.
Entry.980:
th
1919
Lovely day except for a west wind the sea is not so choppy & not quite so big. Some of the boys were yesterday ordered to clean down some paint work (crews duty) & refused (as was right) as their fares are paid as passengers. We are not supposed to be working our passage. One man was given 14 days detension & two others fined 14 days pay - the rest of the boys raised a row with the major & intimated rather strongly that they wanted the man out of clink right away,or he would go in,& they also wanted the crimes washed out. The man was released, but I don't know if the second demand has been granted. No more sports are to be held on account of the seas being too heavy. Whist drives will be held in lieu of - & money prizes given - we had a whist drive yesterday in which I played. I was running well till I struck a bit of bad luck & remained for nine
games
handsat one table. we played 24
games
- hands. We are said to have passed Perth on our North this morning - I was up on deck for a while in the evening enjoying the moon - Our mileage at noon was 265 & clocks were put forward 24 minutes.
Entry.981:
th
 1919
Lovely day - wind in the South but mild. There was a rainbow in the S.W at 7.30 am,they say "Rainbow in the morning,

sailors warning" during the day. I coppied sections from French road maps for future reference. - The Skipper of the boat gave a lecture in the afternoon, on the Pyramids,not knowing of it, I did'nt attend & by what the boys say, it was well worth attending.We put on speed during the evening & appeared to be travelling fast,our mileage at noon was 263. & clocks were put forward 24 minutes.
Entry.982:
th
 1919
A lovely day. The wind has dropped & the sea is tranquille. In the afternoon the Skipper lectured to the Sergeants on the Pyramids. The troops were paid 7/- to £1. apiece & two up which has'nt been plaid since a day after we left Cape Townhas started again with great ardour - The winches have been going all day getting chains etc from the hold ready for Port. - Our hammocks,cutlery etc. have been checked for shortages.I wrote a letter to Gisele & find a great improvement in my understanding of the French grammar. Our mileage at noon was 286 & clocks were put forward 22 minutes -
Entry.983:
th
 1919
Lovely day, sea calm, mild wind very changeable all day but not cold it was mostly East. We had a whist drive in the afternoon prizes £1,second 10/- third 5/- I was 30^pointsfrom winning number

In the evening there was a concert on No 3 deck (the last one to be held) the No 4 deck harmonius ragtime band played & the crew also gave a sketch, it was'nt too bad. If we get into Adelaide before noon on Sunday the South Aus. ("Crow Eaters" .) & West Aus. ("Sand Gropers") troops will go off & we shall leave within two hours, but if we get in after 12 noon we shall have to wait till Monday—

The electric lights of our deck are controlled from the Sergt's deck, & at nights it is very funny to hear the shouting for lights out etc. at 10 pm,those men in bed start, put those lights out you dopey sergts. with a few expressive adjectives thrown in, those men playing cards or not yet in bed say leave them on & this goes on for about five minutes every night, the lights going out & coming on two or three times (& each time a cheer) before they finally go out, a cheer from the victors & things quieten down again—

Our mileage at noon was. 299 & clocks were put forward 23 minutes.
Entry.984:
th
 1919
Lovely day & sea quite calm, East wind - we had a kit inspection in the morning to find dutiable articles. I dont think they found anything other than a few ostrich feathers which the fellows declared & consequently will have to pay

duty, we had a ragtime medical inspection in the afternoon. we walked past the Quack & he was supposed to be able to know if there was anything the matter with us. In the evening the Sergts had a very good concert on their deck, I heard a few items, the last few days, the boys have been "cawing" in imitation of crows, one man would start & then the chorus would take it up. Our mileage at noon was. 288 & clocks were put forward 24 minutes.
Entry.985:
th
 1919
We were running in between land when we got up & we ran along till noon & anchored off the Port, after dinner we had all our temperatures taken by the port authorities & then we pulled in to the wharf at 3 pm. No people were allowed on the wharf, but the girls broke down the barrier one end & overpowered the guard & got through, the people at the barrier the other end followed suit, there were general cheers from the boat when they broke through - The South Australians went off & were duly embraced & hurried off to their respective homes. The rest of us were allowed off from 6 pmtill 10 pmbut there was no place to go to except the Y.M.C.A where they held a concert for us. We were at the outer harbour & no trams or trains were running on account of the strikes - The Norman & Karmala



have been & gone & as we came in, the "Wiltshire" left - I left a note for Bob (on the Port Melbourne which is due to-morrow) with a Coast Guard. I went aboard again at 8.30 pm& went to bed. Our mileage at noon was 202 & clocks were put forward 42 minutes.
Entry.986:
th
1919
When we got up in the morning we were on the move, we left at 6 am,we passed the Port Melbourne just in— The weather is perfect & the sun lovely— Queenslanders were paid at 8.30 amfollowed by N.S.W & others - I was paid £5.- I spent most of the day on deck as the sun was lovely & warm, some of the men played two up until they were broke - I bound this diary in the afternoon. We played cards in the evening but I couldn't concentrate on them. I felt too restless. Our mileage at noon was 60 & clocks were put forward 10 minutes -
Entry.987:
th
 1919
We had a general clean up of the troop deck & handed in all life belts. The place now looks clean & tidy, there are many sorting out their kits & discarding old clothes. I sorted out my kit in the afternoon - In the evening we had a 12 hand whist drive.The winner was 91.I scored 81 - at 7 pmone of the stokers

(or trimmers) came up from the hold & jumped overboard, they stopped^the ship& lowered a boat & searched for him. (we finished our game & went on deck & watched them). They cruised around for a while by the light of an ascetylene lamp on the water. The water was smooth as a mill pond we were just off Cape Ottway - after a while they brought the boat in collecting the two life buoys which had been thrown out - they thought at one time that they had found the body but it turned out to be a shark - The crew made a poor show at hauling the boat up again on the davits, had there been anything but a very smooth sea it would have upset or broken it up. They pulled it up with the winches & first one end would go way up & nearly tip the men out of it, then the other end would go up with a rush & she would slew round & hit the ship a bang. The Captain said that it is not at all unusual for a man from the stokehold to go over the side. It sometimes affects their head -

The troops are already & only wait for morning - We expect to anchor at about midnight & the doctors will be aboard at 7 am.Our mileage at

noon was 270 & clocks were put forward 30 minutes & are now Melbourne time.
Entry.988:
th
 1919
Reveille 5.30 am. We got up & handed in our hammocks blankets etc & after breakfast our cutlery & all ship equipments. We then cleaned up took our kits on deck & waited the Vics went off first at 9.30 am. The Port Melbourne came in opposite to us ( Williamstown) & the Victorian troops were landed - We then went off at 10.30 amfollowed by N.S.W. men. We went straight onto a train waiting for us & left at 12.30 pm. We were not uncomfortable in the train & were given cake & tea. We had refreshments at Seymour, dinner at Aulbrey at 7.30 pm& changed trains - We were seven in a carriage in the N.S.W railway, two of us slept on the floor & the rest on the seats. We passed through a little rain of which the country weems to be in great need.
Entry.989:
st
 1919
We had breakfast at MossVale at 6.30 am,arrived in Sydney 10 am& changed to a hospital train, each man had a bed & found it very comfortable - we were given tea & biscuits on the Station & left at 11.25,we had dinner at Gosford at 1 pm& nothing more till we got to Werris Creek at 9 pmhaving suffered the pangs of

hunger meantime. I had a shave after supper & went to bed, some of the boys hadsome whiskey aboard & made a bit of a nuisance of themselves.
Entry.990:
nd
 1919
I slept well during the night on a lower bunk, we arrived at Wallangara at 8.30 am& had breakfast, changed into the Q'land train, into a first class carriage & left for Brisbane at 9.15 am.The country looked very dry all along the line - we had a snack at Warwick & dinner at Toowomba at 12.noon. Another snack at Hellidon & arrived at Brisbane at 7.15 pm& were taken by Motor to Kangaroo Point hospital where we were given a meal amidst speeches from the heads, after which we were boarded & given our passes etc & turned loose pending discharge.
